snippet.textDisplay:
I describe DS2 as my least favorite (except demons souls) but it had by far the strongest potential to be my favorite 

-Make the combat less "floaty" and more like DS1 (or DS3). Give it more weight. Hard to explain, but it plays significantly worse than other souls games 
-Better connectivity between areas 
-Harder bosses with more unique movesets
-Remove lifegems
-Remove half the samurais in iron keep
-Make the graphics less muddy

snippet.textDisplay:
one reason why DS2 is peak is that everything has a reason and lore.

we can take throne and temporarily cure curse but on the process we die.
or we can reject the throne to find another cure to the curse Which is the Blessed crown. we can complete all DLCs which are ancient kingdoms destroyed by Queens which are  Fragments of  Manus.

The Curse was caused by Manus and the answer or cure to this curse lies in Manus or in the fragments of manus.

if u collect all crowns from 4 ancient kingdom namely Drangleic Castle , Ancient Sunken kingdom, Frozen Eleyum , Brum tower that was destroyed by Queens (fragments of Manus) , If u bring that 4 crowns to vendrick he will bless it and give it to us.


and that crown is the Cure to the Curse. wearing that  crown from inventory prevents us from hollowing.
and We essentially become IMMORTAL. cause no matter how much times we die we will not become hollow.

snippet.textDisplay: Look I'll be honest. I want to like dark souls 2. It had some qualifying factors that did carry over into future games not because they had to but because they were good inventions in the game... However, my biggest complaint will always be the geometry and level layout. None of it feels good and the way your character moves and fights doesn't feel good either. The lighting isn't what they promised it would be, which was a huge letdown. My three major gripes.... However, it gave us plus 1 and plus two and plus three rings which was a fun addition. It gave us like you said the bonfire aesthetics which haven't been seen since it gave us new game plus monster and boss interactions that are different and invasions that are different by being a new game so it had a lot of great things..... But all of that was slathered on top of a cake that was sloppily made at its core. The true level design in this game is just garbage... Not even going to bring up the obvious stuff. I simply don't like how anything looked traversed or felt

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who did DS2 after 3 and 1, it will feel clunky at first. B8t slowly as you get used to the game you will appreciate it. Sure it has ADP stat, enemy ganking, unfair death mechanic and lots of aggrevating aspects. But after coming to Majula and seeing my companions there, it gave me a calming feeling. Diving into the main and DLC story. I was in love with the tragedy of them. Despite the low amount of decent bosses, Fume Knight was one of my favourite Souls bosses. Overall I really had th3 feels after choosing the Aldia ending. Overall, I'd say if you love Souls, give this game a chance. It will hurt you a bit at first, but soon you'll start to see how good it can get despite the flaws.

snippet.textDisplay: Bosses in dark souls 2 isn't really that good. There's only three categories. Super easy doing nothing but a few attacks boss. Bullshitty gimmick bosses that are more annoying than difficult. Finally, the good bosses. The fact that most of the bosses you fight in the first half of the game is the former two makes the experience so bad for newbie players. The only memorable one I fought on my first playthrough was probably Pursuer (although that got old due to its persistent reappearance). I never really got the boss hype until I got to Velstadt. The DLC bosses more than made up for the sheer lack of amazing boss fights in the entire game. But to end on a Nashandra and Aldia, it's just a very disappointing boss encounter journey overall. Compare this to DS3 where every boss is at least memorable in some way, it's just hard to go through this game without hating it in some way. The most memorable boss fight for me in this game is probably Fume Knight, Sinh, and Alonne - which says a lot because these three are DLC bosses. It speaks volumes that the only memorable bosses are DLCs and not base game + the fact that the DLC areas (except Frigid Outskirts) are the most fun to explore areas in this game.

The only memorable one I fought on my first playthrough was probably Pursuer (although that got old due to its persistent reappearance). I never really got the boss hype until I got to Velstadt. The DLC bosses more than made up for the sheer lack of amazing boss fights in the entire game. But to end on a Nashandra and Aldia, it's just a very disappointing boss encounter journey overall. Compare this to DS3 where every boss is at least memorable in some way, it's just hard to go through this game without hating it in some way. It speaks volumes that the only memorable bosses are DLCs and not base game + the fact that the DLC areas (except Frigid Outskirts) are the most fun to explore areas in this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember when DS2 just released. Everyone was hyped, and I don't remember a lot of discourse about the original until a few videos blew up. It was generally considered a really good game, not better than Dark Souls, but an incredible game nonetheless. It was only after Joseph Anderson's video, and a few other people started getting really vocal that the game sort of suffered in terms of opinion, but generally, the engagement was great. You can still find LPDarksoulsHD first run somewhere on YT I think, and generally, that will give you a generally good idea of what the hard core fans thought at the time. Community was a lot smaller back then, but we were just glad to have more Souls in our lives. 

Scholar on the other hand... yeah, that kind of tanked everyone's opinion of the game - but also, Dark Souls 2 is unique in that it plays a lot slower, and you need to be smarter with the game than in the others. Taking your time, strategy, using the correct items and exploring, never just rushing through - there is a reason why everyone agrees the build diversity of DS2 is only outstripped by Elden Ring. An incredible game, best one to play through when not trying to boss rush, and a phenomenal time. So many good memories.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who loves this game, I appreciate your praise of DS2 and specifically trying to get others to play it and not skip over it (something which very few people mention but I've noticed happens a lot). However, some points you made rub me the wrong way and ended up leaving a bad taste in my mouth at the end of the video.

(4:13 - 5:10) Dark Souls 2 takes a different approach to DS1 where it does everything in its power to prevent you from simply running past enemies. This was to punish DS1 veterans who would simply run past all the enemies and to encourage a slower approach to the game (and you don't need to have played DS1 to recognize the game wants you to take things slow and to clear every enemy). It's really weird then for you to run past all of the enemies in Heide's Tower of Flame with... fists only? while in NG+ and understanding there would be even MORE enemies, and then complain about enemies ganking you. And complaining about how far they followed you. That is what you get for not respecting the enemies of this game! If you made it all the way to NG+, you should've learned that lesson by then. You should've been taking out those enemies instead of letting them pile up on you, and if you chose to run past because of your fist-only run, that's an issue with fists-only and you should not have used that as an example of ganky enemies. It feels like I'm watching one of those poorly made critiques of DS2.

Also I'm not sure why you say this is an issue with SotFS, the mindset was in base DS2 as well (and SotFS removed a lot of the ambushes that was in the base game and shrunk down the amount of enemies in a lot of areas). I never felt encouraged to run past enemies except for one instance in Shrine of Amana when playing SotFS for the first time last year, and even when replaying the game multiple times, I still don't run past everything; and a friend of mine who played DS2 for the first time was playing SotFS and they didn't do that either (or at least, if they did, they quickly learned their lesson), so I don't know why you're attributing your poor gameplay to SotFS.

(6:05 - 6:21) That's just... not true about The Pursuer lol. The curse stab doesn't let him use dark magic attacks against you (and while I haven't gotten stabbed by that in SotFS, I did a couple of times in vanilla, so if you have footage of that happening when you first fight the Pursuer in the Forest of Fallen Giants, you should've shown that instead). He gains new dark magic attacks based on the area he's in. I have faced that dark magic attack many times without getting stabbed by the curse stab. In some other areas, he gains an expanded sword moveset, or can shoot magic waves at you with his sword that deal physical damage.

(9:15 - 9:51) This is more subjective but I personally feel like Dark Souls 2 is the best story out of all three games, and even to a younger version of myself who didn't read too much about the lore and didn't look into the themes of the game, the plot was more engaging than DS3 (Dark Souls 1 was the last Souls game I played, after Elden Ring, so I didn't have an opinion on that game). The game expanding on the Undead Curse from Dark Souls 1 that wasn't explored properly enough, what it means to be Undead and to have your memories and sense of self slowly hollow away till you become a shell of your former self, is extremely engaging. Unlike Dark Souls 1 and 3 which focuses on larger than life figures who are way past their prime and where many of the major events of the game happen long before you come along, you instead focus on one man - King Vendrick - and everyone surrounding him and his rule. The war of Drangleic and the giants, his attempts to rid Drangleic of the Undead, his attempts - and failure - to cure the Undead Curse, and him retreating into the deepest parts of the kingdom, both to hide from his wife, Nashandra, and to hide in shame and regret. More focus is given on the other NPCs as well and how they each manage the Undead Curse, how it slowly whittles away at their minds. And if you're keen enough, Vendrick's brother Aldia and the sheer amount of effort he put into finding a cure for the Undead Curse. It all feels so much more personal, especially because you both have a narrative reason and a gameplay reason to want to get rid of hollowing and the Curse (due to your health shrinking from dying), and because of how it's eroding away at almost everyone you meet.

Even if you aren't a fan of that or find DS1 or 3 more appealing, I wouldn't at all call it weak, and it expands on DS1's story and world in a much better way than DS3 did, which just tiredly rehashes the same old ideas and concepts and even some of the figures, and while it tries to make that the point, is too blinded by nostalgia to stick the landing. DS2 just has different priorities in storytelling than DS1, and certainly DS3.

(11:50 - 12:08) I won't go into detail here since it's been mentioned a lot, but the Throne of Want represents the decision to link the First Flame or usher in an Age of Dark, whereas abandoning the throne with Aldia means rejecting the choice and choosing to find a cure for the Undead Curse instead. It's why Vendrick was able to make that choice and is characterized by being afraid of making that choice, it's why Nashandra was urging him to let the First Flame die, and it is why she fights you for the throne at the end instead now that Vendrick and his guards are gone, so she can make that choice herself.

(15:13 - 15:31) Yeah, the animations are slow... that's the point? It's around the same in Dark Souls 1 as well. I've never noticed a difference in how the animation speed feels (hard to compare animations between the two because they are in different engines and don't share any weapon animations) when going from DS1 to 2 or vice versa. They are slower-paced than Bloodborne, DS3 (which became faster after Bloodborne), and Elden Ring, but even then, the point has always been that the animations are slow and deliberate. Maybe that's a negative for you, and that's okay, but it is not exclusive to DS2, it's in DS1 as well (and I specifically enjoy the slower, "turn-based" nature of those two games) and I'm sure it's in Demon's Souls as well.

Also, unrelated to any point, but I think it would've been really nice if you did different builds that weren't just... the rapier and the Tseldora set, or fists only. Like you didn't have to do anything crazy, honestly you could've just used a longsword or something basic, but rapier + Tseldora set just feels like something other people who shit on DS2 use a lot and it gives weird vibes to me as this is a video that's supposed to be praising DS2. Especially because build variety is so good in DS2, it would've been great to see you explore that.

*****

Sorry for all of the complaints and nitpicks! I love this game a lot and while normally I wouldn't spend so much time on something like this, they started adding up for me to the point where I wasn't enjoying the video and I didn't see much people bringing up these points. I do really appreciate you trying to change people's minds about DS2 and encouraging them to try it out, I just feel the execution wasn't completely there. Hope you have a good day <3

snippet.textDisplay:
4:58 "[SotFS] teaches you to run past enemies instead of just fighting them one by one"
Wow, I would literally flip that opinion upside-down. If anything, the tougher enemy placements encourage you to play slowly and methodically, baiting out enemies one-by-one so you don't aggro too many at once and get overwhelmed. Attempting to run past enemies, which usually works really well in every other Souls game, is probably the single biggest mistake I see people making when they get their ass kicked in SotFS. In fact, I think that's the whole entire reasoning behind the new placements in the first place.

snippet.textDisplay:
The funniest thing about people hating on DS2 is that DS2 (or at least the scholar edition) is the only properly optimized title in the ENTIRE SERIES (Demons Souls remake and DS1R don't count). It also has the story delivered in the most comprehensive way, somehow.

I wanted to get into Dark Souls but could never stand the performance issues of 1 and 3. I still avoided playing Elden Ring before I got a PS5, and still I have to run a PS4 version through backwards compatibility because the PS5 version couldn't be fucked to run at 60 fps. For a series of games requiring precision and timing,  performance has been completely shit throughout.

The Scholar version of 2 ran like a charm on my GTX550ti with a shitty AMD FX series processor, and I was able to enjoy it through and through, to then move on and play DS3 and DS1R later when I have upgraded my rig half a year later.

Surprisingly, even playing ER I find myself enjoying the parts of it that feel like DS2 more.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Dark Souls 2 is a good game guys, c'mon. Really though, give it a shot. It's definitely different, but that's okay. This game shouldn't be ignored."

Needed ignore or mod the problems this game has and try resolve myself the problems of this game.

"Why there is no Keyboard icons? Why i can put controls in keyboard and mouse for the same thing but i can't remove controls? Why the attack button has so much delay, oh, this can be fixed by activating the "disable double-click" option, why this option is bugged and aren't saved by the game and i need reactivate every time I enter in game?"

Then, playing the game is like:

"Oh, Jesus Crist, the character is soooooo slow. I have an delay if I just walk and then walk backwards. Bluh, I need more souls to upgrade my ADP, AAAA stupid I-Frames Idea, Again I'm being hitted by enemies because of that bad idea."

In my playthroughs of Dark Souls 2, I always feel like I'm not enjoying it and that I'm just dragging myself to keep playing the game. Man, I tried to give it a chance like you said, but I just can't. I feel much better replaying Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring than forcing myself to play Dark Souls 2.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark souls 2 is my favorite out of the series. A lot of the experimental ideas hit really well, and the stage design was peak in my opinion. I really really love the lighting in the game, the contrast between lights and darks, and the ability to remove enemies from the map by killing them enough times. The game's plot was loosely tied into the degeneration of your character's memories and identity, so being able to use ascetics to re-spawn things and being able to remove them was interesting in that context. it was like your character waded through memories and reality at the same time story wise.
Also the DLC was pretty good overall.

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved the original Dark Souls 2, primarily for it's PVP. But then they decided to heavily nerf basically everything in the game except for dark magic, basic dark magic skills could one/two shot you no matter what you were wearing. Yet you could use the sunlight spear, with the strongest faith equipment in the game, and only do 1/3 of their life. The PVP quickly died at that point. Which means the covenants quickly died. Which resulted in the game feeling empty and boring, and also made grinding effigy's extremely tedious because online covenant play was the only consistent way to do this. 
TL;DR they killed their game through patches.

snippet.textDisplay: Im gonna be honest, I dont think SOTFS encourages running past enemies. In the dragon clip you showed where you got ganked, you could only possibly get that many enemies to follow you by running past them all and ignoring them. If you actually take the encounters one at a time, they become much more manageable, as you're able to slowly push forward and pull enemies into more manageable arenas since you've cleared everywhere before. Even the enemies stopping respawning after killing them too many times also reinforces this, as if you keep pushing forward and killing enemies but keep dying anyway, eventually the slow push becomes easier, as the earlier areas become permanently cleared. You are absolutely not taught to just run past all the enemies, in fact I think you are taught the opposite. I would like to know what makes you think that SOTFS teaches you to avoid enemies though.

snippet.textDisplay:
People are way too hard on this game. This game is the tits! First souls game that I played, and it put me down the path of platinum-ing each souls game (with the exception of Sekiro) 

This game added so many important ideas and mechanics that became staples of the series. And some I wish they carried over! Like new items and events in NG+ or the use of bonfire ascetic to replay areas and bosses!

And people love to crap on DS2 bosses, but every game has some that are crap design for one reason or another other (I’m looking at you Pinwheel, Micolash, BED OF CHAOS, dragon god, etc)

DS2 will always have a special place in my heart. Is it the best? Nah. But it’s a solid entry with great ideas.

snippet.textDisplay: While it did have some actual problems with it came out, the fact is that after Scholar and updates, the problems were gone or not noticeable. The fact that the problems videos and threads harp on about are *_ALWAYS_* either before Scholar and updated fixes or require a microscope to even find at all tells me that there isn't really any argument against the game anymore and there hasn't been for years. It then comes down to nothing more than preferences about some gameplay design features such as adaptability and the movement control change.
snippet.textOriginal: While it did have some actual problems with it came out, the fact is that after Scholar and updates, the problems were gone or not noticeable. The fact that the problems videos and threads harp on about are *_ALWAYS_* either before Scholar and updated fixes or require a microscope to even find at all tells me that there isn't really any argument against the game anymore and there hasn't been for years. It then comes down to nothing more than preferences about some gameplay design features such as adaptability and the movement control change.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've only played Scholar, but at no point in my playthroughs outside of a boss door run back that I'm comfortable and confident that I know what I'm doing, did I ever feel "I should just run through this."

I feel like you might enjoy Domo3000s videos on DS2 and Scholar, defending them from the blind hate that gets thrown around a lot, with hit boxes shown across all 3 DS games, sometimes DeS, and even ER sometimes. As well as pointing out staged things in videos while giving other examples. Thanks to them I now know the giants hitboxes are one of the few *actually* inflated as fk in the game, but also that the weapon hitboxes in 3 are the most inflated in the original trilogy. Among other things.

snippet.textDisplay:
I cannot understand why everyone loses their mind because you can have "infinite" (up to 99) small life gems, they only heal a little tiny bit of hp and it's over multiple seconds, 

Specially because it seems as if no one even dares mention the fact ds1 had the almost instant full heal humanities and twin humanities that both also stack up to 99 (for a total of 198, tho good luck finding twin humanities), they (the regular humanities) are really easy to farm very early game in the Depths and get even easier in lategame of the DLC, also let's not forget every single humanity you use increases your resistances, item discovery chance and even the damage you do on certain weapons

If people where more objective when comparing Souls titles, they'd realize Humanities were a disgustingly overpowered item that nullifies the game's difficulty once you start using them, and life gems in contrast are a very well balanced item that gives you a tiny bit of bonus healing for a small amount of souls, only really there to motivate you to explore the map more, not to cheese the game

snippet.textDisplay: Scholar teaches you the opposite of needing to run through areas, doing so will lead to you getting ganked. All the huge ganks you showed in that section were due to you running past and getting the attention of way more enemies than you would ever have the attention of if you quickly took them out one by one instead of running past. You could argue that heavy encouring the player to play slow and methodical is bad, but saying that the game teaches you to run past enemies when doing so is the cause of your complaint is weird. Domo3000 on youtube has a lot of great videos comparing the Vanilla and Scholar versions as well as showing off how almost every example of a bad gank is caused by running through the area, getting the attention of all the enemies. Still, a great video!

snippet.textDisplay:
While I call it the worst of the Souls games, it's also somehow the one i keep coming back to the most. The changes to the game can make it frustrating as all get out, but once you get the hang of it you'll find a different but very intriguing and absorbing loop that will keep you coming back. Paradoxically, it is also the most free and flexible of progressions of all the Souls games.

Hopefully I managed to explain myself well.

snippet.textDisplay:
im just gonna go ahead and like/sub only 51 secs in. so im replaying the series myself after getting a friend into it. just finished up with int and faith builds in ds1. was a blast. now im onto ds2, my personal favorite of the trilogy. demon's is my actual favorite, but its bc it was my first experience with the 'series.' i think we are all a lil biased towards whatever our introduction was, and i think thats valid. ANYWAYS, thank you. you've alrdy made me happy cry from the intro alone bc i feel very much the same. ok back to actually watching, but i just wanted to say thanks for making this even if you feel like its just 1 of many. those few matter, bc those few are the ones that appreciate the game for what it is, instead of what it isnt. the whole reason i stumbled on this vid is bc i wondered while playing if the stigma surrounding ds2 has changed at all.

edit:

concerning enemies spawns AND some of the bosses. imma just get this spill outta the way. i think a lot of ds2's design choices were specifically meant to target habits ds1 players developed. things like iframes on levers and fog doors. things like running thru entire areas unpunished. things like spamming dodge roll instead of timing dodges (bc in ds2, stam econ is much more rigid.) anyways, i think all those things were meant to increase difficulty if you didnt adapt. what i mean by that is taking advantage of the despawn mechanic. how i think they WANTED you to play, is slower, taking out problem enemies, so your runbacks were either completely enemy free, or you made it to the boss with more supplies. one of the best examples of this i can remember are the degrade bugs in shrine of amana right next to a bonfire. you were clearly meant to despawn those before progressing. or for example, all the enemies surrounding strand. anywho, my point is, i think the balance of enemies is designed with some of those enemies being despawned by players. what that means for players who dont interact at all with those systems is they end up chased by a horde of enemies treating ds2 runback's like ds1 (or whatever other title.) i also think the reason bosses feel weaker as a whole is bc the area itself AND the boss are the 'fight' in a way. its a battle of attrition, of who can sustain longer almost. so i think the areas were made harder, while the bosses are oftentimes weaker. this is true for areas even in ds1, like blighttown, catacombs, or sen's for example. 

favorite areas: no mans wharf, shrine of amana, gutter, lost bastille, black gulch, drag castle, undead crypt, dragon aerie, dragons sanctum, and frozen eleum loyce

favorite bosses: pursuer, chariot, looking glass knight, fume knight, and sir alonne

this is SUCH a refreshing video, i cant even put into words how much i enjoyed this. life gems are my main form of healing generally. to balance out being able to get them early on i like to only buy them after ive lvled up. so say i have 15k souls, use 12k on lvls, then spend 3k on life gems. it gives those souls a use and also helps with not just having an overabundance of life gems early on. i very much agree even the negs are a part of the game as well, and you learn to appreciate or at the very least understand them.

I played dark souls II for the first time 2 years ago and hated it. Played it with kbm after i've finished DS1 before (as my first souls game ever). Especially the animation delay made it really unfun to me (so i used cheats just to get the story, lore stuff and completely abandoned challenging myself with its combat xd).
Last month after playing dark souls 1, 3 and elden ring for hundreds of hours i thought i give it another chance and it clicked 100%. The game is really enjoyable when you know how to handle yourself. The pre experience in all the different souls games definitely helped me coping with most of the janky/ unfair stuff in ds2. Now i love it (almost as much as the other 2 dark souls games). Really enjoyed the whole story with all the different areas and even the dlcs. I still hate the coffin snow area with its endboss in ivory king dlc. xd

snippet.textDisplay:
I knew people hated ds2, but I actually like ds2 from the looks of it. I think people hate it are some of the mechanics and I guess the HUD on screen, it looks out of place for some reason.

I love the very different atmosphere in the outside environement, it gave it a pretty nice change of pace. The bright sunlit when you're outside seems great, although it looses that dark eerie atmosphere from the previous and ds3, it's different. I think people would look back at ds2 and might appreciate the changes/new things added. 

Ds2 seems like an experimentation stage, as I knew that Miyazaki didnt direct it. 

It may not work for a lot of people but considering fromsoft and Miyazaki experimented shows they care, instead of staying safe.

You tend to fail first before actually improving.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree for the most part except for two points.

DS2 is the only entry that actually teaches you to confront each level at a slow and steady pacing. It's why we have Lifegems for downtime healing and counteracting the poison statues. This isn't runback city where you can roll spam (DS3 & Elden Ring) because the stamina system and the AGILITY stat (note: NOT ADAPTABILITY) discourages this "strategy". In fact, this is very evident by the fact that enemies are permanently despawned (until you burn a bonfire ascetic ofc) if you keep eliminating them multiple times every bonfire reset which rewards those who take time and effort to engage with this mechanic with a guaranteed safe journey to the boss if it ever proves difficult. Granted, this poses the risk of being vulnerable to the Soul Memory mechanic if you choose to engage with online mode or not equip the Agape Ring.

I have no freaking idea why ADP is the only attribute being blamed, considering ATN also affects the true culprit of this system. Pure mages can choose to just keep levelling ATN and never engage with ADP; they'll still get increased estus chugging speed and more roll i-frames. I get the idea for ADP tho. It was meant to be a dump stat along with ATN for the heavy load builders who do not wish to engage with rolling. I do like what it should've done for the pvp scene, as it makes it realistic for casters to not be all-in nukers (they sadly failed at it since player characters have always been vulnerable to dark damage so hexers stay winning) if they want survivability that is not in the form of VIG pump, for heavies to retain the realism that rolling is a very high risk option for them when they can instead dump those points on VIG, END, and VIT (also failed since it's easy to attain medium roll with a modest VIT investment unless going for extremely high poise builds), or for hybrids who get to have an option of whether speccing into a caster-heavy playstyle (full ATN until desired slots and AGI levels) or only utilizing magic for utility and other non-spellbuff dependent castings (20 ATN for spellswording, 30 ATN for utility casters + any ADP level into desired AGI).
snippet.textOriginal:
I agree for the most part except for two points.

DS2 is the only entry that actually teaches you to confront each level at a slow and steady pacing. It's why we have Lifegems for downtime healing and counteracting the poison statues. This isn't runback city where you can roll spam (DS3 & Elden Ring) because the stamina system and the AGILITY stat (note: NOT ADAPTABILITY) discourages this "strategy". In fact, this is very evident by the fact that enemies are permanently despawned (until you burn a bonfire ascetic ofc) if you keep eliminating them multiple times every bonfire reset which rewards those who take time and effort to engage with this mechanic with a guaranteed safe journey to the boss if it ever proves difficult. Granted, this poses the risk of being vulnerable to the Soul Memory mechanic if you choose to engage with online mode or not equip the Agape Ring.

I have no freaking idea why ADP is the only attribute being blamed, considering ATN also affects the true culprit of this system. Pure mages can choose to just keep levelling ATN and never engage with ADP; they'll still get increased estus chugging speed and more roll i-frames. I get the idea for ADP tho. It was meant to be a dump stat along with ATN for the heavy load builders who do not wish to engage with rolling. I do like what it should've done for the pvp scene, as it makes it realistic for casters to not be all-in nukers (they sadly failed at it since player characters have always been vulnerable to dark damage so hexers stay winning) if they want survivability that is not in the form of VIG pump, for heavies to retain the realism that rolling is a very high risk option for them when they can instead dump those points on VIG, END, and VIT (also failed since it's easy to attain medium roll with a modest VIT investment unless going for extremely high poise builds), or for hybrids who get to have an option of whether speccing into a caster-heavy playstyle (full ATN until desired slots and AGI levels) or only utilizing magic for utility and other non-spellbuff dependent castings (20 ATN for spellswording, 30 ATN for utility casters + any ADP level into desired AGI).

snippet.textDisplay:
It's an issue to use such hyperbolic language, but with "criminally underrated" aside, all of the issues you describe are the many of the primary issues that people have with the game. It isn't hated for the wrong reasons, it is hated for the reasons that you describe in the video. Plus some - like the ganking being emblematic of a much larger issue when it comes to handling enemy design, placement, and even level design. This feeds into the boss issue, which really placed normal enemies in groups to make a despawning set of enemies into a boss.
Some other things you describe are very personal. This is fine, but it shouldn't surprise anyone that others could feel the opposite. Dark Souls 2 feels very small and disconnected to me. I don't get that sense of wonder when approaching areas from far away because in simple moments I'm already gone. Each area feels individually smaller than in Dark Souls 1 - whether this is objectively true or not, I don't know - and I can't think of any areas that I can see in the distance aside from some I might see from Majula. It's also possible that I've already been to some, because little emphasis is placed on being able to see a cohesive world. 
I'd say Dark Souls 2 is rated appropriately, rather than underrated. The people that truly like it do so with caveats, and those that can't get past its many objective flaws don't like it. This is a deserving spot for the game. 
I am playing Scholar of the First Sin right now. I didn't buy it, I am family-sharing it on Steam, and I am glad because it's such a scummy thing for them to have paywalled 60fps and forced these odd updates into the game. I'm also glad because the parry, backstab, platforming, and hitboxes are frankly embarrassing. 

ADP.

These problems don't erase the good qualities of the game, but they are layered underneath some very serious problems that you have to constantly wade through to see the hard work that the team put into it. Whether these make up for the game  are up to you, but pretty much everyone seems to agree that they "make up for" the bad parts. This isn't something you say about an all-around great game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here’s my issue with Dark Souls 2 and it totally comes from personal experience:

I used to really like Dark Souls 2 - to the tune of a couple hundred hours. But I very recently tried to play it after a fairly decent hiatus and I genuinely despised the experience to the point that I couldn’t be bothered to finish the game. I hated the masochism, the crap feeling of the controls and the nonsensical level design. And it made me realise that all of the things that made Dark Souls 2 really cool for me once were not there anymore - or I’d have to dig for a hundred hours to find it again… not worth it. And this mostly stems from the fact that I just could not justify playing Dark Souls 2 when there’s so many better games that I could have been playing

However, I am really glad that you went in-depth on some of the more strange decisions that Scholar made - those “gank-squads” are ridiculous! And I remember being able to run through levels like a speed-runner, but years later I found this to be very unsatisfying. I couldn’t justify skipping the game, it felt like cheating and I know boss-runs have been a thing since Demon’s Souls but it didn’t justify the experience for me
snippet.textOriginal:

I used to really like Dark Souls 2 - to the tune of a couple hundred hours. But I very recently tried to play it after a fairly decent hiatus and I genuinely despised the experience to the point that I couldn’t be bothered to finish the game. I hated the masochism, the crap feeling of the controls and the nonsensical level design. And it made me realise that all of the things that made Dark Souls 2 really cool for me once were not there anymore - or I’d have to dig for a hundred hours to find it again… not worth it. And this mostly stems from the fact that I just could not justify playing Dark Souls 2 when there’s so many better games that I could have been playing

However, I am really glad that you went in-depth on some of the more strange decisions that Scholar made - those “gank-squads” are ridiculous! And I remember being able to run through levels like a speed-runner, but years later I found this to be very unsatisfying. snippet.textDisplay:
90% of gank issues with scholar literally boil down to skissue. Of course if you run through everything thinking you're playing DS3 you'll get your ass handed to you. 
Essentially SoTF is much more similar to DeS in the sense that the 'challenge' of the game is the areas leading up to bosses, as opposed to bosses being the 'challenge' at the end of areas.
You shouldn't be having more than 3 mobs on you unless you're intentionally (or rather cluelessly) grabbing unnecessary aggro.

snippet.textDisplay:
You mention the DS2's slower combat and say it's one of the downsides of this game. But for me, it's one of the significant upsides! I *adore* the combat of DS2 and its speed is a big part of that. 

I really, really don't like what they did to DS3 and Elden Ring after Bloodborne. All of those games are insanely fast, fast animations, fast attacks, gigantic bosses that all look like lumps of flesh jumping around the whole arena spamming you with infinite combos and AoE's that cover the whole arena, UGH. 

I understand why Bloodborne is like that, it's a different game, a different "franchise", with a different style of combat, and it's okay to be a lot faster in Bloodborne (I also love Sekiro and especially Lies of P, which is my absolute favorite soulslike ever, they're very fast, but, again, those are completely different games with different combat rules), but I'll never understand why they took the insanely fast/twitchy/combo-heavy/AoE-spammy formula to Dark Souls and beyond, turning DS and ER into some kind of DMC wannabe. It just ruined those games for me.

That's why DS2 is the last true Dark Souls for me, with its slower, more strategic combat, where every hit matters and feels meaningful, its slower combat feels a million times better, and that's also why, among other things, I love DS2 so much more than any other FromSoft title.

It just ruined those games for me.

That's why DS2 is the last true Dark Souls for me, with its slower, more strategic combat, where every hit matters and feels meaningful, its slower combat feels a million times better, and that's also why, among other things, I love DS2 so much more than any other FromSoft title.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark souls 2 is the only fromsoft game I didn't finish because I got bored

Sekiro I actually didn't finish because my reflex are not fast enough and I eventually hit a boss that I wasn't able to handle so eventually I took the L and moved on

But DS2 nah I was making progress, the boss felt laughably easy in fact, but damn I was simply not having fun. 

An action game where the core gameplay is to walk away slowly, wait for the 3 ennemies to all hit the void, then hit one once and repeat that 15 times for the 10 groups of the area, is not a fun action game

An rpg where you only start having fun with your build 20 hours in and before you are just doing normal attack and slowly increasing your 3 mandatory stats to acceptable level like you're doing homeworks is not a good rpg

If y'all managed to enjoy it despite that, that's good for you, but that doesn't mean the game is underrated, that just mean you guys are the niche it panders to.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS1: Love the interconnected levels, but only a few bosses were fun.
DS2: Bosses are lot better, but the entire experience feels disjointed, not connected. A lot of the areas are ugly or not interesting.
DS3: Beautiful art, great bosses, and very good level design.
Sekiro: Best combat system ever. Amazing boss fights. Beautiful levels, but much more "linear" than Dark Souls.
Elden Ring: wonderful level design, beautiful, great boss fights....

The problem with DS2: If you've got 100's of hours into DS3, Sekiro, and Elden Ring...for me, it's unplayable now.

snippet.textDisplay:
My take on the ending: The first sin is that Gwyn linked the fate of humanity to the first flame, which results in the undead curse manifesting in humans as the flame fades. Taking the throne means you become the 'monarch' of the next age, whether it's by linking the flame for an age of fire or keeping the fire from being linked, resulting in a dark age. In either cases, the curse still persists, and the cycle will continue when a new undead challenges you for the throne.
Aldia offers you a third option, to ignore the first flame altogether, and search for a way to break the curse and exist outside of the cycle. To take charge of your own fate, to become a true monarch.
snippet.textOriginal:

In either cases, the curse still persists, and the cycle will continue when a new undead challenges you for the throne.
Aldia offers you a third option, to ignore the first flame altogether, and search for a way to break the curse and exist outside of the cycle. To take charge of your own fate, to become a true monarch.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! It aways a joy to listen to defence of obviously enjoyable things, people hate for some reason. DS2 for me is last "true" Dark Souls, coz from the very beginning  this games was... survival horros. Like, srsl. Slow, deliberate movement. Kinda clunky.  Cowardness incentivized over heroism. Resourse management. Semi-open world with ALOT of deadly corners. And yes, restricted "saves". Not exactly like ink ribbon from RE, but close enouth to force you to sweat like a pig, after you make a 1.5h progress into deadly unknown. 
Demon Souls was pure survival horror mechanicaly.  There was no estus, you NEED resourses and you NEED to  preserve them. Sure you can farm, but noobs never know how, where, and probably want to leave most of areas behind coz it was hard. So, from my expierience it was constant balance of your items to progress. 
Dark Souls was much more "action oriented" but it was such a brilliant interconnected world with so many dangers, i nbever feel like estus was something out of place. Intence survival expierience, and then relief at bonfire... or lost of hours of your life sometimes. Extremely intence. 
DS2 for me in the middle of this two.have lots of items, not terribly open, but have some corners, character is not perfectly responcive, but you have some options to make your playthrough easier etc. So, like a non-action survive..ish game it was pretty balanced and cool. And also very pretty and sometimes stunning with it visual desighn (not visual quality, artistic endevours)
And then DS3 came. Playing the game I was never afraid to lost my progress, game feels EXTREMELEY polished and fair, and it all was very proactive, incentivized  movement and speed...... and i get very-very sad, coz i relized, after game like this they never would do something like first three. And i was right. 
So for me DS2 is a last mammoth of "thouse souls games" and i adore it :)
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi! It aways a joy to listen to defence of obviously enjoyable things, people hate for some reason. DS2 for me is last "true" Dark Souls, coz from the very beginning  this games was... survival horros. Like, srsl. Slow, deliberate movement. Kinda clunky.  Cowardness incentivized over heroism. Resourse management. Semi-open world with ALOT of deadly corners. And yes, restricted "saves". Not exactly like ink ribbon from RE, but close enouth to force you to sweat like a pig, after you make a 1.5h progress into deadly unknown. 
Demon Souls was pure survival horror mechanicaly.  There was no estus, you NEED resourses and you NEED to  preserve them. Sure you can farm, but noobs never know how, where, and probably want to leave most of areas behind coz it was hard. So, from my expierience it was constant balance of your items to progress. 
Dark Souls was much more "action oriented" but it was such a brilliant interconnected world with so many dangers, i nbever feel like estus was something out of place. Intence survival expierience, and then relief at bonfire... or lost of hours of your life sometimes. Extremely intence. 
DS2 for me in the middle of this two.have lots of items, not terribly open, but have some corners, character is not perfectly responcive, but you have some options to make your playthrough easier etc. So, like a non-action survive..ish game it was pretty balanced and cool. And also very pretty and sometimes stunning with it visual desighn (not visual quality, artistic endevours)
And then DS3 came. Playing the game I was never afraid to lost my progress, game feels EXTREMELEY polished and fair, and it all was very proactive, incentivized  movement and speed...... and i get very-very sad, coz i relized, after game like this they never would do something like first three. And i was right. 
So for me DS2 is a last mammoth of "thouse souls games" and i adore it :)

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 will always have a special place in my heart, it was actually the second Dark Souls game I ever played and is the only Souls game I have ever gone into New Game Plus 8 on. The build variety and the combat alone make this game a blast to play and that doesn't even mention the fact this game is actually really fun to speedrun and do challenge runs.

I have beaten this game 18 times and just started another playthrough to see how fast I can actually Beat It wow incorporating all the knowledge and glitches I have gained over the years.

Bloodborne and Dark Souls 2 will forever be the best in the franchise and for me personally my least favorite would have to be held in ring because I still think the souls formula should never have gone open world, it's a fun game to complete your first time but I think after your first time completing it Elden ring loses a lot of its luster just because of its size. But that's my opinion, My Last Hope is they finally remaster Dark Souls 2 like they did to Demon's Souls. Guarantee it will become one of the most popular ones.

snippet.textDisplay:
The "why dark souls 2 sucks" videos actually inspired me to play Dark Souls 2 again.

There are some characteristics in Dark Souls 2 that people hate:

> You have to approach areas methodically
- usually eliminating enemies one at the time, agro one enemy using a bow or a spell, or simply walk close enough to agro one enemy. Some people would only use a broad sword and charge-in and panic roll and do badly, or rush to the fog wall and get hit while touching it.
- there are also lots of ambushes in ds2, which further infuriates people who "just go in and be rolling".
- enemies can also chase you really fast and at long distances, so you need to eliminate them.

>  You need to have a good build:
- With stamina recovering slower here as well as estus drinking, plus poor rolling due to low adaptability, you are punished more if you don't have a good build. 

> You need have a long range option:
- You are expected to use the bow and arrow or spells to eliminate long range enemies. Not doing so will make areas like Iron Keep and Shrine of Amana torture to play. You can imagine how this will infuriate people who just won't use a bow.


Certainly, not approaching methodically and not using long range, will make the game look like it was trying to be hard just to be hard.
The early area, Forest of Fallen Giants, actually teach you to be methodical. The Mossy Rotunda area has multiple hollow infantry playing dead and a long range enemy. You will really hate this game if you barge in this area like you're playing Devil May Cry.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am happy to know that Dark Souls 2 has it's devoted fans for sure. I even agree with many of it's defenders' points. However I myself am not a fan of the game overall and do think it's the worst in the series. But it has it's moments:
I love Majula, it's beautiful cozy and a well-designed hub area
DS2 has a handful of areas that are aesthetically gorgeous like Dragon Shrine and Frozen EleumLoyce
Some of the bosses are great, my personal favorite being the Burnt Ivory King
Armor sets and weapons are fantastic visually and so are many enemies
Music has some highlights as well. The end credits song in particular is wonderful

But the thing I NEVER hear addressed in these DS2 defense videos is the core of all my and most of the souls community's dislike of this game: the core gameplay. The movement and swordplay is NOT GOOD. It's floaty and imprecise. The hitboxes are absurdly wonky. Lock-on often doesn't work and you swing where you don't want to. Input lag + VERY slow animations like healing make the whole game feel sluggish. Compared to not just it's descendants but even it's predecessor, DS2 is miserably worse to play. Even if all the areas and bosses were fantastically well-designed, it would still be my and most peoples least favorite because the core-movement and combat feels so much worse than the others.

Problem is, the rest of the game ISN'T all fantastically well-designed. Areas like the Black Gultch and Shrine of Amana, and bosses like the Gank Squad or Blue Smelter Demon all suck. Enemy spamming is a common theme of the game and NO its not because of bad players failing to crowd control. It's very obviously designed in a way that you are constantly ambushed by legions of poise-breaking enemies. Iron Keep is prime example. I'll always see Dark Souls 2 as one of the most inconsistent games ever made. 25% of it is amazing, 50% of it forgettable, and 25% of it terrible... all while being frustrating to play through because of the core-movement and combat.

I appreciate your video and your opinion, no hate towards you at all. And you are skilled at video editing and writing.

snippet.textDisplay: This video is describing the quality of the game, which obviously matters and still has different opinions. Bit to be honest, i think a lot of peoplw overlook the most simple and basic aspect of games where you control a character in a 3d space: the controls. They first thing you can do after starting DS2 (other than seeing the cutscene and where you spawn) is how you move. The weird, spread out controls that are unlike a lot of games we are used to throw us off immediately and makes the process of relearning controls not fun, usually resulting in giving up the game before being fluent in how to move and attack. (this is about PC controls. I just got to borrow and XBOX controller recently, but that doesnt help because i have the same problem: learn new controls. I didn't grow up with any consoles (or even PCs and phones but those are easy to learn) so figuring it out was annoying. Ill still keep trying though. Stick drift is gross.)

snippet.textDisplay:
it's not controversial to say it's a good game... What's controversial is to suggest that it stands anywhere near the rest of the series. Just because we like something a lot, doesnt make it objectively better than it actually is, or good at all... I like resident evil 6, and that game doesnt get the hate it deserves, it is THAT BAD... I still like it, but i would never say the game is underrated... Because just like Dark Souls 2, it isnt underrated.

Fat ppl be saying "Big Macs underrated", murderers be saying "killing innocents underrated", filthy ppl saying "bitting your nails off underrated"... No, just because we like something that others dont, doesnt make it underrated. Dark Souls 2 is the worst of the series by a colossal margin, not even close to Dark Souls 3 or Demon's Souls, which are considered "weaker", and they may very well be compared to Dark Souls 1, Bloodborne or Elden Ring... But they are still martepieces compared to Dark Souls 2... Demon's Souls is in fact a masterpiece and UNDERRATED (the original not the remake) but not enough ppl got to play it to even have an opinion on it, while dark souls 3 is very techinally sound, but doesnt do that much new, which makes it a "NOT MASTERPIECE", or underrated XD.

snippet.textDisplay: I want to defend Dark Souls II enemy placement and tracking. Dark Souls II is a game that is wonderful at teaching you focus and patience. If you fail an area you have to do it again from the top and kill the things, just running through is hard. When I played it, I thought this was intentional and genius, and is one of the aspects that kept me coming back, the "breathe, don't rush, do it again better this time", clean the area, attempt the dragon. The area is the challenge, not just the dragon. I love Elden Ring but I hate the fact that you can pretty much ignore 99.9% of the enemies and bosses with no punishment.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm very conflicted with the game.
 
The worst part for me is the fact that there are way too many enemies in areas especially on the way to a boss. 
This paired with the fact that you can get hit out of fog animations (or chest opening etc) is simply a bad design choice. No other game did this as well. 

Whacky animations and other problems you mentioned don't help either. 

The game is beautiful (especially at the time) and the story is nice but that was never the main point for me and a lot of others i guess.

Most people value the gameplay the other souls games offer. And if that feels all wrong then it becomes hard to just "embrace" it or deal with it. 

Also horsefuck valley. There is no need to explain that one. I love snowy areas in games but this one is my exception.

snippet.textDisplay:
I disagree with the gankyness of DS2. With how I observe people playing Souls games, they play like they just hit a line. 

DS2 punishes the player for running around everywhere. And it actually does the OPPOSITE of what you said. It SHOULD teach the players to slow down and learn aggro. I've quite literally never been ganked as hard as people keep showing in DS2. Maybe at most 3 weak enemies. The worst being in  Iron keep when you first enter the area with the collapsible bridge. You Need to know where the aggro triggers are and when to really cut loose. For example, almost all the Iron keep tall boy enemies sprint up to you then stop for a moment before attacking. This gives the player a lot of time to Kill the one in front before the other one comes running in from the outfield.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 is my favorite Dark Souls game, always has been. DS3 comes in second, followed by DS1 (very good, but still figuring things out) and Demon's Souls. (Very clearly a prototype for the series.) Elden Ring is about on par with DS2, I'd say, although it's hard to fairly compare the two. Anyway,  the main reasons would be that A) I really liked the more Arthurian themes of DS2, and: B) it's just more hopeful than the other parts of the series.

Unlike Dark Souls one and three, which are _all_ about how the world is ending and you should really be feeling that existential dread, Dark Souls 2 gives the impression that it's not all bad. Nature endures. The world keeps on existing. People make do. There's still some beauty in the world. It's the only game in the series where the NPCs don't all go insane and/or die, rather you end up collecting this weird little village of survivors who somehow manage despite it all. There's this sense that once you look beyond the folly of mortal pride, thing are probably going to be okay in the end. That's what kept me going. 

(Also, Majula is 100% the best hub world and I will fight you IRL if you disagree.)

snippet.textDisplay:
You know, it's not as bad as some people think, but it's not as good as some of this recent revisionism seems to be, and by coincidence I've replayed it literally last week.
Some of the areas and boss runs are straight up evil. (Looking at you, Iron Keep Smelter Run). Like a stupid amout is either a weirdly hard run through or a tedious bow adventure.
Most of the bosses are fine, but a lot of the DLC difficulty comes from just big damage big resistance. It's not good when one-handed Craftsman Hammer does comparable damage per swing to highstest damaging spells in Crown of the Old Iron King.
Adaptability/Agility was a bad idea. It should be like the other games, where you invincibility is tied to the animation, but in DS2 you can have a drastically different dodge with the same animation based off another weird stat.
The level of polish is worse overall. There are a lot of enemy placements that are just MMO areas, as well as other small details. My "favourite" recent example is that if you do a spear attack while blocking, your targeting is really bad. Unless the terrain is super specific you just cannot hit a crystal lizard with your spear. In DS1 the blocking attack had such good targeting it was useful for snipin things like Blighttown mosquitoes and such. 
Dark Souls 2 is not a bad game. But it's definitely the least of the 3 in many aspects.
Also, do remember than when you see someone critiquing the game, there's a high chanse someone is talking many years ago about something that was changed twise over, like the Dragon Shrine or Shrine of Amana which use to be just the worst on the original release

snippet.textDisplay: I completed dark souls 2 and the DLCs around 3 days ago and i do have to say i really enjoyed myself in the end. 2 things i hated were how many enemies there were and the loss of your health when you die it also felt like the devs hated the player and wanted to put as many inconveniences into the game as possible without making it unplayable lol. For me the bosses were fun but not very interesting or particularly challenging compared to bosses from other games however with that being said, it was so much fun once i got used to the mechanics and got invested in the story/lore. I had the same feeling of wanting to continue playing like i had with DS1 and Elden Ring (the other fromsoftware games i completed). I didn't think id enjoy it especially after hearing so many people tell me to skip it and go straight to dark souls 3 and my first impressions weren't the best either.

snippet.textDisplay:
32 ADP? my brother, my first character (currently on my second playthrough for whatever that info is worth) had 46 by the time I felt like it was pointless to go any further, still got slapped around in PvP but the PvE stuff felt the same as any other soulsborne game, I understand the annoyance surrounding ADP, having I-frames be tied to stat especially when this game launched must have been horrific although I do think the hate towards ADP is a bit overblown at this point, especially given how many souls the game throws at you.
is it kind of annoying? yeah, sure is but I never found it to be the deal breaker it is often made out as being.

as for lifegems I think this video is the first time I have ever heard someone bringing up the fact you can buy as many lesser lifegems as you want as a negative, I think they'd be a lot more of a barrier to enjoyment if they were harder to come by especially early game, where your sippy breaks take like 7 seconds and often require baiting out specific attacks in a boss fight to be able to heal safely.
I personally found it incredibly easy to accept this games flaws and to push through to the more enjoyable parts but I did see how someone could try the game for an hour or two and swear off of it from that point forward, it isn't for everyone who liked DS1, and it certainly isn't for everyone that likes DS3 and ER.

snippet.textDisplay:
4:57
So, I've never played the original version of DS2, but I've recently played through Scholar. I've never really felt like the game encouraged me to run past enemies or anything like that, if anything, I feel like the game encouraged me to take each encounter one at a time, and intentionally fight each enemy, rather than ignoring them like you could in DS1 or DS3. I found that just by running through a zone, you would just end up pulling the whole area and die. You actually showed a clip of this happening earlier, too, at 4:30. This scenario would have never happened had you not just killed each enemy one by one approaching this part of Heide's Tower of Flame. I'm not really sure what your point is here, because it seems like you're simultaneously wanting to be able to run through a zone, but you're also lamenting that you can't do that in Scholar? I'm a bit confused.

15:20
I'm actually gonna jump in again with some more thoughts on this, it is my firm belief after having played the entire trilogy + elden ring to completion multiple times that Dark Souls has ALWAYS been turn-based combat. You are not going to stagger a boss out of every hit. You can't always have your turn. You have a certain window of time between a boss's attack patterns in each game to take actions. This isn't any different with DS3 or Elden Ring. Do you swing your sword? Do you drink Estus? Do you use a spell? A consumable? These are choices that have ALWAYS been present in the Souls series, and are not a problem with DS2, but rather, a problem with the series as a whole. Boss fights are not interactive in any Souls game. Framing this as a DS2 issue is not accurate.

Ultimately I do agree with you, DS2 is my favourite DS game. The experience is good, and there are certainly negatives, as with any other game. Good video 👍

snippet.textDisplay:
I finished and experienced the game for the 1st time around a week ago and I can definitely say I am so happy I played it. I wouldn't say the game is underrated but it's definitely overhated. The lows of the game are worst of the series (which in reality are just like 4 or 5 really annoying walkbacks) but apart from that the game was very enjoyable for most part.  The ADP argument I find kind of pointless considering the fact I was over level 200 at the end of the game which makes it possible for me to reach soft caps for most stats. The length of the game was jaw dropping for me too with wopping 43 hours at the end of my 1st playthrough. Bosses like Sir Alonne, Fume knight, Burn ivory king were peak bosses this game had to offer for me.

My TLDR: Game is overhated and deserves more love.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm playing DS2 now for the first time, currently doing the DLC before finishing the main game. I'm really enjoying it. I'm doing a fully offensive strength build for the first time, which I have learned is very difficult. But it's so fun and I love uncovering the story as I go. At least, what I think the story is.

My main complaint is the hollowing mechanic. I get being barred from doing certain things when hollow, but constantly chipping away at your health just feels like being punished for trying and not already being good. Glad it wasn't in Bloodborne or Elden Ring. And it would be nice if the stats had a description explaining what they do like in Elden Ring.

But other than that, really loving the game. It's beautiful, moving, and every victory feels earned.

snippet.textDisplay:
When I played the souls games for the first time, I knew almost nothing about them, including the general opinion on which game was better or worse, when I finally finished playing them and decided to take a dive in the community, I was honestly shocked with the hate Dark Souls 2 gets, since it was by far my favourite in the series, I loved the fantastical and colorful areas, the sheer variety of weapons, armors and bosses, the mystery and suspense of the story, and of course, majula is my favourite hub of any game.

I could see it's flaws very clearly, but it didn't matter to me, the game was still a blast, and I still play it to this day, it's the most fun souls game to replay for sure. 

Great video, always happy to find other people who also love Dark Souls 2!

I could see it's flaws very clearly, but it didn't matter to me, the game was still a blast, and I still play it to this day, it's the most fun souls game to replay for sure. 

Great video, always happy to find other people who also love Dark Souls 2!

snippet.textDisplay:
It's rightfully underrated :)

It was an art to balance your game between very hard and beated by improvement.
Dark Souls 2 threw this idea in the bin and ignored the rightful dev's lessons.

Now it's just a hard game. And not beated by pure skill per se.
(also there are plenty of "cheesy" ways to become stronger loadout wise not skill wise, further ignoring the original goal.)

snippet.textDisplay: Nah, my opinion of Dark Souls 2 is pretty pure.  Do you know why?  This game introduced me to its series, it was my first, I simply had nothing to compare it to, I just didn’t see all these problems of yours with “it’s good here and here it’s worse than it was before.”  I just enjoyed the game, I didn’t see any flaws in it, I was fascinated by it, and it will always be so (if you don’t like something, that’s okay, but don’t shout about it at every corner!).  So yeah, I don't "like" this game, I "love" it.  I love DS2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I really liked this game when it was the only way to get more Dark souls. However these days I put it at the bottom of the list of the franchise

Partly just because the other things that have come out have just been more enjoyable for me, but the other part is because I really don't like scholar of the first sin and that's now the only way to play that on modern systems. I really think the changes just doubled down on a lot of the gank squad ambushes Just for the sake of making the game hard, but that just to me makes it frustratingly unfair

The vanilla version I did really still enjoy though. And even if it's at the bottom of the list, it's at the bottom of a list of amazing games. So it's not bad by any means

Part of what I'm not a huge fan of it's just kind of the atmosphere in art direction of that particular game. To me it feels like a more generic Western fantasy setting that just happens to have Dark souls combat

But it's leagues better than just about any Dark souls clone

snippet.textDisplay: Would love to know how many people are still playing this game today. Relative to Dark Souls 1 and 3. I’m one of those that feel 2 is awful compared to the other games. The way the character moves, animates and overall combat feels unpolished. Dark Souls 2 feels like a third party title that was just allowed to use the franchise name and could not replicate the same experience as the others. Haven’t touched the game since I beaten it years ago. In contrast I still play Demons Souls, DS1 and DS3.

snippet.textDisplay: It is way better than Dark Souls III for sure. I like II almost as much as the first one. III feels like it was made to specifically please haters of II. It doesn't even bother having a unique vibe of its own and just goes for massive DS1 fan service. And its garbage combat design feels like it was made for people who, during DS1 era, were all like "armors should be just for fashion and if you don't play entire game rolling around with light load you are just noob who needs to git gud". Elden Ring was only a slight improvement to DS III combat because at least shields weren't useless garbage but it was still mostly same crap. Therefore first two Dark Souls games will remain special to me while III and ER I consider to be forgettable.

snippet.textDisplay: Well.  The large numbers of videos about Dark Souls 2 are prefaced with "In defense of".  Which means that in fact, liking Dark Souls 2 is the outlier.  And personal biases aside, this game's history is one of development hell, engine problem and last minute director switch.  I also liked Dark Souls 2, in fact a lot more than 3 which is still objectively a better game that I just didnt vibe with.  But if DS2 has that feeling of cobbled together nonsensical mess, it's just because that's exactly what happened to make this game even playable and ready for release with good hearty "Good Enough" stamp.  It's not even my least fav fromsoft game, but objectively, it's all around an far inferior product than any of their modern games.  So saying it's underrated?  Heh.  No.  If anything I think we are way too forgiving towards it because it was nothing more than a Bandai Namco comitee driven ordered cash grab.  Do I still like it?  Yes but for me it's more comparable in quality to a Lords of the Fallen 1 than the usual Fromsoft game.  And whoever designed SotFS should burn in hell for eternity because vanilla is the superior version.  SotFS feels like an amateur fan mod with someone going trigger happy on the copy/paste of mobs.  Also frigid outskirt.  What the actual fuck.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 is my favorite FromSoft game. I think it's even better than Elden Ring. It has some serious flaws, but it does so many small things right that it comes out on top in the end. I think it's even more replayable than DS3 due to how many different routes you can take for optimizing your build, while DS3 is probably the most linear Souls game not counting Sekiro.

I recently did a SL1 playthrough, and it's ridiculous how many options you have. You can go with a Dex or a Str build, even using items like the Great Club despite starting with 6 Str due to all the stat modifiers you can get. The fact you can have such a huge variety despite being lv 1 is just a microcosm of how much variety you have on a normal playthrough. I'd easily say it has the most variety of viable playstyles out of any Souls game. Even Elden Ring gets extremely restrictive by the endgame (god forbid NG+7 and its huge stat increases) in terms of how many weapons and spells are basically unusable.

snippet.textDisplay:
Things that makes DS2 unenjoyable (for me)

-The annoying mouse lag bug on PC. You can remove it easily by turning on and off the double click detection option. EVERY TIME you launch the game. Because for some reason, the option is not saved EVER. Everytime you launch the game that option is on (even if the menu says it's off, it's in fact on)

-Bonfire ascetic. Look, I'm not a pro, I need to level up during my gameplay. If you make enemies stop spawning after they are killed a couple of times times I won't be able to progress... I NEED TO LEVEL UP

-"Unavoidable" traps. Dark Souls has traps, but if you observe the environment you can easily spot them, The game rewards perceptive players, that's cool. The only way to avoid traps in DS II is knowing beforehand where the traps are, it sucks

-Too many enemies. It sucks entering a room and being surrounded by 5 or 6 enemies that inmediately aggro you. Dark Souls is not Devil May Cry. Specially, as you say, you cannot cancel animations. It suck even more when you are in narrow spaces and your attacks hit the wall

DS2 is a miserable experience for me

snippet.textDisplay:
Over the years I have grown away from Dark Souls 2, it's not my favourite in the series anymore I think that goes to Dark Souls 3 now at least until we see Elden Ring DLC but not long ago Dark Souls 2 was my personal favourite and is still my most played of the series. I had a silly amount of play time on the Xbox 360 version of the game before SotFS and then some more when that came out and I swapped to Xbox One.

I really enjoyed the unique changes and creative systems the game had for combat and ng+. The world felt way more alive and reactive to the player. Dark Souls 1 had the best world design but Dark Souls 2 had the best world feel. Dark Souls 3 was probably the best game experience in terms of how things felt and played, like Elden Ring is was smooth and easy to pick up. 

If they ever make a Dark Souls 4 or Elden Ring 2 I would like to see them bring some of Dark Souls 2's best features into those games. The unique stances, powerstancing system, NG+ and Bonfire Ascetics and more use for certain items like the torch, pharos lockstones and such. Really enjoyed that air of mystery when first exploring an area and seeing all these locked doors, examine options, torches I could light up to change how the area looked and felt. I really enjoyed those aspects. Also it was the first souls game where we could fight the same boss multiple times in a single playthrough meaning you could get every weapon. 

Truly a unique game that sadly some people in the community didn't enjoy. I honestly think it was just released at the wrong time because look at how many Soulslike games are releasing these days and people eat them up. Dark Souls 2 suffered from the Sequel effect I think. Didn't live up to the hype people created and the nostalgia around Dark Souls 1. If it released as spiritual entry into the Kings Field series literally being titled "King's Field" I could see it being a much bigger success. It shares a lot with those games and the theme of kings and the dlc crowns really works into the idea of the title. Even Majula being a field rather then a small hub/shrine makes sense. 

Literally just being called Dark Souls 2 was enough for some people to dislike the game sadly.

snippet.textDisplay: I also noticed that DS2 screws you over less than DS1.  I had countless issues with NPCs, whether it was NPCs not showing up, not following the correct order, or answering an NPC question wrong.  I got screwed out of getting pyro flame past +15 bc I killed a certain boss and that NPC wouldn’t appear.  That’s only one example , I ran into countless road blocks along the way.  Never had this issue in DS2, I like the regen health stones, weapon/armor variety, and DLC was stellar. Idk how but DS1 took me longer and I had a harder time. I still love all of them but DS2 was excellent.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s really dumb to get mad that people don’t like this game. If you appreciate why people don’t like it then the emotion really shouldn’t be there. It’s a lot more reasonable to recognize that these people intended to enjoy ds2, and were in fact frustrated by not being able to fulfill their intentions. And if you consider that entitlement then you are a child. I think this video is great but I see that sentiment everywhere and frankly THAT frustrates me.

I hated ds2 so much, I was disgusted just reaching majula. 
But I gave it another chance, discovered that you could dual wield and I was so happy I enjoy the game til the very last boss, doing all optionnal bosses and got 100% achievement and I loved it so much! 
Now that it's done I feel empty again... until eldeng ring dlc comes out.... 
I went from Demon Souls Remake to Elden ring (BB not yet but soon) and I cannot chose my favorite one! They all have something I love! 
So If you read this and you are just like I was until recently, hating on ds2 but haven't really played it, give it another try, it's really fun, just pour everything in ADP until you have 25-30 early, then think about getting it to 40 midgame and never touch it again.

What I hated the most in ds2: god damn petrified motherfucker blocking my way!! Pharros Lockstone for illusionary wall and the game dumping 4-5 ennemies thinking "yeah this is difficulty" when you can litteraly just walk around most ennemies to avoid taking any hit.

snippet.textDisplay: I've played dark souls 2 so many times I even got the Platinum(all achievements) I've completed it with sword and shield and also magic. The only thing I love about it is how many secrets, Items and things you can do, NG+ and story but that's it. I hate the movement, adp and slow health regeneration. Boring, annoying and unmemorable areas with no aesthetics. Mostly boring and annoying bosses and enemies. And my most hated thing is the bullshit hits I can't even count how many times it happened to me one time I got back stabbed in the face and my character rotated to do the animation. It's the second most souls game I've played, bloodborne is first. I've completed all fromsoftware souls games sekiro was the hardest for me but DS2 is the most annoying and my least favourite if you want to play it you can but your experience will be good then some bullshit happens that makes you stop playing until you feel playing again

snippet.textDisplay: It's not underrated at all. It's overhated, and for good reasons tbh. I've beaten this game about 15 times so I actually like it, but the hate is deserved. snippet.textDisplay:
Actually replayed. 
Is the most terrible souls, but if conpared to other soulslike, the best.
Have serious problems in rpg mechanichs, like how physical defense is completely useless since the formula is broken, and defenses in ng+ are useless then (while elemental ones are %, thus effective).
Enemies tracking is utterly ridicolous while player tracking is almost non existent.
The great stamina consumption while rolling is a great thing, but attacks stamina consumpation is really too much and makes dual wield very useless.
Is just a good game but full of flaws. Ironically, it has the best pvp, or would have, if it was not for soul memory and the pyromancy Warmth (which totallybdestroys 1vs1 making them last indefinitely).

snippet.textDisplay:
Very few people actually hate this game. It has stellar reviews and most Souls fan enjoy it as a good game. You have to separate the fact that a bad/flawed Souls game, or a a sequel in general, doesn't make for a bad game.

As a follow up to Dark Souls and as an entry in part of a franchise, there are lot more issues with Dark Souls 2 than if you viewed it in complete isolation. As a sequel, I think there's very little in Dark Souls 2 that it takes from its predecessor, refines, and then improves on.

They just took a whole bunch of new ideas and put them in. Some of them were good, but a lot were bad or made the game worse compared to its predecessor. Also, the worldbuilding and lore general. It's not bad, but it's a far cry from Dark Souls. Dark Souls 2 just does not ooze atmosphere. Besides the weird map, almost nothing about it feels cohesive. It just in general feels much gamier than Dark Souls.

It's still a great game and all reviews and the general opinion of the fanbase reflect that. One has to be the worst in the series and DS2 is the most unique and has plenty to pick on when viewed as one entry in a franchise. Being 3rd place out three doesn't mean it's objectively bad and I can't see how you can say a game is underrated when it is lauded both critically and by the fanbase as a good game.
