As a follow up to Dark Souls and as an entry in part of a franchise, there are lot more issues with Dark Souls 2 than if you viewed it in complete isolation. As a sequel, I think there's very little in Dark Souls 2 that it takes from its predecessor, refines, and then improves on.

They just took a whole bunch of new ideas and put them in. Some of them were good, but a lot were bad or made the game worse compared to its predecessor. Also, the worldbuilding and lore general. It's not bad, but it's a far cry from Dark Souls. Dark Souls 2 just does not ooze atmosphere. Besides the weird map, almost nothing about it feels cohesive. It just in general feels much gamier than Dark Souls.

It's still a great game and all reviews and the general opinion of the fanbase reflect that. One has to be the worst in the series and DS2 is the most unique and has plenty to pick on when viewed as one entry in a franchise. Being 3rd place out three doesn't mean it's objectively bad and I can't see how you can say a game is underrated when it is lauded both critically and by the fanbase as a good game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Also i think ds2 is a good game. Its by no means bad. The problem is that 1 and 3 are masterpieces imo. And its justifiable to compare since it carries the same title. 
However just because it doesnt live up to be a masterpiece doesnt mean its not a good game worth playing. 
But holding devs to high standards is a good thing. Ds3 might not have been so fking good if people didnt "hate" on ds2. And you see nowadays the state games release in.
My point is, we should hold devs accountable for releasing sub par games, it will only increase the quality of games in the future, for everyone. So "hate" when you gotta "hate".

snippet.textDisplay:
The main problem with ds2 imo it that it feels clunky and weird to play. Its not as crispy clean as 1 and 3. 
Also the sounds are weird, even when you hit someone with the sword, you get the feeling you hit a stone or something. 
The character also controls pretty bad. In a way ds2 feels outdated compared to ds1 in mechanics.
Another turn off for me was the pacing. It felt for me like and eternity yo get out of majula and do anything interesting. The first area was pretty bland and uninspired. Never got that feeling with 1 and 3 that was addictive from the get go.

snippet.textDisplay: Dark Souls 2 is not just underrated. It is being constantly being shit upon because of the flaws of a difficult development cycle. And not in a Lost Izalith kind of way, where you can pretend it doesn't exist. The problems with this game are so deep that the Souls community has decided to make a joke out of it to "protect" the rest of From Software games from the criticism associated with this particular enty. And it is a pity, because this game had some interesting ideas.

snippet.textDisplay: I think you focused a lot on the looks and story, but the real reason why people dont like DS2 is because the gameplay kinda sucks. Enemy placement is jonky, which you did mention somewhat, but having to fight 5+ enemies at once every other fight in a souls game just doesnt feel right. This isnt dynasty warrior, the character also feels more clunky and unresponsive. Also the game world feels disjointed, yes it looks nice but it doesnt feel nice because it feels like demon souls where one area is completely disjointed from the other. Overall the polish of the game feels subpar, but i do agree on the vistas and the areas looking cool, I especially enjoy the dragon area near the end.

snippet.textDisplay: The development of this game was a train wreck. They spent a lot of time on a new engine that wouldn't run well for many areas of the game so they had to change it. They started with two directors and ended with one. They basically created a ton of cool areas and monsters and had to stitch everything together. I love DS2 it's not my favorite but it took risks and I feel it deserves praise for that. Also the amount of cut content is insane. Shalquoir had so many things she was going to tell you about lore and everything from what I remember the ring of whispers was supposed to let you talk to her and she would be sort of a lore well or info dump haha.

snippet.textDisplay: I have always enjoyed DS2, and felt like it is my personal favorite of the soulsborne games, with the best of the currently released DLC, (still waiting on the supposed Elden Ring DLC). I absolutely loved the kind of hopeless and times long past feelings that the game portrays through it's soundtrack and world design. You have a level that is a castle being reclaimed and sinking into the sea because it's been there for so long. A forest and castle filled with the remnants of a long forgotten war that left them scared and in disrepair. Sure there were things I didn't care for in it, but I definitely feel like the pros outweigh the cons of this game. And if you never played it because you heard it was bad, that is your loss.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS1: the cycle begins, you come into a world at the end of its first repeat, and you must do something because the gods who kept it propped up are gone. DS2: cycles have been happening and will continue to happen so many times in the same place that the ruins of kingdoms past are starting to pile up. DS3: The cycle has perpetuated so long that the world is turning to ash, all the people who's duty it was to restart the cycle said enough if enough.

    I think DS2 fits perfectly right where it is, the story leads you through kingdoms who arose and fell, showing that the fall is inevitable.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 SOTFS is in my top 5 best video games of all time list, and I've been gaming for 40+ years. 

I never understood the hate for this game.  It's my fav in the trilogy.
It always seems to boil down to a lack of understanding of how ADP works, and/or 'sequel syndrome'.  Sequel syndrome is when a sequel to a hit game is disliked simply because it's not exactly the same as the first game, ie Majora's Mask.

snippet.textDisplay: I love DS2.  I'm currently playing thru Scholar. The hitbox issue isn't as random as DS1, to my mind. And there's hardly any frame rate issues, which was a big glitch in the original. Beauty shots really help this game as does the fairy tale music in Majula. This may sound odd but DS2 is more player friendly despite the difficulty of the game and I can even forgive the egregious over reaches, such as the gargoyle rematch. Voice acting is better, the sheer variety of item drops is better. Adaptability is garbage, no helping that. NPC dialogue scripting is still atrocious. I mean, it's better than Skyrim........................ sort of. I prefer the simpler weapon upgrade tree here, as well; it's not anywhere near as cryptic as DS1. There are late game locations that seem thrown in for the sake of prolonging the game rather than really ramping up the tension and difficulty, as on my very first play I felt very OP by late game, not just at the moment of the final boss. You never felt safe in DS1 but there is definitely a comfort zone in DS2. Maybe Scholar fixes that, but I haven't gotten to that point. It's neck and neck for me which one I like better, with DS3 a far, far distant 3rd place.

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually disagree with you on some of the story stuff; I don't think it's weak when held up to the other games.

I think it surpasses them.

So preface, I've only *finished* SOTFS, and it does make a couple of changes to the story. I also 100% agree with you that DS2 is "detached" from the other games; DS3 is a direct sequel to DS1, DS2 feels like more of a spinoff set in the same world. But despite that... as much as I love the first game, and the lore of it, my connection to the story just absolutely pales in comparison to DS2.

I think this is for two major reasons; the first being, your character in DS2 feels like the most independent character in... well, any Souls-Like, really. In all the other ones you're some "mystical undead / tarnished / whatever fated to be the one that saves the world, but actually you're just a puppet being strung along by gods or great old ones or whatever else. In DS2, you're not some prophecised being, you're a dude with a curse that wants to get rid of that curse. Everything you do and achieve in the game is YOUR work. Sure, you're still getting strung along by other beings. For a while. Until you start realising what's going on, because...

Reason 2; out of every Souls-Like game so far, the story of DS2 is the most comprehensible for a normal person playing the game. Again this is where SOTFS comes in because I understand Aldia is... different, or not even present in the original? But the dialogue he has along with item descriptions and the cut scenes, DS2 is the only game in the series where I got a pretty good idea of what was going on and what the main crux of the story was about without needing a vaatividya video to explain everything for me.

And because of this, the game felt so much more personal. My character isn't some stalwart knight marching towards one of two endings that are in reality identical. They're an actual person with thoughts and ideas and beliefs. I like my DS1 and 3 characters, but I could roleplay my DS2 character in a D&D game and they'd actually be *fun*. And the concepts it brings to the series which are integral to the series' overall narrative; how the world is in an endless cycle where essentially the same things happen over and over, and there's this stupid, pointless battle between light and dark, where every how knows how many millenia we go from an age of light to an age of dark and everyone thinks they're doing something big but in reality it's pointless... That's like a core part of Dark Souls lore and it was like entirely created by Dark Souls 2. 

AND, it's the only game where it feels like, hey, *maybe* you're choices did actually matter, maybe you *will* find a different path. Like even the "best" ending in DS3 just kinda makes it feel like, nah, it's just all going to start over again.

Honestly, while I like DS3's story and it's a nice wrap-up to the series, it's almost insulting how much it ignores the existence of Dark Souls 2. It doesn't need to continue that story or wrap it up; I'm fine with 2 being its own thing, but at least *some* acknowledgement of the events of the game would have been nice.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is absolutely nothing wrong with loving a game, even if it's bad. I certainly have bad games that I love.

There are certainly elements of DS 2 that are fantastic, but the issue is that the complete package is ultimately just a cheap imitation of DS 1 that plays more like a fan game, which is pretty much exactly what it is anyway being that it was not made by the same people.

Really, at the end of the day, it's not that people are just hating on DS 2. It's more that we know that we could have had something much better. We could've had a proper sequel to DS 1 that improved upon it in every way instead of falling short in every way.

snippet.textDisplay:
Liking Dark Souls II over any, and especially all, of the other Souls/"Soulsborne" titles feels like coming out of the closet to fire-and-brimstone conservative parents lol. Like as soon as you say Dark Souls II is your favorite in the series there are people who react as if you had praised Osama bin Laden or Jeffrey Dahmer.

Personally, Dark Souls II is *not* my favorite of FromSoft's "Soulsborne"-style games, and it's not even my favorite in the Dark Souls series itself. (I prefer Dark Souls III.) But I do feel like there are a number of aspects of DSII that make it stand out in a big way from the others. It contains narrative and gameplay elements that I felt were outstanding, especially in SotFS.

Then again, to me, each and every "Soulsborne" game is a huge achievement in its own way. Demon's Souls (PS3), Dark Souls (I), Dark Souls II, DSII: SotFS, Bloodborne, Dark Souls III, Sekiro, Elden Ring, and the Demon's Souls remake (PS5) are all masterpieces, but in different, and sometimes very different, ways, in my opinion.

It's like enjoying a variety of different types of food: just because one dish (say, a really good bowl of ramen) is outstanding, that doesn't imply that it's somehow "more outstanding" than, say, really quality filet mignon. You can enjoy one just as much as the other, but you can enjoy them just as much *for different reasons*.

snippet.textDisplay: I watched a bunch of his videos of people saying that this game is actually good. I decided to get the game and play the base version and I got all the DLC’s for it and I was excited to play. I thought that the bad reviews were just overreactions but this game is a pain to play. I was trying to force myself to like this game but I can’t it’s just bad. The story and the bosses are like the only good thing when I played dark souls one every time I beat a boss I feel accomplished, but one and I was playing darksouls 2 I just wanted to beat the boss to get it over with I swear every run back is like a minute long some being more and some have unavoidable enemies, I also don’t like how they split my stamina bar and my carry weight into two different stats. I also don’t like that I have to upgrade a stat just to get more invincibility frames I had to do in Darksouls one was level up one stat and that was that but besides that most of the areas just feel like gank fests I can’t Edmeyer the locations because I’m dealing with like 12 different enemies at once and I plus playing on the base version not scholar of the first sin. the normal vanilla version is supposedly a good game but it’s not. Playing for the game has already been a shit experience. I can’t imagine what playing through scholar of the first sin would be like

snippet.textDisplay: I think right off the bat one of my biggest complaints with DS2 is that I'm just not a NG+ kind of player. I genuinely truly try to get as much content in a single playthrough as possible, even if it means after coming through every corner of an area myself unaided, before leaving what I think is the end of said area looking up a guide online just to make sure I didn't miss anything. I'll *revisit* a game later with a totally different character concept or idea once I've completely finished it, but the idea of just taking the same character through the same game again just has never gelled with me. The rest of the modern FROM games feel perfectly fine with ignoring the whole feature, a single playthrough feels just fine, but right off the bat one of the oft repeated strongest points for DS2 is how it handles NG+, so I'm really not sure it's for me.

snippet.textDisplay: Look, it's a souls game so I'll like it, but it's definitely the worst of the souls games overall. Some of the points you name here (Ie the story) are basically "I like it even though it's not good." I feel like you make a large effort to say the game is good, but as you explain them it only highlights some of its negatives. Yeah, the story is cool, and every story can be cool. A story however, is largely based on how it's told and you yourself said it's not very cohesive. All the souls games have good stories, the others just tell them better. Graphics wise I don't think the game is that great. Sure the environments are neat, but graphics are terrible to look at and most of the game has bare and basic textures. The detail only looks decent from far away. Many of the mechanics of the game seem useless (although you see them as a plus) and the redundancy of having so many is insane. Like "ah yes, I enjoy having to repair my weapon at majula every 15 minutes or less" because durability is heavily incorporated. It would make more sense if it wasn't a game that resets the environment and enemies every time you traveled back. Not only that but repair powder isn't even largely available until drangleic castle and only repairs about a third of your equipped weapons. Enemy spawn as you mentioned are terrible in the game, and it's quite easy to be overwhelmed and chased down for miles. The NG experience is quite neat and I'm sad that they didn't have more things like that in the game, but they're just harder enemies here and there and a few new reused boss encounters. To say it's your opinion that it's overrated, sure, but I think it gets an appropriate amount of slack for what it does bad in comparison to other games from fromsoft.

snippet.textDisplay:
Of all the games DS2 has the most vibrant community. Every February I boot up a new character for the Return to Drangleic. 

Why? Because it's not a perfect game. It's flawed, has exploits, is frustrating to deal with many times over. But every time I find a way to overcome it. Not all games are worth going back to.  Quality of life improvements in games like halo and final fantasy,  make earlier versions unplayable. DS3 & elden ring have refined the core of the game.  they abandoned others, things that shaped my experience as a unique one.  and that makes this game stand out so much more. The last thing is no game embodies the idea of melancholy like this one. It's meditative and beautiful. 

I love this game, with all its flaws. It wouldn't be the same without them.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually prefer ds2 to 3. I like that 2 is this weird experimental game that sometimes doesn’t work but more times than not I have fun with it. 3 annoyed me with its reliance on “nostalgia” for ds1, whereas 2 does its own thing to varying effects. I’d rather play a weird experiment that has issues but a “heart of gold” than a nostalgia trip for a game that at the time was only like 7 years old.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ds2 was indeed a unique addition to the series, when you put it up against other games in the series at first, it could be seen as weak BUT it was amazing, also the only game in the series I believe that you could strengthen your armour in, making you pretty strong in end game. I loved it, it had some of the most challenging areas in any of the games and level design was on par with the rest of them in my opinion, and that's saying something since the genius level design of the first dark souls game was what really made me fall in love with it in the first place, along side the rewarding gameplay when you overcame an area or boss for the first time. Ds2 didn't do that as well as ds1 for the most part, but it did it right at some parts. Enough for it to be a true dark souls.
The thing about dark souls (all of them) is that once your knowledge of the level design, enemy placement and overall gameplay mechanics becomes sufficient, the game becomes extremely easy as opposed to the polar opposite when you don't have any of this knowledge. I could run through most of these games from start to finish and die very few times because I know where I'm going and what to expect,but that adds to the game experience for me because I've earned that knowledge and skill

snippet.textDisplay: I could write a whole thing on this, but the reason people don't like DS2 is that it was lazy. Good bosses were replaced with A LOT of gank fights. Reskins were common. Sure, there was tons of loot and I particularly like the variety of spells, but Boss Fights define a Souls Game. O&S from DS1, Gwyn, Ceaseless Discharge, Bed of Chaos, all are iconic. I can't even name a DS2 boss that wasn't a humanoid with a weapon. And DS2 has more bosses than any other game in the series. That's why people didn't like it.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 bosses in this guy's head are criminally overrated.

They're all just strafe and hit, over and over. They're not memorable. I don't remember half of them, while I can list all DS1 bosses after waking up at 2 am.

The story is ok. However, I enjoy 3's style of building the story over areas and stories of 1 more directly, instead of showing completely separated kingdom, with no resemblence to Lordran (bar the lord souls being the same souls from 1). And the world is just connected badly in 2.

1 and 3 are masterpieces, 2 is not, it's just an ok game. And Scholar of the First Sin is straight up garbage.

snippet.textDisplay: I never played ds2. And I’m don’t band wagon and hate it outright. But from what I read about it and seen other videos it’s more about me being afraid playing it. I’ve played the souls series out of order as after Elden ring I played DS3, skipping DS2, and played DS1. I then played Bloodborne and Demon’s Souls. Then stopped right at Demon’s Souls. I’ve been always thinking about DS2 and been telling myself to go and play it, but scared too knowing the game. Right now with my understanding without playing DS2 is that it’s difficult but in the wrong way. Not in a fair like challenge way but more unfair way. Like having so many enemies in a area and taking the Iframes from things that give you it like pulling levers, going through dog walls, backstabs, etc. Again this doesn’t make me in a way dislike or hate the game (since I didn’t play it yet) but more about being scared to play it.

snippet.textDisplay: dark souls 2 and sotfs is peak soulsborne, I loved how much they slowed down the combat loop (i mean just look at dark souls 3 its just spam roll, win) where dark souls 2 you have to really think about your openings or you are going to get bodied. The character respect system is one of the best in the series besides the likes of elden ring. also the only game in the series to add secret rings for playing the game well, bravo. Everyone complaining about the adaptability skill just don't understand it, but I think its one of the coolest off stats in any souls game, "turn based dark souls" but I don't see it as such, if you choose to level adaptability you can play more reckless, but is no means needed at all to play the game, you don't have to dodge roll every attack, but everyone is so hard into lock on and dueling an enemy, that it seems as the only way to play, truth be told the games are far easier if you don't lock on, you can control your attacks better and roll onmi-directional instead of the 4ish directions while locked. The dlc's were amazing, and some of the coolest boss fights in the series. I really don't understand all the hate for the game when people praise ds1 and 3 so highly for no reason. ds1 was an unfinished mess, and dark souls 3 was just a copy cat of ds1, where ds2 stands on its own unique pillar. Now to sotfs enemy placement, I'll agree that they can be overwhelming and that is why everyone runs past them, but that just makes them worse at the game and in turn make them hate it more. GET GUD if you would, thanks. However, the only thing I refuse to defend is frigid outskirts, wtf were they smoking man... lol. Rant over, enjoy.

snippet.textDisplay:
4:42 and this right here, highlights what i think 90% of the people who hate the game don't understand about it. you are NOT SUPPOSED TO RUN PAST THE ENEMIES!

In dark souls 2, trying to run past the enemies is the worst possible idea you could have, you are rewarded for FIGHTING them, because that is the GAME, the game is you fight the enemies, so it makes no sense that you'd ever try to run past them.

Plus dark souls 2 has the system of enemies no longer spawning after being killed so many times, which means you're rewarded for fighting them by being given an easier time in the future, the more you fight them, the less you need to fight them.

People who try and run past enemies and just... ignore 90% of the game are just making it harder for themselves, you wouldn't have that "being swarmed by 20+ enemies all at once" problem if you just fought and killed them methodically and one encounter at a time like you're supposed too.

Dark souls 2 is not a boss rush game, don't try to treat it as such.

snippet.textDisplay: A counter point to adaptability, you get more souls and levels quickly in DS2 to account for the fact you're spending points in in an extra stat. This has the upside of letting you the player decide if you want I frames, or better dps. Depending on your build, and how good you are at dodging without I frames, it actually gives the player more freedom and choice without actually punishing them. People forget how obtuse the stats were in DS1 on day one, and how you needed to learn how to build a character. They seemed to have wanted to walk into 2 and level up without learning a new system, and then made fun of the new system despite it probably being better.

snippet.textDisplay:
I always praised DS2 PvP as the best in the series, but I couldn't quite put my finger on why until Parker The Rat mentioned the slow animations in his video essay. The weighty, slower animations definitely reduced successful roll-spam escapes and made duels much more engaging, like a proper fight, baiting your opponent into playing into your hands, punishing their mistakes, and rewarding the player for clever plays and successful predictions. They couldn't just roll-spam away like they can in DS3 and ER. 

The combat felt methodical and nuanced and not without its punishments for spams or overcommitment. In this sense, it was like all players obeyed the same animation laws that the enemies and bosses did, and it felt natural. You bait a big swing, they whiff, and that's your chance for a punish. Or maybe they're fishing for backstabs, and you punish them with a good turnabout. Stuff like that just doesn't happen with lesser animation locks and spammy dodges.

I fondly remember falling in love with the humble Broadsword because of its charged R2 sweeping attack, which could whip out a full 180 sweep when you unlocked your targeting, letting you roll-catch and punish backstab farmers. Players were rewarded for learning little techs like that, and it was a great expression of player skill. That slow weightiness made the tempo for PvP feel just right. (And the lack of a Hornet Ring for less prevalent parry cheeses helped alot too.)

snippet.textDisplay:
It's really not. It's really, really not. It 100% deserves its reputation. There were some cool gimmicks and experimentation but for some to act like some of its biggest mechanical faults (healing system reworked by nerfing the flask to stop your movement for like 3 seconds despite lifegems trivializing the game, i-frames tied to a skill that everyone just levels up to 30ish immediately anyways thus wasting time and xp that could've been spent on actual buildcrafting, gank squads that ds2 defenders insist were also present in the other games even though other ganks in the series are usually composed of enemies that die in 1 or 2 hits) are actually really interesting design decisions that are actually what make the game good and special is legitimately delusional. 

Even its best bosses like Fume Knight, Alonne, and Ivory King are only on par with some of the mid tier bosses from ds3, the most I can say is that they're better than a large chunk of bosses from ds1. Ds2 is like if they took post-Anor Londo ds1 and made it the whole game while also making the moment to moment gameplay mechanically worse.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 while a good game is no doubt the worst of all the souls games. Too many half baked and poorly implemented ideas. Especially the area design. So many areas hampered by something very detrimental. Shrine of Amana is so cool, but playing it is horrible because of the mages. Iron Keep is a cool idea but not fun to fight any enemy in the whole area. Aldia's Keep is a let down if you were hyped from the original gameplay trailers/teasers. Lots of cool ideas in terms of aesthetic design, but implementation is pretty bad.
Overall my absolute BIGGEST complaint is durability. The system in DS2 is the worst any game of the series has ever had. ADP is a close second. Hit boxes a close third.
The story is ok, not bad just a little bit too much rehashing like DS3.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like approaching this game with the same mindset as dark souls 1 and 3 narratively speaking is the wrong way to approach it. Focusing on the light and dark aspect shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the *actual* narrative dark souls 2 is trying to push. It is focusing on the *curse* and the bearer of the curse is not here to link the flame or take the throne of want. It’s clearly stated in the intro cutscene that they are here to find a cure for the curse. This ties into the stories of Vendrick, Aldea, and the 4 daughters of Manus. The focus isn’t the cycle, it’s the effects of the curse and the lengths people will go to in order to reach this unattainable goal wether it be physical, metaphorical, or even non existent. It’s a bleak look into the curse’s effects and just how much Gwyn has fucked everyone. Hell, Vendrick actually *has* the soul of Gwyn in him (which is never really elaborated on as clearly as it should have but dark souls 3 does actually make up for that.)

Like.. I don't understand why the community keeps shitting on it when it's far from being weird for a fromsoft game to do. Iron keep being "over the skies" isn't really that hard to understand that it's meant to show that the world makes no sense just like ds1. Time is fucked, the world is fucked. So of course the land itself wouldn't make sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
15:09 Adaptability and Attunement to a lesser extenct govern the amount of Agility your character has with big diminishing returns after 99 Agility.
For Casters this means 30 lvls on Att (6 slots) and 17 lvls on Adp give enough Agl for you to never worry about this stat again.
For all other characters 25 lvls on Adp have the same effect.

While I agree the game fails to explain these things, and Adp is kind of a wasted stat, after looking it up on the wiki I stopped having a problem with it.

I played the Dark Souls franchise in order of launch, ds2 being my least favourite by far for a long time, but after getting tired of ds3 I went back and replayed the older games and the differences in ds2 have made it my favourite, these days I have about 200 hours in DS1, 600 in DS3 and 700 in DS2, currently playing through it again with a friend, trying out the Vanquisher's Seal, puching things in the face feels so good

snippet.textDisplay:
- The pursuer doesn't gain dark magic from an attack, that's something you get from some of them, but not all of them have it.

- The only non DLC boss I can say is cool and unique is Looking Glass Knight. You can end up on a 3v3 PvP match with two players helping the boss against the host and two summons, and those players helping the boss can use miracles to heal him, so it gets chaotic and exciting very easily.


- I still think that Dark Souls 2 would've been better as a King's Field, and I wish they would've got all the time they needed to finish all that lost content (Like the black gulch).

- My favorite thing that no other souls has done so effectively is how Dark Souls 2 allows me to build a "Spellsword" or Magic Knight, since I could use Blue Flame to cast spells and actually do damage since it was an amazing catalyst.

- I really hate how Dark Souls 2 removed the ability to break off grabs. Dark Souls (both 1 and 3) allow you to break off a grab (or at least mitigate the damage) by mashing your right hand attacks (both light and heavy), and this is because the game seems to be planed for multiplayer (you can only break free of a grab if a phantom hits whoever grabs you).

- We got less Stamina to work with on Dark Souls 2, forcing us to learn to keep our distance and use fighting game skills like footsies and punishing. This can be good or bad depending on personal preference.

- I don't think the flack is undeserved since the game did a lot of annoying things like ADP, some bullshit attacks (16:22 is an example), lower stamina, equipment durability and enemy aggro.

Despite all this, I still like Dark Souls 2, but that doesn't mean I don't agree with all those who hate it for all those bad things it did.

snippet.textDisplay: LOOK HERE. I played ds 2 first time and thought like hell the game is amazing and i really liked and after that i often sought to defend it whenever posssible, then i went to play the second time, after i experienced ds 3 personally, i also had more general knowledge and was more critical and objective, and... The game is shit. It's a cbt experience. It's like watered down scorched contract mod, it's suffering for the sake of suffering. There are many things in the game that are intentionally bad, and a lot of things that are unintentionally bad, but still bad. DS 2 also had novel and amazing things like powerstance that were later adopted in both ds 3 and elden ring in some or full capacity. The problem with ds 2 is it doesn't understand what it should do to be good. It doesn't have to be a direct sequel to ds 1, but it didn't need to make things harder. They didn't need to make stamina as annoying to manage as it is compared to any other soulsborne for example, they also didn't have to create absolute dogshit enemy gauntlets for boss arena runs and then "fix" it by making enemies despawnable. They didn't have to make weapon durability equate to a wet noodle and tie to a fucking framerate, because noboy enjoys using repair powder midfight with the boss or even exploration of some location, nobody wants to use ring that decreases weapon degradation for anything other than gimmick weapon attacks that eat durability. I can go on for much longer, but i'm gonna wrap this up here. DS 2 has a lot of potentinal to be a good game if it was simply remade by someone more competent whether it's design of battles, design of locations, or more techincal side of things (i know fromsoft are notorious for their tech issues but it's just so much more prevalent in ds 2 because of all the other bad things)

snippet.textDisplay:
I will admit, Dark Souls 2 has a lot of good things about, but there's *so much wrong* about it that I just can't find myself enjoying it.  The obvious stuff like the plethora of boring bosses, ADP and Soul Memory being terrible ideas, and bad map design aside.  But there's also just so many wonky hit boxes, bad animations, countless poorly designed and outright unfair enemy placement and encounters, and the lore, while really cool in some places, just doesn't do a good job of explaining how the fuck half the world is the way it is.  I don't need a reminder that Heide's Tower and the Blue Citadel are obvious Anor Londo callbacks when Ornstein V2 shows up, or that the big bosses are supposed to be "references" to the DS1 lords.  Yeah, I'm sure the Old Iron King has a fantastic lightning bolt somewhere in his arsenal, he just doesn't feel the need to break it out.

Then there's the people who try so hard to defend the bad aspects as if the two or three good things make up for terrible ones.  Multiplayer is only fun when you *want* to play multiplayer, and thats a different argument.  The New Game+ mechanics, and by extension, the bonfire ascetic, are cool in theory, but suffer because 90% of the time they exasperate the bad enemy placement problen.  And don't try to argue that DS3 was bad because it actually tried to be a sequel.  Dark Souls 2 was going the way of Final Fantasy, ie new and original world with a few recurring elements.  No, I want *ACTUAL* continuity in my video games, thank you.

In short, DS2 is a cool idea thats pretty poorly implemented.  Too many janky, unrefined mechanics, too little depth to make me actually feel like it means something.  When the only actually good parts of the game are the DLC, you have a problem.

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually disagree with you on adaptability and animation timing. 
If you think about it, adaptability just gives you more options on what your play style will look like. Dont want to focus on dodging much and rather go for a tank build with a massive shield? Pump the points into vitality instead! This also somewhat forces you to commit to that play style and keeps the builds balanced (you dont want a stone turtle to have 17 i frames and be practically unkillable that way, do you?). Casters get most of their agility via attunement anyway, so no big deal for them. I feel like we‘re just so stuck on using rolls the entire game that we see leveling adaptability as an unnecessary chore, when leveling it really is a choice, just like any other stat. 
And the slow animation timing fits well into the rather slow nature of the rest of the game. You have to play it slow if you dont want to get ganked by the alonne knights, for example. The bosses are also a lot slower than in DS3 or ER, so it makes sense for those games to have faster animations, a faster pace and hence DS2 having slower ones.
I really enjoyed watching this!

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who love DS2, I can say that I haven't ever noticed the animation thing he talk about here. I say this because I think that sounds very scary, and I don't want that to turn people of from trying DS2. 
My praise: The game truly has some of the most epic locations in the whole series, and some of the most epic bosses too. The game also has the MOST bosses of any of the soulsborne games. And most of them are good. Some of them a truly amazing, and amongst the most memorable :D Lastly, I find Firelink Shrine in this game to be my favorite. Both the music, and the view/location. In DS3 Firelink Shrine was just bullshit. Dark room, and you teleport everywhere. DS1 and DS2 had it be an outdoor location interconnected with the world around it, and DS2 does this just like DS1 does, only I personally like DS2 location and music better for this.

snippet.textDisplay:
For me, Dark Souls 2 is not a bad game. However, it does deserve criticsm for its change in design philosophy for difficulty for the sake of it. Even the changes in New Game + in Ds2 don't help this, as they tend to overwhelm the player. There's a couple boss changes in NG+, but it leads me to believe that idea was half baked, like a lot of mechanics in Ds2. 

As for the bosses, yes there's some good ones, but the sheer quantity  of how many bad to mediocre bosses, many of which try to be important to the story and I expect to be better, just flop around before the player. Every time I've played Ds2, I question the developers every choice, because it feels like they could never say no to an idea.

I think the story is decent, but the only truly profound moment I felt in the entire game was Vendrick's reveal. Almost everything not related to him through the DLC and Nashandra just felt like padding or bland flavoring. That's like a fourth of the base game that made any impact on me. I would like the base game more if the presence of Vendrick and Nashandra were more apparent, rathering than feeling like I'm traveling through unrelated ruins.

In Ds1 I genuinely felt like I was exploring Gwyn's Kingdom, now in ruin. In Ds3 I felt like I was exploring a world warping on itself at a foundational level, with the remaining lands desperately trying to find space for themselves as the world converges on a singularity point. In Ds2 I just took in each new area as another video game level, not thinking about any sort of world building. As a writer, details like that matter to me, espcially related to lore.

snippet.textDisplay:
While i always liked DS2 for me it was/still is the worst all around.
But it for me had the best and most fun PVP, so many different weapons was actually viable in PVP and powerstance made it even better.
DUO WHIPS IS MY JAM!!!!
That along with the PVP covenants made it so much easier and more fun to play PVP imo, i haven't really played PVP in Elden Ring with that i have it on playstation and i refuse to pay to be online but even so i haven't seen anything comparable to that.

The aesthetics i like but mostly in that you could get gear from a higher NG+ cycle without having to play it over and over and over.
I didnt like when it was just a better ring but when you could get 2 of the same unique weapon on one playthrough that was nice.

I also personally liked the decreasing max hp when you died, it made death just a bit more consequential but even so the amount of "humanity" you got and the ring that would cap it made it not so hard to deal with anyway.

The whole thing with enemies not respawning after... *x* amount of kills on them was annoying, ESPECIALLY WHEN I WAS FARMING THE RUIN SENTINEL SET AND DESERT SORCERESS SET!!!!
But then i learned of that one covenant that turned that off, which helped but still having me forced to have that covenant to farm was annoying...

snippet.textDisplay: This is the most level-headed video on the subject I've ever seen. People can really get heated on the subject of "game bad/game good" and both sides are to blame. For me, I absolutely love Dark Souls 2 and it's my favorite of the trilogy (Bloodborne beats it by just a bit). At the same time, when I meet someone online or irl that hates DS2, I totally get it. I can't defend the problems with it, because I SHARE those complaints. But, Dark Souls 2 is still the one I always gravitate towards when I feel sad and want to burn a day healing up. It's the world were I care the most about the characters and the most fun bosses to fight. It has a lot of replayability and openess that only Elden Ring could rival, so even I, stubborn as I am, am inclined to experiment with different builds. I love this game, it's fucking ugly and broken, but so is dark souls 1. Dark Souls 3 is the "polished" version of Dark Souls 3, and as much as I love it, ds3 lost something that ds and ds2 had.

It has a lot of replayability and openess that only Elden Ring could rival, so even I, stubborn as I am, am inclined to experiment with different builds. I love this game, it's fucking ugly and broken, but so is dark souls 1. Dark Souls 3 is the "polished" version of Dark Souls 3, and as much as I love it, ds3 lost something that ds and ds2 had.

snippet.textDisplay: I am a sucker for an underdog, an ugly duckling, a runt, etc etc, more belabored metaphors. And DS2 is one of the most significant oddities in any major franchise. It feels like a timcapsule of PS3 era, cartoonish graphical fidelity, and a wonky stroke of genius that dared to be whatever it wanted to be, despite the legacy of Dark and Demons Souls before it. It feels like it's overflowing with ideas and doesn't stop to think whether they're good or not but does consider whether they're interesting (and all the design choices of this game are interesting, imo). Anyway, Majula forever. 🤘

snippet.textDisplay:
This is my advice for DS2, though I would recommend this for all other games except perhaps Elden Ring due to its much more open nature: KILL EVERYTHING (except enemies just put there to teach you that you don't have to fight everything due to them being very hard). 
What I mean by this is, avoid ganks by destroying said ganks. Do not run past enemies. In DS2 you can even despawn everything after 10 deahts or so. It's what I always do in Heide's Tower of Flame or the memories of Sir Alonne, kill everything, level up a ton with the souls gained, and then walk up to the boss with no opposition. 
Also while you do all this you might want to listen to a podcast or music or something.

snippet.textDisplay: I think 2 is probably my favorite in the series and I frankly never understood why it was seen as so inferior. Granted the world isn’t as interconnected, but it also doesn’t have Lost Izalith which has many of the worst design choices in the entire FromSoft catalogue. The “feel” of combat in 3 never sat right with me either. Like it didn’t have enough weight to it or something. Getting all the crowns to break the undead curse for yourself felt immensely satisfying and was a solid challenge. I don’t remember what they changed about dual wielding between 2 and 3 other than it felt better in 2.

I think i just have to mention this, because i like ADP. ADP is almost a mandetory stat and that can be unfun. But:
1. Id rather have a bad Stat like ADP than a usless stat like Resistance in DS1. ADP atlest does somthing positive for you. While RES just does nothing.
2. ADP is part of the player Fantasy. If you want to be Agile you LVL ADP, if you want to be a heavy Knight with a Greatshild you can safely Ignore it. 
the animation Frames on ADP really arent that significant and most ppl wont feel the difference even with MAX Agility.
3. I dont like how my Chars in DS1 and 3 always feel the same. Sure one uses magic and the other dosnt but the move the same roll the same, you get the point. Not LVling ADP can be a conties choise, or something you just didnt know and can make you playthrough feel very different from just this one stat.
so i like it. but i understand why ppl feel different about it. they have an expectation of how it feels to play a Souls game and DS2 dosnt fit that and having to invest lvl into ADP just to get it somethere close to what you expect feels bad.

snippet.textDisplay: I prefer sotfs over ds1. ds2 is genuinely one of my favorite souls games of all time, and I could care less what the majority says. it has a ton of good content, and sure, it can be ganky at times, but you eventually get used to it. the amount of armor and weapons is insane compared to other games, and it really shows how experimental this game was. some were bad, sure, but a lot of it was great. I feel most people push it aside because of the ganks, janky animations, adaptability, and experimentation (with things like rolling through doors for example)

snippet.textDisplay:
I played Dark Souls 2 for the first time only after playing Bloodborne, Dark Souls 1 and 3, and Sekiro. With the experience of those games, I went into DS2 curious to see what all the fuss was about. I liked a lot of things about the game. The locations were beautiful, the story was intriguing, Majula is a great hub area and that music is mesmerizing, going into the memories of the giants was a cool idea, Bonfire ascetics were fun to try out, I liked how backstab animations were different for each weapon instead of the same like in DS1 and 3, and although the map doesn't cross and intersect and loop back around like DS1 or Bloodborne do, I still liked that you had many different paths to choose from connecting to Majula. From the start I was really curious what was down that hole in Majula, but didn't have enough health to survive the fall. Eventually, going down there and discovering just how deep it went was a really cool experience. 
However, being experienced with the other Souls games, I couldn't help but notice that something about the gameplay felt off. The character was noticeably slower at everything, no matter the equip load. Rolling was slower, drinking estus was slower, the health filled up slowly and not instantly, the time it took roll after an attack or any animation was much longer, and for some reason I couldn't understand why I was still taking damage when I swore I dodged at the right time. That wasn't an issue I had in the other games and of course I had no idea adaptability was a thing. I struggled through most of the game thinking it was the wonky hitboxes everyone was talking about, until I finally read somewhere that leveling up adaptability increased your speed and invincibility frames when rolling. After leveling it up a little bit, all of a sudden the game felt how a Souls game should feel. Rolling and drinking were the right speed now. 
This is one of many aspects of the game that were put in just to make it harder, but it wasn't fair difficulty, it was just for the sake of difficulty. Constantly being swarmed by too many enemies to handle at once, too many bosses were only challenging because they were a 3v1, having your max health be reduced with every death until you use an effigy, enemies' attacks had farther reach than you would expect, many enemies had combos that were just annoying and unpredictable, and the fact that your health fills up slowly caused so many deaths that wouldn't have happened in the other games.
It just makes it a less enjoyable experience overall.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you’re watching this thinking you should play the game, note that he doesn’t discuss the moment to moment gameplay of the game almost at all, because the game fundamentally is not fun to play.  The combat feels both sluggish and unfair, and the game lacks the interconnected world for exploration  of the first game.  The bosses are either complete pushovers or filled with the most jank hitboxes imaginable, and there’s a clear emphasis on quantity over quality.
I’ve beaten every souls game/sekiro/elden ring/bloodborne and you should play literally any other of these games unless you just want to be able to say you’ve beaten the series like me.  When I took the throne of want, I was just glad I’d never have to play the game again

snippet.textDisplay: Common misconception about the attack animation timings, most attack animations are cancel-able in the beginning of their animations. So you do not have to wait for an animation to end unless you messed up the timing of a cancel. Some of the quicker weapons also for some reason still apply their hitboxes even if the animation is canceled, provided it's done in the later half of the cancel window. Easiest weapons to do this with in my opinion are dual fist weapons, as doing the powerstanced light attack has a pretty big window for dodge canceling it before the first hit, and rolling while doing this still has the first hit connect WHILE you're in dodge roll.(I was called a lag abuser in PvP on the original PS3 release because i discovered this early on, but i can assure you it's not lag as it works in PvE as well.)

snippet.textDisplay:
Demons souls - Cool areas, unique atmosphere, gameplay can feel dated at times
DS1 - Iconic, best atmosphere and map design, lackluster second half of the game
DS2 - Felt like an adventure, cheap level design and enemies but tons of stuff to find and enjoy
DS3 - Very replayable, amazing boss fights, lots of nostalgia bombs instead of new things 
Bloodborne - The best in general, very unique setting and lore, only bad things i can think about are blood vials farming and underwhelming chalice dungeons 
Sekiro - Best combat, really cool setting, very different from other games, lack of customization 
Elden ring - The most epic, tons of customization and things to do, gameplay felt unbalanced at times and open world formula can get annoying

snippet.textDisplay:
11:54 This is not accurate. The throne of want doesn't represent linking the flame. The throne of wants represents accepting the choice to either link the flame or let it fade. It includes both of the endings of DS1. That's why it's called the throne of want, as it allows you to shape the world according to your want.  Accepting the throne represents becoming what Aldia calls "a true monarch". Quoting the scholar himself: "There are but two paths. Inherit the order of this world, or destroy it. But only a true monarch can make such a choice.". However Aldia has realized that the choice itself doesn't matter, because either way the world will end up the same. If you rekindle the flame, it will just fade again in the future. If you let it fade, it won't trully die out and another undead will link it, eventually. This is the main point DS2 tries to convey and it is manifested in the fact that the game does not let you actually make that choice, because it's irrelevant, and you are supposed to realize this too. You are trapped in an endless cicle, and there is nothing you can do to escape from it. Aldia realized this, and spent his life looking for a way to break the cicle, some kind of 3rd option, but failed in doing so. "I sought to shed the yoke of fate, but failed.", then he kinda incites you to do the same as he did, to look for that 3rd option: "But the question remains... What do you want, truly? Light? Dark? Or something else entirely..." That "something else entirely" is what leaving the throne of want represents. It is renouncing making the choice between Light and Dark, just as Vendrick did before you. It means you are following Aldia's steps and looking for that 3rd option.
His final dialogue if you choose that option is very telling: "There is no path. Beyond the scope of light, beyond the reach of Dark...what could possibly await us? And yet, we seek it, insatiably... Such is our fate."
In all games, the characters and the player know the same things about the world:
In DS1 you are not aware you are in a cicle. 
In DS2 you become aware of the cicle but no one knows how to break free from it (still many try to do so).
In DS3, you are finally able to break the cicle (Betraying the flame ending).

snippet.textDisplay: As an RPG, DS2 is still a good title, despite its flaws. But a game in the Souls genre is fundamentally about combat, and the combat mechanics in DS2 are atrocious. When you combine poor hitboxing, iframes tied to agility, excessive move tracking, and high numbers of simultaneous enemies, it's a chore to play. DS2's combat is below titles like Ashen, Remnant, and Mortal Shell. Mortal Shell in particular not only executes combat better, but introduced new mechanics to the genre that far exceed anything DS2 tried to do with the Souls formula. DS is good, but it's not good enough, especially from a developer that was also making *Bloodborne* at the time. FromSoft were capable of better than this.
snippet.textOriginal: As an RPG, DS2 is still a good title, despite its flaws. But a game in the Souls genre is fundamentally about combat, and the combat mechanics in DS2 are atrocious. DS2's combat is below titles like Ashen, Remnant, and Mortal Shell. Mortal Shell in particular not only executes combat better, but introduced new mechanics to the genre that far exceed anything DS2 tried to do with the Souls formula. DS is good, but it's not good enough, especially from a developer that was also making *Bloodborne* at the time. FromSoft were capable of better than this.

I think the reality is that the community set up DS2 to fail. 

If it was too similar to DS1, people would have complained. They made it very dissimilar to 1 instead, but kept the lore ties, and people complain and say it’s “not even the part of the story.

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved DS1, but neither it nor DS3 really gripped me like DS2. It's the only one in the series I find myself going back to.
I've never really seen ADP as an issue, since even 10-12 ADP is enough to avoid most attacks with proper timing, especially if you have enough attunement for even 1 spell. The only exception are those dang thunder reindeer xD If you know you know. If you don't, you lucky plonker.
One of the really stronger parts of DS2 are its variety in how different the areas look from one another. Even at the very start, the 3 first areas from Majula are so different. Instead of just grey and undead here undead there, ooh that undead has a torch; what a sight to behold. DS2 has a ruined and overgrown fort, a pristine but "partially" sunken castle, and a shadowy pirate bay

snippet.textDisplay: In my opinion Dark Souls 2 has the best ambience in the series thanks to moody soundtrack, character stories and general art direction. This air of sadness and melancholic nostalgia is unmatched. Also I just happen to enjoy the slower, a bit more tactical combat a lot more then the fast one in DS3. Having played all FS titles in order from Demon's Souls to Elden Ring as they released, I must say Dark Souls 2 is by far my favourite in the series. Bloodborne is a close second though for it's style and themes. So I don't get the hate. It may not be a Dark Souls sequel that fans dreamed of, but it's an incredible game doing it's own things in it's own ways. Thus thank you for making a point in defense of this underrated game.

snippet.textDisplay: I have to disagree with your take on enemy placement in Scholar. It wasnt made that way to teach you to run past enemies, it was the opposite, to teach you to fight them. Thats why if you try to enter a fog wall or open a door or pull a lever you can get hit out of it, incentivizing you to kill all enemies before that point. There are some spots that have a few enemies that are too much for comfort, but with careful skill and patience you can take them all out unscathed. The issue you had in Hyde's tower of flame was the fact you killed Dragon Rider first then just ran past everything. You arent meant to just run past all the enemies, the game punishes you for doing that. Thats one of the biggest reasons why people hate 2, because they think its "too ganky" and its really not.

snippet.textDisplay:
Something i really missed in ds3 is breakable objects and traps. In Ds2 you can break weak doors or make tough enemies break some damaged walls to open new areas or shortcuts which was nice addition. In Ds3 and Bb a warrior who kills eldrich horrors and overworldly monsters can be stopped by simple wooden door which "does not open from this side".
 Wooden chests in ds2 are breakable and loot inside can turn into rubbish if you do so which makes you act extra carefully around it. In other chapters you just whack chests with your Instrument of Ultimate Destruction +10 without any consequences.
And traps just kept you on your toes each time you saw something valuable. Even if chest in front of you isn't a mimic there can be trap inside or pressure plate around it which could damage or even kill you so you have to always watch out for those.
And don't get me started on Power Stances! It's really sad that many good ideas were undeservably forgotten.

snippet.textDisplay:
The thing about DS2 is that almost all of the problems with it are exclusively about the gameplay. The story, the lore, the art direction, the ambience, the designs, all of that is top notch and most people agree that those are all amazing, but some of the flaws with the gameplay pull people's attention away from that.

I'm pretty sure that if you ask a big souls fan who says they dislike DS2 about their opinions on the visual direction of the game or the lore, chances are they'll compliment it and say they like it. Most of the people who say DS2 is bad (the ones who actually know what they're talking that is, who played the game and formed their own opinion. Not the people who just repeat what they heard) are thinking about gameplay aspects when they say that.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 is my least favorite of the series, but that isn't because I dislike it, it's just because I like the others too much.

I really do love DS2 and despite it being my least favorite, it actually has more things in it that I remember foundly than most of the others because of it's many unique and characteristic aspects. So even as someone who often says DS2 is my least favorite, I still believe that the game recieves FAR more hate than it deserves.

And honestly, even though I liked playing DS1 and DS3 more, I actually think DS2 is the most interesting one to go back to. Mostly because it has so many different things and so much stuff I'm not as familiar with, as well as because of how similar DS3 is to Elden Ring in many ways, with Elden Ring just being better.

i just wish that ds2 expanded on ds1 more, like a sequel should. people poke at ds3 for having too many references to ds1, but like, why wouldn't it? it's another game in the dark souls series, why shouldn't it carry on the same story? ds2 just feels like it tried to distance itself from ds1 as much as possible, which is a weird decision to me. they could've just chosen to make it not a dark souls game at all, but instead they made it a confusing half sequel 

ds2 really just doesn't add anything to the stories we had in the original game, when it could've done so much more with them

snippet.textDisplay:
the ascetics also allowing you to rechallenge bosses is, to me, the main draw of them. Boss fights are a large part of these games, and while it is fair to criticize most of ds2's bosses for being easy to forget dudes in armor... I HATE the idea of having to play through ALL of that linear hallway colloquially known as Dark Souls 3 just to see a boss I like again.

I was SOOOOOO hoping the Stakes of Marika in Elden Ring would function similarly to the ascetics; interact with them, give them an item, boss respawns but at a higher ng level. Instead they are just a boring "respawn point, but closer to the boss this time" statue of wasted potential.

Thats the real cost of everyone constantly shitting on Dark Souls 2. Its different. It has some objective issues. But I'll be damned if it didnt evolve the Souls format in many ways and some of those ways were incredibly good... and then From Software tossed the baby out with the bathwater in future titles. Its taken until Elden Ring - FOUR GAMES LATER - to get proper dual wielding (power stancing) back ffs.

snippet.textDisplay:
My favorite memory of dark souls 2 was when it released.   There were so many people online playing that when we put the ring on to be Bellkeepers, we kept getting summoned so quickly that we couldn't get the ring off for a while. 
Coming from a nearly dead dark souls one (in terms of multiplayer still on Microsoft Games for Windows Live) having covenants work so well that we didn't have time to take off the ring before being summoned again was a giddy joy that I haven't rightly experienced since. 
I like dark souls 2 and always will, if only for that silly memory.
snippet.textOriginal:
My favorite memory of dark souls 2 was when it released.   There were so many people online playing that when we put the ring on to be Bellkeepers, we kept getting summoned so quickly that we couldn't get the ring off for a while. 
Coming from a nearly dead dark souls one (in terms of multiplayer still on Microsoft Games for Windows Live) having covenants work so well that we didn't have time to take off the ring before being summoned again was a giddy joy that I haven't rightly experienced since. 
I like dark souls 2 and always will, if only for that silly memory.

snippet.textDisplay: I just started playing DS3 after finishing DS2 in its entirety, and so far, I like DS2 more, gameplay and lore-wise. Like for example, fashion souls-wise, armor options in DS3 early are rather limited, unlike DS2 which already gives you a wide array of cool armor sets from the get-go. I also prefer DS2's boss progression and enemy placement (The original one) over DS3. Not to mention powerstancing is one of the coolest things inthe Souls series. Elden Ring is basically Dark Souls 2: Remastered:: Remastered.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Scholar teaches you to run past enemies"

All scholar footage: Punishes you endlessly and harshly for running past enemies.

I get that you like the original version more but even your own footage contradicts you on this point.

This is my only real issue with the video that isn't just a correction. Such as Agility being the I-frame/item use speed stat(Mostly effects healing/thrown items) that is also obtainable from Attument (at a worse rate)not just Adaptability. 

So late game spell casters can get rid of most of their ADP while respecing to get more spell slots/casting speed without losing I-frames/Estus speed(Which I-frame soft cap at 99 and Estus speed Maxes out at 100).

Overall I like the video despite the above.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sotfs explicitly teaches you not to run past enemies.

In the Forest it teaches you to take it slow to not wake up sleeping enemies or to aggro enemies behind corners. In Heide's the Old Knights gank up on you if you run past them, but let you do 1 vs 1 duels if you fight them fairly. In Iron Keep you get ganked if you run through it, but can fight them all 1 on 1 if you take it slow.

And then in the Dragon Shrine they ramp it up to a hundred with the duels against the Old Knights. If you run past the duels you get ganked hard, but if you fight them the small knights bow down and let you pass.

It always teaches you that you'll get ganked if you run past enemies, but that you get rewarded for fighting enemies fairly.

snippet.textDisplay: I like Dark Souls 2. It has a weak boss lineup but incredible build variety. It also introduced a lot of features and ideas that I like a lot, some of which even come back in other FromSoft games. Torches, power stancing, a good medium roll, huge Berserk swords, a respec npc, four ring slots, a useful inventory layout, ditching the blacksmith embers and weird boss weapon system from ds1, all of these changes are stuff that makes me glad DS2 exists.
snippet.textOriginal: I like Dark Souls 2. It has a weak boss lineup but incredible build variety. It also introduced a lot of features and ideas that I like a lot, some of which even come back in other FromSoft games. Torches, power stancing, a good medium roll, huge Berserk swords, a respec npc, four ring slots, a useful inventory layout, ditching the blacksmith embers and weird boss weapon system from ds1, all of these changes are stuff that makes me glad DS2 exists.

snippet.textDisplay:
I love these vids as 2 is my favorite Dark Souls by far :)

The atmosphere is top notch

I also strongly disagree with people saying the story is the worst. While I do think the whole throne of want plot is weird, I LOVE how much it focuses on a more intimate and personal story more based on the undead curse that the player character and NPCs they meet along the way are struggling with instead of it being all about the gods and rekindling the fire. I love the take of “finding a new solution other than the linking of the flame”. The memory loss that everyone experiences, and just how tragic you learn the curse can be in that regard is just amazing to me. I’ll never forget Lucatiel’s questline.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played dark souls 2 after Dark souls 1 and before dark souls 3 and I can say all the hate it got is well deserved.
I feel the only people who love this game are people who don't care about atmosphere and npc dialogue and the overall dark souls vibe and those who replay these types of games endlessly.
The mechanics are atrocious and sluggish. For a person playing it the first time without using the internet to know about adaptability or any other decisions this game is an absolute nightmare from start to finish and feels like filler rather than a justifiable sequel to ds1 the level design also felt extremely random and incompetent and the enemy placement just feels off and unfair to be unfair not to pose a challenge. (Im talking about the non-vanilla version, which weirdly enough seems like the better version. So I cannot speak on the vanilla version which I should probably play after finishing elden ring)

snippet.textDisplay:
A fantastic video in defense of this much maligned classic. I've had so much fun with it over the years. Yes, even pre-nerf Shrine of Amana! 

That said, I disagree about adaptability breaking balance. It's the opposite imo. It forces you to think things through and punishes you if you go for a jack-of-all-trades build early on. A tanky dude with pancake unga bunga weapon shouldn't be as nimble as some dude with a dainty lil' rapier and a loincloth. I absolutely love it. Too bad the game never explains the mechanics very well. Of course it all evens out once you advance far enough.

It's just a slower and more strategic game than the others. Chugging Estus is sloooow even with high ADP so the healing gems are a godsent.

Thank you again for this video.
snippet.textOriginal:
A fantastic video in defense of this much maligned classic. I've had so much fun with it over the years. Yes, even pre-nerf Shrine of Amana!

A tanky dude with pancake unga bunga weapon shouldn't be as nimble as some dude with a dainty lil' rapier and a loincloth. I absolutely love it. snippet.textDisplay: Fume Knight is my favorite boss in Dark Souls 2 and one of my personal favorites bosses in gaming at all. snippet.textDisplay:
I had no previous opinions of any Dark Souls games, and came into the series with DS3 on PC years after it was released. I thought it was a great game. I wanted more so I went to try DS1. I was scared it would be too clunky to enjoy after all these years, but I thought it was better it some regards while showing its age in others, but ultimately it was very playable and enjoyable. 

Then I tried DS2 and I just wasn't able to enjoy it at all. The controls/movement was just too clunky for me. I even tried various mods and tweaks to solve it based on lots of Googling, but I wasn't able to make it enjoyable to play. This seemed to be a common complaint towards DS2 from what I could tell. This is surely subjective as some people may not even notice it, but I just couldn't understand how it could feel so much worse than DS1 to play, and it was simply inexcusable for me, so even if the actual game is good I wasn't able to get to a point where I could evaluate that.
snippet.textOriginal:
I had no previous opinions of any Dark Souls games, and came into the series with DS3 on PC years after it was released. I thought it was a great game. I wanted more so I went to try DS1. I was scared it would be too clunky to enjoy after all these years, but I thought it was better it some regards while showing its age in others, but ultimately it was very playable and enjoyable. 

Then I tried DS2 and I just wasn't able to enjoy it at all. The controls/movement was just too clunky for me. I even tried various mods and tweaks to solve it based on lots of Googling, but I wasn't able to make it enjoyable to play. This seemed to be a common complaint towards DS2 from what I could tell. This is surely subjective as some people may not even notice it, but I just couldn't understand how it could feel so much worse than DS1 to play, and it was simply inexcusable for me, so even if the actual game is good I wasn't able to get to a point where I could evaluate that.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m writing this before the vid. I will update after I finish watching. 

I don’t like the way the game feels. The combat is slow and clunky compared to the rest. It just feels wrong. I guess it’s hard to explain, but the hit boxes are also a big issue. 

The bonfire ascetic along with other new items are really great and missed in other games. My huge complaint is the combat feel. 

Frigid outskirts is also just complete trash and I never finished it after hours of pain. It’s the enemies you can’t avoid due to the snow. 



After watching:

TLDR: combat is the worst in the series. Everything else about the game is as good as any other souls game. 

Love the Pursuer

Love the world and pretty much everything about the game and lore

Huge amount of bosses even repeat or cheese ones are great. 

Huge play time is great. 

Visuals are great. 

Healing and animations in general are too slow and not good in my opinion. 

DLC is mainly great. Don’t like the blue smelter for  the run back, horrible hit boxes, and combat of ds2 in general. 

I like all but 2 areas previously mentioned. Dark souls should be hard as hell and a pain to get past. It takes it too far a couple times. The terrible combat and hit boxes ruin it overall though. 

The build variety is incredible. 

Final thoughts:
This is by far my least favorite soulsborne game. Not even close. 
The only reason is the way the combat feels. Blood borne, dark souls 1, dark souls 3, and elden ring feel incredible to play. I have not played demon souls or sekiro. 

The combat ( from boss fights to the the weakest enemy ) is not as good as the rest of the series. Too slow and clunky as well as terrible hit boxes. This is by far the most important aspect of these games. Story takes a back seat and good mechanics can’t save a bad feeling combat system. 

Besides combat, dark souls 2 is as good as the rest of the series easily. Story wise and mechanic wise. 

Sadly, the combat feels absolutely atrocious and I have spent hundreds of hours in all the games I have played in the series. So I can say without bias how the game plays. I wish it was great combat. I was addicted for weeks to this game, but once the combat finally caught up to my patience, I can say I will never play this game ever again.

Great video though. I consider dark souls 2 a success because it should provide at least 100 hours of enjoyable gameplay for souls veterans. Well worth it for the price considering other games out there.

I’m sure no one read all this, but comment if you did and we can discuss. 
I know it’s probably a little repetitive and hard to read, sorry about that.

snippet.textDisplay:
I genuinely get frustrated by something new every single time I play the game. Like, just minor things that lead to a lot of issues, like the ludicrously short lock on range, the number of "hidden enemies" that can't be locked into even when you see them, or adaptabilites effect on dodge frames making it basically a mandatory stat dump.

Reguardless, it's still by far my most played souls game (Elden Ring is quickly catching up though). I think DS2 is a genuinely great game for experimenting with new builds from NG1, because you can so quickly get OP and farm a ton of souls from bosses to snowball into a really satisfying power fantasy. 

Obviously the other 2 entries allow for this too, but I don't think they do so on nearly the same level.

snippet.textDisplay: Calling it criminally underrated is a counterjerk to a counterjerk to the original Dark Souls circlejerk. DS2 is alright. Initially, the game rode on the massive reputation that DS1 built up. It was more of what we loved, MUCH more, following the same formula and without introducing any major flaws. As the time went on though, people noticed that it wasn't as pristine as the first game. Being able to get under the skin of a Fromsoft game and point out that it had some flaws made you an alpha gamer back then, and so the first counterjerk was born and people were eager to hop on that train. That happened especially after DS3 came out, which no longer had those flaws (as well as some of the good mechanics that DS2 introduced that people conveniently forgot about). Is DS2 criminially underrated? No, it's just regularly underrated. I still consider it to be clearly the worst Fromsoft game in the post Demon Souls period, but it's still a Fromsoft game, which makes it better than 99% of games out there, and you should definitely still play it. The differences between DS2 and other Fromsoft games are still small enough that individual perferences might still easily swing it into being your favorite.

snippet.textDisplay: Dark Souls II really didn't get the love it deserved. I will never ever forget the first time I played this game. It was the first souls game I had ever played and usually when people describe their once in a lifetime experiences I can't really relate. I have a hard time imagining the spark they must have felt when explaining those experiences, but for me Dark Souls II was exactly that. I had never experienced anything like that game ever before and haven't ever since. If I had to describe the experience I felt in one word it would be magical. In the most literal sense. I had never been so immersed in a game. For anyone reading, if you have the time I would highly recommend playing this game. Especially if you haven't played a souls like ever before.

snippet.textDisplay:
I did 2 full DS2 playthroughs. One on the original version right around release and one on SOTFS. I do think it’s the weakest of the 3 Dark Souls games. But I also think it is vastly better than people give it credit for. It had its flaws and shortcomings, but it also had a lot going for it in terms of combat flow, weapon and armor design, presentation and plot. The lore wasn’t as deep and pervasive as the lore in 1 and 3 but I also felt like the story of Vendrick and Nassandra was intriguing and compelling and far more directly engaging than in the other entries. Lordrahn castle still remains one or the most memorable locations I’ve played through in a Souls game, the sheer scale and weight of it, the significance of all the answers it may hold, and then the realization that it, too, is empty and a shadow of what it once was under Vendrick’s presence…

Dark Souls 2 is the worst of the souls games. But it still deserves infinitely better than what it got.

snippet.textDisplay:
I find the discussion around this game so strange. It's loomed over by all it's brothers and rightfully so, it's the runt of the litter and has far more issues than even the soul draining garbage that is the final stretch of elden ring or the clearly observable unfinished final 4 areas of dark souls 1. Now if this video was titled, "Why you should still give DS2 a try" or something to that effect I wouldn't be commenting, or at least not in this manner. The fact you're saying DS2 is criminally underrated I just find ridiculous.

The game isn't underrated, it's the sequel to an era and genre defining game. The game DS1 followed was just as genre defining but it managed to add enough to the formula that it still to this day gets concessions for huge flaws it has. DS1's world and level design did something in 3D space that is still to this day mind bending. Making your way back to bonfires to find they're already lit and that you were actually at that same location 15 or 20 minutes ago was such a fresh experience there is still hour long videos talking about it.

Dark Souls 2 had legendary boots to fill and didn't even have the full eye of the man who did most to bring the world into being and shepherded it to it's end later. What Dark Souls 2 does is in most areas is fall short, in a few it falls woefully short and in fewer still it improves or brings in new ideas. The game is clearly made in a way that misunderstands what makes so many of it's systems and combat scenarios work. It completely loses anywhere near the degree of world detail that made DS1s so special and desecrates the meaning of Boss in a from software game to a level that's only been surpassed by Elden Ring thus far.

Now all this doesn't mean you can't like, enjoy or even prefer this game over it's brothers but you've basically shone a light on what you enjoyed and barely touched on the plain and clear issues people have with the game itself on it's own. Not to mention the issues that come from it having From Software as it's developer and the Dark Souls title on it. In doing so you've discounted a fair amount of your points. Just as you highlighted there's been a lot of defence and rousing of positive sentiment around the game since Mauler skewered it across 8 bloody hours. There has been just as many if not more highlighting it's flaws and shortcomings.

This all to say if you like the game and think people should try it that's fine, I like the game quite a lot. I even prefer it over 3 but it's below Bloodborne, DS1 and Sekiro and I think despite it being the poorest made Fromsoft game it's still enjoyable enough that it's worth slogging through it's weaker and frustrating areas because of the satisfaction of certain weapons, spells, boss encounters, levels and most of all it has some of the greatest music. When I suggest the game to others though I don't try and sell it as more than it is which this video is definitely doing from my perspective.

It's a very well done video, I hope this helps you make better content and perhaps think about your approach to argumentation in future. Best of Luck.
