snippet.textDisplay:
I mean... most fans of the Souls series don't really 'Hate' DS2, per say.

Not like TLoU fans hating on TLoU 2. Now that's pure hate. (Justified.)

But Dark Souls 2 is just... Mundane... for a Souls game, that's really the only way to describe it. Mundane.

Sure, the armor sets are amazing, the soundtrack is fantastic (especially Majula), it has many qualities going for it, such as the life gems.

It's side quests feel like actual stories, like you're part of the world, like Lucatiel of Mirrah's questline.

But these bad decisions made by FS are just too pronounced.
The more you die, the lower your health, which is problematic when you're navigating a hard to navigate area (such as Blightt- I mean... The Gutter). Also, The Gutter. The I-frames being whack, ADT stat, boss runs that are just too slow, and too packed with enemies, the DLCs are... just bad...

Soulsborne is meant to be hard, ok. Cool.
But DS2 feels like it was specifically designed to kill you... and then punish you for dying.
And I think this is what it makes it so "hated".
When, in reality... it's still a good game. But not a good Soulsborne game.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually think the slowing down of combat was what made its PvP the best among the souls series. Slower combat actually meant combat had more weight, whiffing attacks was far more punishable than DS3/ER's roll spam that was extremely hard to punish, and playing footsies was a lot more fun than DS3/ER. Better yet was the turning ability of each weapon type that gave more nuance than "in range = can hit". Katanas were extremely powerful at trading, but its poor turn ability meant that it was very easy to roll past a person and counter with a rolling attack. Spears dont perform similarly (or even better) than straight swords because you had range, but you had no turning ability. If a straight sword user got close to you, it was very easy for them to roll behind you and attack because you couldnt turn very well while attacking. Compare this to the current ER spear meta where spears perform better because they turn infinitely well, and stabbing attacks had lingering hitboxes vs sweeping attacks. I had the most fun in DS2 PvP because it felt the most nuanced among the rest.
snippet.textOriginal: I actually think the slowing down of combat was what made its PvP the best among the souls series. Slower combat actually meant combat had more weight, whiffing attacks was far more punishable than DS3/ER's roll spam that was extremely hard to punish, and playing footsies was a lot more fun than DS3/ER. Better yet was the turning ability of each weapon type that gave more nuance than "in range = can hit". Katanas were extremely powerful at trading, but its poor turn ability meant that it was very easy to roll past a person and counter with a rolling attack. Spears dont perform similarly (or even better) than straight swords because you had range, but you had no turning ability. If a straight sword user got close to you, it was very easy for them to roll behind you and attack because you couldnt turn very well while attacking. Compare this to the current ER spear meta where spears perform better because they turn infinitely well, and stabbing attacks had lingering hitboxes vs sweeping attacks. I had the most fun in DS2 PvP because it felt the most nuanced among the rest.

snippet.textDisplay: I played all the souls born games except DS2, so having run out of all the rest, I finally gave it a chance recently.  Getting used to the controls was tricky in the beginning, I dunno why but it feels really stiff compared to all the other games, but once getting used to that, it feels okay now.  But then I somehow missed the super duper important NPC that lets you level up and ran around beating the first 3 bosses with no way to spend my over 25,000 souls at level 1, with a dagger and 1 spell... that was frustrating.  But now that I've got that all sorted out, I can say that I'm coming around.  This game is fun.  And if you are looking for more dark souls, after exhausting all the better ones, this is still a viable option.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 Scholar of the First Sin was the first souls game I ever played, and I never finished it because I had a pirated copy (I was poor) and lost my save, due to forgetting to back up the %appdata% folder during a format, after probably getting through more than half the game.. 

Years later I played Elden Ring on release and it blew my mind, so then I went and played Demon's Souls Remake, and then Dark Souls 3 (still need to play the DLC). I am a gamer of many genres, and I grew up mainly on PC FPS and adventure games as a kid in the 90's, then later platformers and many others (my fave game of all time is Half-Life 2).

I LOVE Souls games and consider them up there with the best games ever made, and I can't wait to go back and replay Dark Souls 2 even if, as a seasoned Souls player now, I find it not as amazing as the others.

snippet.textDisplay: In my experience people who played DS2 as their first souls game tend to enjoy much more...I don't think people realize how much bad reviews can influence peoples opinions about game...I love all 3 Dark Souls games, because honestly they are all completely different from each other! snippet.textDisplay: It sucks. Just admit it. I like it. At the time, I loved it. But honestly. Game sucks. You can talk about how much detail was put in, and there was, but too many major issues were missed. All I can ever think about is going up an elevator through the top of a windmill and coming out in a lava valley. All I can think about is the final walk to the final boss room being a giant gray tunnel with the same texture copy pasted over and over. The DLCs were bad. Scholar was even worse and compounded all of the original game's issues to the point of being unplayable. Just ugh.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think DS2 would have been so much better received if they just didn’t call it Dark Souls 2. Like, if Fromsoft released Demons Souls, then Dark Souls, then… Giants Souls? (Idk, just any name like that for DS2), then Bloodborne, then DS3 as “Dark Souls 2”, then we’d have been talking about Giants Souls (or whatever) as “its own thing” all along and the discourse would years ago have been where it is now. Granted, I think it’s pretty common now to view DS2 as “its own thing” (discrete from DS1 and 3) but it took a long time to get here because on release it was so far from what most people expected or wanted when a sequel to Dark Souls was announced. It seems so clear to me that all the references to DS1 were shoehorned in and even though I still don’t think it would be seen as one of the best entries, imo it never would have been relegated to just “the worst,” as it was for quite awhile by what I’d argue was a sizable majority of the fanbase.

Basically I think Bamco chose to cash in by shoehorning gratuitous Dark Souls miscellanea into what seems to me to have been a pretty discrete game, to make it the formal sequel to its big cash cow instead of letting it stand on its own and marketing it as more of a “spiritual successor.” So they financially benefited in the short term but I think damaged the legacy of the game in the long term by pitching it as something that would fill a demand that (imo) it was never intended to.

snippet.textDisplay:
Whilst I have put in around 250+ hours into this game (split between vanilla & SOTFS) I do think it is the weakest in the series at is rated poorly for all the right reasons. 
Objectively it is the worst in the series for a number of reasons however I do find myself coming back to it, I can't quite put my finger on why. Probably similar to the other games in the series, as I have played so much of them another playthrough always feels good to reuse what I have learned. 
It is for sure the most experimental game in the series! Bonfire Ascetics are an interesting one, I think the only time I use them is above Medusa to get silver serpant+2 but still, good for challenge!
The new mob placements and Freia encounter in NG+ is great, caught me fully off guard my first time through. I fully agree they should have pushed this idea further instead of simply new mobs for difficulty sake.
I absolutely loved the Pursuer. They could have cleaned up some of his arenas but a great idea that fits his theme for sure. 
I would disagree though that "all the bosses have a unique design to them" as this game uses a lot of reskins for bosses. 
The game feels like it was built from creating individual areas/set pieces first then placing them together second as the overall world design is very poor imo. Some of the specific areas were fantastically set up and fun to navigate however! The world does not feel like it fits together, i imagine this was as a result of bonfire warping from the get go.
A fair synopsis of the story! It is the weakest imo, but I appreciate this is most likely due to it being a self contained kingdom and not the world of life and death as a whole so just feels less impactful. 
So glad you touched on life gems! They are game breaking for sure. And the focus on consumables was great, its what made me want to try different playstyles most.
ADP and animation timing are for sure awful however I don't believe the hitboxes can be blamed on ADP - the hitboxes at high Agility are still poor. 

Man this was longer than I intended, apologies! All in, this was actually a fantastically balanced discussion of the game (which is rarer, most videos seem to go in hard on liking or hating) and well put together! ✌

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually don't like Dark Souls 2 on an entirely other level than it being good or bad, I just don't enjoy playing it. Dark Souls 2 was my first souls game: 
I wanted to try it out and play it because Dark Souls 3 was right around the corner. Then after what was somewhere around 15 hours I stopped and I came to the conclusion that souls game just weren't made for me.
If one of my friends at the time wouldn't have told me that I should try out Dark Souls 3 anyway I would have never touched another souls-like game again and I wouldn't have gotten the hundreds of hours of enjoyment I did get out of them.
I did give Dark Souls 2 at least 2 other tries but at a total of 36 hours of playtime I concluded that I can't enjoy this game. I have played many games that are worse and many games that are jankier in a lot of ways, but Dark Souls 2 is probably the game that I can't finish without being forced to.

snippet.textDisplay:
i hate how the DS2 discourse in the DS community is either you love DS2 or you hate it, no inbetweens. i like DS2 for very different reasons, its story and themes, the pace of the gameplay, the builds you can quickly create and have fun, there's a lot to like that isn't in the other souls games, and its my most replayed souls game out of the trilogy. but i can also recognize that the game has issues and some really dumb design decisions, like tying iframes to agility is just stupid, and the base game bosses are incredibly easy in my opinion having done an SL1 melee only run.

but trying to take this centrist approach will only give you shit from both sides. people will relentlessly defend ADP/Agility tied to iframes and the existence of horsefuck valley, and then on the other side you'll have people flaming you for simply citing something positive about DS2. you can't win with having any opinion on this game.

snippet.textDisplay: I really liked the story and concept of helplessness of trying to break the cycle, but that I'm afraid is almost the extent of what I really liked about it. The areas ranged from forgettable to frustratingly cheap. Enemies where in large part places in such a way to maximize the death toll on the player relying on gank squads, or enemies with the weirdest hit boxes. The bosses though was a even worse example of multi boss spam or bs hitboxes. What makes that frustrating is there where some absolute gems of bosses in DS2 like fume knight, alonne, Nashandra, and the ivory king. The game potential was there was just no way they couldn't have known that the cheap level design and cheese Lords of bosses was a artificial difficulty spike imo.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 is a good game, it might be the "worst" of the series, but its still a solid 8 out of 10, its just the other games are 9s and 10s. The level design is really good, Majula being my favorite hub area in all souls games, I love the different spells and armor sets, and the DLCs are awesome.

I hate it tho hahaha I really do. Animations feels clunky, graphics looks like a downgrade from DS1, I fking hate estus taking forever to use and heal, and I will never EVER forgive adaptability. These things take away from the fun so much for me that I simply can''t enjoy the game. If this game ever gets a remake I hope they change these things.

snippet.textDisplay: I love Dark Souls 2. In some ways, I think it's the best in the series. It is the only one of the 3 games that actually made me dread walking into a new area. It did amazing stuff for the lore, opening up the concepts from 1 and creating a ton of possibilities. Also, the nonsensical world design created some incredible surprises. I'll never forget Majula, or coming out of the elevator into the view of the Dragon Aerie.

snippet.textDisplay:
ok first things first, I LIKE DS2, I think is great and to date is the one I had the most characters and beat most times.

one point that no one seems to talk about when apreciating dark souls 2 is that it had the most variety in pvp viable builds, to me ds2 had the best pvp of all the souls game to date, because the changes to combat and animations make really hard to get a build to be truly broken in the first place.

another point no one seems to mention, is that ds2 had the best covenants.

ds2 is good, and let me put it like this, people compare ds1 and ds3 all the time, but the best things that make ds3 beeing such an improvement over ds1, are things taken from ds2

snippet.textDisplay:
While I respect the fact that you enjoy DS2 so much, I find many of the points you are making quite contentious. Now, if you allow me, I want to do a break down of your video. Alright, shall we? Here we go:

-) First, the intro:

You open up by broadcasting your bias towards the game. Nothing wrong with that, but puts your honesty into question. Next you mention people avoiding the game because of the hate. Who is "people" exactly? The consensus is that the majority of the Soulsborne community derides the game because it was such a catastrophic departure from the formula of Dark Souls.

Then you mention how you are going to talk about the positives, and some of the negatives. Why just some? Why not all of them? There is a metric ton of objective criticism leveled at the game. 

Finally, you close by saying that this is your opinion and people should make their own, and then you encourage them to go play the game. Let me be clear: This is manipulative. If you are going to encourage people to make their own opinions, at the very least you should point them to videos that are critical of the game in order to balance the defense you are about to make.

-) Now, unto Game's Mechanics:

You mention Bonfire Ascetics and how NG+ is handled. I agree, both are net positives for the game.

Next is enemy placement feeling off. It is not off, it is sloppy and shit. You fail to mention the instances of enemies being placed in the world without rhyme or reason; you fail to mention the ad nauseam instances of spambush; you fail to mention the number of times enemies are placed in positions that will nearly guarantee you will take damage if not outright kill you.

You continue by bringing up the bosses and while you acknowledge that some are not good, some might be hits. Except you don't specify which ones are which. Lucky for everyone I can do it now:

GOOD: the Pursuer, Looking Glass Knight, Flexile Sentry, Lost Sinner, Ruin Sentinels, Mytha the Baneful Queen, Smelter Demon, Veldstat, and Darklurker.
MEDIOCRE: Executioner's Chariot, The Last Giant, The Rotten, Old Dragonslayer, Scorpioness Najka, Old Iron King, Giant Lord, Vendrick, and Ancient Dragon.
SHIT: The Skeleton Lords, The Belfry Gargoyles, Royal Rat Vanguard, Royal Rat Authority, Duke's Dear Freja, Covetous Demon, Guardian Dragon, Demon of Song, Dragonrider, Twin Dragonriders, Prowling Magus and the Congregation, Throne Watcher and Defender, Nashandra, and Aldia.

Then you make this strange point, as if it is a positive, that the bosses aesthetically fit the areas they are in. Are you implying that DS1 bosses didn't match aesthetically their own arenas? Because I find that to be a bizarre point to make.

-) Next you move unto the world's design:

You state that the areas are aesthetically pleasing. Yes they are. But once again, you omit important information such as the many areas are ugly at the technical level with textures that are missing, flat, or washed out. Another thing you fail to mention is how BORING the world is in its layout. Where Dark Souls set the gold standard for world design, DS2 made this central hub with branches that stretch in a specific direction with zero interconnectivity, and all end on a dead end. You don't that some areas are so poorly designed that they overlap unto each other, but the player never sees it because they override each other when loaded unto the game (Aldea's keep for those interested). How about a volcano at the top of a tower, that stands alone in a poison ridden swamp?

-) Next you move unto story:

I am not messing with this one, because oh boy, that is a whole thesis unto its own.

-) Extras:

First, you mention lifegems, and you deviate into an opinion. So let me argue objectively: Lifegems break the game. There is no if or buts about it. Not only they are a powerful healing system that will keep you alive through most damage sources (except spambushes), but they are so abundant and cheap, that unless you utterly suck at the game, you will have 99 lifegems before the 5th hour mark. And likely will have over a hundred healing items by the end of your first run through the game. And they are not a "back up option" they are a full on replacement for the Estus.

Next you mention that there are other negatives to the game, but you won't mention them. Why not? What is exactly stopping you from doing it? Don't you think that that is important information that you should make available to your subscribers, and viewers? Now, I appreciate that you are honest about ADP and animations, but I disagree that the janky hitboxes are somehow tied to ADP. The janky hitboxes are one of the many technical issues that the game has.

And then, there is this: "none of the negatives matter if you actually like the game". This fucking line, and all the ones that follow are some of the most atrocious logic I ever heard in my life. You should never EVER excuse bad/lazy/incompetent design just because you like something. Because if we do that, then there is no point to having discussions about quality. By your logic then FIFA and NBA, and gatcha games, lootboxes, MTX and all other predatory forms of monetizing in a game are okay, because hey its just a negative you can understand and embrace in order to see the good in the game. You wanna love the game, love it all you want. But don't fucking ever excuse nonsense.

This is your logic: "Hey I got molested at summer camp, but now I know how to canoe, alright!" -- Dave Attell.

For anyone curious, DS2 got a lot of DESERVED hate for many things, including: janky hitboxes, ADP, overabundance of upgrade materials, unbalanced invasions, broken AI, lifegems, hack n' slash elements, overabundance of leveling points, idiotic contraptions, poorly designed world, terribly designed bosses, bloat of key type items, human effigies, adding obtuse problems and solutions to negate them, broken backstab, broken plunging attack, broken animations, broken sound, broken music, all of Scholar of the First Sin, broken netcode, broken PVP, replacing 360 movement with 8 directional snap points, broken jumping, broken falling, enemies instantaneously switching weapons, spambushes, excessive number of ambushes, downgraded graphic quality, unfinished systems, broken repair system, padded DLC, so on and on and on and on.

Finally, for those wishing to delve deeper into the mess that DS2 is, I recommend you to watch HBombnerGuy's In Defense of Dark Souls 2, MauLer's A Response to In Defense of Dark Souls 2, Joseph Anderson's critique of DS2, and finally Matthew Mattosis' review of DS2.

As for you, Parker, I understand what you are trying to do. And I empathize. I love the Dark Souls series, and I actually enjoy Dark Souls 2 a lot. But the way you went about it to defend it, its no bueno. If you want to defend the game, you need to put your bias aside and let your viewers know why the Soulsborne community was so critical of DS2. And THEN  you make a case for why the game should be considered. You missed mentioning that DS2 has the largest pool of weapons, encouraging all sorts of cool builds, or that the overabundance of levels and upgrade materials allows for experimentation like none of the other games (outside of Elden Ring). The magic system in DS2 is far more robust than Demon Souls, DS1, and even DS3. It as a more stable PVP (arguably).

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 suffers because it released at the end of a generation- and feels like it. Compared to Bloodborne coming out a few months later, it looks bad. The levels feel hurried. 

It *is* a great game with an awkward development timeline. I feel like it should have just been pushed to the next generation with better graphics and a bit more polish.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark souls 2 is a perfectly good game. It is, however, a very loose cop out of a direct sequel to Dark Souls1. It’s like if someone took over DMing a campaign and completely disregarded the places and characters established in the first. Even with the passage of time vibe that it tries to set in, DS3 made the correct choice of mentioning the older players and characters from 1. Which makes it feel more faithful as a sequel.
DS2 could very well be an Elden Ring Sequel given its own logic

snippet.textDisplay:
Hands down, I’ve played DS2 most among all games. It’s more controversial and reviled mechanics are: SM (soul memory), Agl (agility, oft referred to as ADP/Adaptability- the iframe stat), numerous bonfires and bosses, despawning mobs, lose max hp after a death, get invaded while hollow, directional aiming with big weapons, lifegem hoarding, too many enemies, and unconnected map. 

I’ve discussed every complaint, so many times, and have rationales for each that have changed more than a few minds. The most important thing to keep in mind is that DS2 is a multiplayer game. PvE is trumped by making the game work for PvP.

1. Soul Memory: conceptually, eliminates twinks from invading low level, and destroying with a bevy of maxed gear. Also, some players like that there’s a permanent consequence for losing bloodstains; your build gets watered down, so be careful. This example highlights why lifegem hoarding is detrimental. Your SM will increase, with no benefit to your build. PvP will be harder, as you meet players who only invest souls in stats and the gear they use. 

2. Agility (commonly referred to as ADP). As noted with SM, your “build” includes every soul, whether lost or spent. Iframes are extremely desirable, so NO ONE should get them for free. You want, you pay. There’s a skill to knowing if your opponent has invested many souls in getting them, lending interest to fights, as an opponent’s number of iframes is not so black and white. Main point, tho, is every build must invest to get them, and your SM reflects that. 

3. Numerous bosses & bonfires. This is simply to keep Bonfire Ascetics power in check. If they respawned vast areas, they would be too OP. Smaller areas associated with each bonfire are required. And more bosses are there to “fight” you for increasing the bonfire’s intensity. Though there are some bonfires that can be asceticked without needing to fight a boss. 

4. Despawning mobs. Basically preventing noobs from unintentionally jacking up their SM, and no longer able to find area-appropriate co-op. Prevents skilled players from farming items without any difficulties. RatBros won’t have an infinite army versus greys. 

5. Lose max hp after death. Basically a throw-back to Demons Souls. But less harsh. Instead of losing 50% after one death, lose 5%/death, up to 50%. Some people like the challenge, others don’t, but it’s a more player friendly version of a pervious mechanic. Love it or hate it. 

6. Get invaded while hollow: the price you pay for being able to go human anywhere, at any time. Multiplayer can be blocked, by burning an effigy at a bonfire. Precious though they may be, the small white soapstone can get you back human in less than 10 minutes. Using the multiplayer helps with effigy availability. 

7. Directional aiming: big weapons swing the direction your stick is held. Not towards lock on. This takes time to adjust to. But it helps big weapons to catch backstab fishing in PvP. Not particularly friendly for PvE. 

8. Lifegem (especially hoarding.) See #1 SM. Also, lifegems give the player a choice between big fast chug but immobile, or stay mobile, but get a small slow regen. If you buy 99, then complain that you can buy 99, Imma shake my head. 

9. Too many enemies: valid. Buy Vanilla DS2. You’re welcome. So different from Scholar, it’s like a new game. Easiest enemy placement, but much harder item placement.

10. Unconnected map. It’s hard to follow DS1, who’s initial area is a masterpiece. But DS1 also gets the rose colored glasses treatment, and the whole game is praised for its interconnectivity. DS2 is basically Demons Souls, where it has spokes coming off a hub. But DS2 connects the spokes organically, instead of Demons “level selector” hub. DS2 does interconnected zones, like Lost Bastille. Huge interconnected areas. 

I hope I’ve given some food for thought. Hopefully, righted a poor opinion about something into a positive.

snippet.textDisplay:
All I’m going to say is that true DS2 haters have never been able to perform no death/no bonfire runs. And those 2 guys that did and still didn’t enjoy DS2 are sheeple who got carried by guides.

What I’m saying about this challenge in particular is THAT THE GAME WAS DESIGNED TO SOME EXTEND TO ALLOW IT TO BE POSSIBLE!

No other game has this insane “mastery challenge” outside of personal skill testing.

And I’m amazed at how natural DS2 feels! Usually for me, I have to master attack patterns and animations to truly master a boss inside and out (kinda of a requirement for everyone seeking mastery).

But DS2 movement feels super natural, like if enemies are kids swinging swords, you can tell when they are winding up and when they start the slash.

I never paid close attention to Veldstat yet I’ve beaten him hitless countless times because his swings are so cool to react to!

snippet.textDisplay:
I also thought this way, cause DS2 is my first DS. But after replaying it after some years - all illusions fell off. DS2 is ok game when you treat it as some kind of fanfiction on dark souls game or spinoff.

Pros:
* Majula (and music!)
* Characters
* Dual wielding
* Proper backstab/critical hit animations
* Great magic schools separation - max faith for miracles, max int for sorceries, min both for pyromancy, max both for dark.
* Some of the vibe'est locations, stories and enemies. Remember scythe dudes, sitting on pillars in unded hunting grounds? Or girls singing for the dead bodies? yeah
* Bonfire systems and leveling up a zone to transfer it to NG+.

Cons:
* Horrible zone-cohersion
* Horrible and chotic placement of magic spells. No logic, no proper progression like in DS1.
* Horrible graphical downgrade
* Horrible enemies placement in SOTFS
*

I LOVE the slow combat pace of DS2. 
I also love the agility stat (raised by adaptability and attunement) - cool idea, if you ask me. 
There are hardly any games I enjoyed as much as DS2. The aesthetics, the soundtrack, that special kind of spooky athmosphere, the controls and gameplay (way better than DS1!!), the always fair difficulty,... Simply loving it. More than I will ever be able to love it's predecessor. <3 
Nice video. 
Many spoilers, hola hola.

snippet.textDisplay: DS2 is still prob my favorite overall Fromsoft game.. I loved DS1 but everything clicked for me with DS2. I played from launch, the multiplayer was incredible and it was fun to do repeat playthroughs with varying builds. NG+ was also different enough to be worth it. The DLCs were solid and added a lot of solid, difficult content. Ranks in my top games of all time for sure.

snippet.textDisplay:
I still don't get the Adaptablity backlash at all. 

Isn't it usually the case that if you want to be good at something in an RPG you have to put points into it? If you don't invest in it, you just have to dodge AWAY from attacks or be a good shield user/tank. Having a nimble character that can dodge through devastating attacks is something you have to work towards. And even then, if your timing is good, you can still evade attacks all the time with low ADP. 

There was a reason DS2 also created a stat exclusively for Equip Load, which was tied to a stat EVERYONE built in DS1 because it also raised your stamina. The Attributes are just more balanced than in the first game, and every time I go back to DS1, I'm wishing it was there from the beginning.

snippet.textDisplay:
I dislike this game because of how it feels when attacking and engaging with enemies, it's either frustrating or completely uninteresting. It has possibly the worst healing system in the series, I think the levels/areas suck, I think the Bosses are awful, I think the music is mostly terrible, and this is all excluding the countless nitpicks I have. 

It's one thing to have a hundred issues with a game, all games have plenty of issues, nothing is perfect. But what I dislike more than anything about DS2 is that it offers nothing new that's significant enough to warrant revisiting; unlike the other From Software titles, with DS3 being maybe an exception.

snippet.textDisplay: The one other negative that I've found during my genocide run, is that some enemies have attacks that, literally, have no wind up, no tells. Just BAM you've been hit. (Looking at you, hiede knights) add that to the love of chain aggro, adaptability and the slow animation timing, and it all comes together in a package that *feels* like they couldn't figure out how to make it difficult without cheating or going for cheap shots. There is a lot to love about DS2 in the greater world building, majula is absolutely beautiful and haunting. I don't even have an issue with life gems, they balance well with how estus was handled. It's the moment to moment gameplay that makes playing through an absolute slog.

Dark Souls 2 was the last one I played. DS1 -> DS3 -> tested Bloodbourne and Sekiro but skipped both -> then DS2. It was fantastic and really liked this massive landscape to explore.

However, what bugged me the most:
The controls are kinda sticky. It's not really 360 degree movement as the controls kinda snap which makes some movements difficult.
Also some locations were weirdly connected. Like going up an elevator in a windmill and you end up in a lava location.

However, if there HOPEFULLY will be a DS Trilogy, they'll hopefully get rid of all these problems and make this game such a fantastic expierence!

snippet.textDisplay: The "slowness" of DS2, you describe as a drawback, is actually one of the point I think it is one great game. snippet.textDisplay:
When I started the souls series, I decided to skip 2 because of all the negative things I heard about it. I played 1, played 3 and then replayed 1 a dozen or so times until I got curious enough to actually give 2 a go...

And by GOD, is 2 my absolute favorite souls game (hell, it's one of my favorite games in general). I genuinely love (almost) everything about it!

From the story to the atmosphere to the bosses, I love it all! Hell, my absolute favorite thing about this game is the goddamn torch mechanic (which is why I like the gutter so much).

I went in as a dark souls 2 hater, didn't like that I had to spend the first hour of my playthrough doing the controls (which I eventually made just like DS1, outside of the jump and the back button), but loved everything after that.

snippet.textDisplay: I miss those old days when it was new. All the crazy 1v1 PvP, chasing each other across the map. Most fun invasions I've ever had. It didn't feel like someone was just coming into the world to annoy me, but they instead felt like an integrated challenge of the world itself. I expected it. They literally became a boss I had to overcome to proceed. All that came to a thematic peak when I actually had an invader smash through the mirror shield during the Mirror Knight battle! I did not know that could even happen and it had to be the coolest thing I had ever fucking seen in a game. I about lost it. XD I had two phantoms with me at the time, so it was the Boss + Invader against the three of us. You just can't find that kind of experience anywhere else.

snippet.textDisplay: I started a playthrough of ds2 a couple of days ago, my mistake is that chose sotfs, for anyone that wants to give ds2 a chance I suggest you play the original and not sotfs, all that does is putting a lot more enemies in every area, and making the path to the boss if you die a pain. I did not play the original ds2 so I don't know if it has the same problems but, the lock on system is making no sense switching targets in the middle of a combat and some times targeting a random enemy that is not even in your reach, the dodge-roll is massed up because you are not invincible for the whole animation and only a third of it making you take damage while rolling. If you don't own a controller you are gonna have some problems on mouse&keyboard but whit some rebinds is actually playable. Sometimes the game has input lag and makes the gameplay feel clunky. If you get used to those problems, the game is not that bad. (be prepared for a lot of dark spirit invasions)

snippet.textDisplay:
I tried playing DS2 when it first came out after having never played a Souls-like before. I never even found the tutorial area, because I didn't realize the house had another door. I just died trying to get past the troll thing until my life bar was stuck at half and then ran past him to the town where I was instantly killed by three tiny piglets. I didn't touch a game from the series until just this year. Dark Souls 1, by comparison, was like playing with training wheels at least until I decided to force my way through the catacombs first, but at least then I always knew I had an alternative path if I wanted to give it up.

After finishing DS1, I thought I'd give DS2 another go. Nope. Still terrible. It looked worse. It played worse. Even WITH the tutorial the game just isn't fun. I thought the point of this series was that you were supposed to have the freedom to experiment, but it seems if you don't build a character a specific way and use certain weapons, you have no chance. Obviously that's not true for people who have already mastered the game and can do no hit runs and stuff. But for a first time player, it really sucks being constantly punished for wanting to experiment with different stats and weapons because you don't know what you like yet.

snippet.textDisplay: Being a giant fan of pretty much everything FromSoft makes, it took me a while to finally sit down and give DS2 a chance, having heard so many people diss on it and such. Only after years of playing everything else they made and looking to scratch that itch again but with something fresh I stumbled upon a number of videos dotting on 2 and it really piqued my interest after getting some better information on the game itself I broke down and purchased the Scholar of the First Sin edition for the PS4. Needless to say I fell in love with it immediately, the atmosphere, level design, characters, surreal world building, the story almost everything except a few hiccups along the way that I easily brushed off since I was so engrossed with everything else the game had to offer. I can understand why some people would find it not for them, but many of those people go out of their way to make sure other people don't even try it, which is absolutely bs. If you don't like the game that's fine you didn't vibe with it, but don't try to undermine those that like it or especially might want to try it. I lost out on years of enjoyment for this game because I took the word of someone that may not even enjoy the games for the same reasons I do

snippet.textDisplay:
Played all of the SoulsBorne games last year. DS2 was really fun even if I had a lot of issues with it lol.

Also I like the idea that the game actually has 3 endings. The first two are combined in a sort of Schrödinger’s box type deal with how the throne is shaped like a kiln and closes you inside. At that point, the player character embodies both endings from DS1 as they technically can choose one of the other- we’ll just never see it. This ending continues the cycle light and dark. 

The third ending then sees to it that the player character exits the cycle altogether. They are still undead, but with the DLC crowns, they no longer have to worry about the effects of the curse. They have escaped the cycle. I like to think this is the true ending because it means that even though Vendrick couldn’t protect his kingdom or himself, in the end he was still able to find a way for someone to live outside of the cycle.
snippet.textOriginal:
Played all of the SoulsBorne games last year. DS2 was really fun even if I had a lot of issues with it lol.

Also I like the idea that the game actually has 3 endings. The first two are combined in a sort of Schrödinger’s box type deal with how the throne is shaped like a kiln and closes you inside. At that point, the player character embodies both endings from DS1 as they technically can choose one of the other- we’ll just never see it. This ending continues the cycle light and dark. 

The third ending then sees to it that the player character exits the cycle altogether. They are still undead, but with the DLC crowns, they no longer have to worry about the effects of the curse. They have escaped the cycle. I like to think this is the true ending because it means that even though Vendrick couldn’t protect his kingdom or himself, in the end he was still able to find a way for someone to live outside of the cycle.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am a huge soul fan from the beginning. I love them all. But, DS2 has two major issues that mechanically make it inferior to the other games. Those are agility and soul memory. Agility affecting your invulnerability frames means that the enemy animations and boss fights cannot be choregraphed and timed for all players. If you do not level agility, then you are going to get snared by enemy attacks later in the game. If your agility is too high, than dodging makes fights easy. 

Likewise, soul memory is a terrible mechanic. Soul memory not only makes pvp and co-op harder to do, but there is no reason to not keep leveling in DS2. You may as well max out your stats. The longer someone plays on the same character, every time they loose souls or buy anything other than stats with souls you are loosing an end game arms race where all characters are eventually going to have 99 in every stat. So there is no point to builds and playstyles around a community at a certain soul level.
snippet.textOriginal:

Agility affecting your invulnerability frames means that the enemy animations and boss fights cannot be choregraphed and timed for all players. If you do not level agility, then you are going to get snared by enemy attacks later in the game. If your agility is too high, than dodging makes fights easy. 

Likewise, soul memory is a terrible mechanic. Soul memory not only makes pvp and co-op harder to do, but there is no reason to not keep leveling in DS2. You may as well max out your stats. The longer someone plays on the same character, every time they loose souls or buy anything other than stats with souls you are loosing an end game arms race where all characters are eventually going to have 99 in every stat. So there is no point to builds and playstyles around a community at a certain soul level.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's like a time loop we're in.
First, there were videos praising it. Then there was Matthew, and everyone realized that actually it's not that good. Then people started defending it again, because actually it's not that bad. Then people started shitting all over because no, actually it's still bad. And now we're back at the part where people are defending the game, because actually there are still good parts.
I admit, I haven't watched the video yet, but the loop this discussion is going through is just fascinating. I personally really like the aesthetics of the game: Majula is the best hub area of them all, and in general the world feels a lot brighter and warmer in this game. It's also the last part in the series where the combat was still slow. Janky as it is, I prefer that combat to the dodge spam of DS3.

As someone who doesn't care which Souls game is the best and just wants to have fun with these games I can tell you the replayability:

Worst: Dark Souls 1 (max. 2 times) and 3 (max. 2) , Demon Souls (max. 2)

Best: Bloodborne (LOADS), Dark Souls 2 (less LOADS), Sekiro (same as DS2, because it's fast, not as good as the other ones in terms of replayability but surprisingly more fun than playing DS3 over and over again.)

Elden Ring I'd say is in between. It's better than DS3 and 1. I'm on my 2nd playthrough with Strength instead of Magic/Faith and Dex. Maybe I won't do a 3rd but it's overall more fun than DS3 definitely.

Yeah I played it and it was okay. But over all I hate it. Like holyfuck I really hate it. And with how wonky parrying is I just gave up on it and just used a great shield all the time, waited for an enemy to attack and then circle around and back stab them

Oh also the duo pursuer encounter was utter cancer. Had to glitch the fucking game just to finally kill them. Cause no matter what I did I never could kill them. And that’s pretty bad game design to me. Wouldn’t say I’m an amazing dark souls player I’m maybe above average but still no matter what I tried I could never kill them when they’re both in the same room. 

Even tried a strategy where I poisoned one of them with ricards rapier (infused with poison) and then tried waiting out the poison and just repeat that. They’d eventually manage to kill me everytime. Usually with that stab attack. I’d jump out of it and somehow get caught in it anyway. And as that pursuer threw me to the floor, the other one would whack me with his sword on my way down and I’d die before I could even defend myself.

 So the fact I have to use a glitch to win that fight just shows how bullshit it is. Like this whole game just feels like the bed of chaos from start to finish

snippet.textDisplay:
I love the story of Dark Souls 2, far far more than that of Dark Souls 3. Dark Souls 2 allows the player to kind of be a detective, piecing together the distant past. Dark Souls 2 feels like millennia have past since Dark Souls 1, or even more. There are no recurring characters, at least not in the sense of it being the same person (save for Old Dragonslayer, possibly,) no recurring locations, only familiar feelings. Dark Souls 3 feels like a generic sequel in comparison. It feels like it takes place maybe a few hundred years after DS1, and doesn't have as strong a mystery as DS2, at least until the Ringed City DLC. 

Also I like the slow combat of DS2. I enjoy that it feels kind of like a turn based game, and how it allows for very clever setups and tactics. R1 spam is a lot harder in DS2 and I greatly appreciate that.

snippet.textDisplay:
Handful of things I'd like to comment on. First, don't ever feel bad for liking something. You can like something and it still be of bad quality, but that doesn't say anything about you personally. If you have fun playing the game, then it doesn't really matter what others think of it, you are having fun. Toward the end of the video you say you embrace the flaws, and I don't think we should be embracing them but rather understand them. I think no matter how much we adore something, it's important to discuss the issues in detail so that we can understand how and why they occured. That way an even better product can be created next time around.

Next thing is New Game Plus. I both agree and disagree with you here. In terms of adding in or changing enemies and content for new game, I absolutely think thats a fantastic idea...In concept. However, DS2 already has an issue in regards to spam, and the game is flooded with enemies as is. New Game Plus adds more enemies ontop of what already was problematic simply exasperating the issue. You even show in your video how you were swarmed by enemies which was made worse by faulty AI causing them to chase you across the map. Conceptually, I really like the idea of changing up the enemies you fight, but it is unfortunately not handled well in the game. 

Moving onto the discussion about Bosses. When talking about the Pursuer, you mention his grab allowing him to cast new abilities if he pulls it off. This is something I think is pretty interesting as well, however in that same clip you also show off something really strange. When he does his grab attack, you may notice that your character is hit by the blade but then is jarringly moved to the blades end point. This might be considered a nitpick as you were hit regardless so its kind of just a weird visual. But that actually happens quite a bit with grab attacks in the game. The game often moves your character to be in place for the grab attack due to the god awful hit boxes in the game. This is something important to note because despite many bosses being fantastic, like Alonne, the wonky hit box issue will often create frustration and or confusion. You do mention hit boxes later in relation to ADP, but its unfortunately a separate issue that appears quite often. 

Then you start to praise the boss design because they fit their environments. Which is find to be an extremely strange thing to praise. This is something I would expect to be a standard, not out of the ordinary. It would be a hell of a lot stranger if they didn't fit their environments. The twisted firey bosses go in the firey area, the well kept knights go in a castle. It would be hilarious if the Demon of Song(A frog) was in Iron keep.

I also agree that one of the biggest things to praise about DS2 are the visuals. Some areas, like those you showcased, can be stunning. I am still very partial to Medjula, It's my favorite hub area in any of the souls games. However, you also praise the game for how it presents its areas, saying you often get a distant view of where you are headed. And this is also something I find to be strange to praise. You get to see where you go at the back of the area, this happens in lots of games. The reason this is often praised in Souls games is because its usually not the area you are currently in but future areas. In DS1, you can see the walls of Anor Lando AND Blighttown from Firelink Shrine. In DS3 you can see many areas you'll head to from the bridge outside of Vordt. But what exactly is so special about seeing the castle at the back of the Dragon Aerie when you walk into the area? Is it because it looks cool? Fair enough, but again I wouldn't praise the game on its presentation of areas, I'd be praising the game on its visuals. 

Then you speak about Life Gems. This topic is definately one talked about quite heavily. But I feel you describe the issue quite well in why you actually like them. You say they are a great back up option if you run out of Estus, and thats kind of the whole issue to begin with. The point of Estus is to limit the player. You only have a certain amount, and as many often say it symbolizes your allowed amount of mistakes. If you mess up too much then you will run out and eventually die. But Life Gems destroy the whole point of having estus to begin with. Now the player has access to astronomically more healing than they otherwise would. That doesn't mean Life Gems are bad inherently. I think if they worked more like Bloodbornes Blood Vials, and they simply made it the specific way healing worked in the game, it would be fine. Maybe not let the player carry 99 at once, but oh well.  

If you couldn't tell, I disagree with your premise of the video. I think a great video series to watch is from Mauler. He made a reponse to Hbomberguy's DS2 video, and regardless of what you think of bomberguy, Mauler systematically breaks down large portions of the game in immense detail. It's a long watch, but it's quite informative. But just because I disagree with you doesn't mean I dont like the video. I appreciate you putting your thoughts out there, its a fun discussion to have! Keep it up!

If you couldn't tell, I disagree with your premise of the video. I think a great video series to watch is from Mauler. He made a reponse to Hbomberguy's DS2 video, and regardless of what you think of bomberguy, Mauler systematically breaks down large portions of the game in immense detail. It's a long watch, but it's quite informative. But just because I disagree with you doesn't mean I dont like the video. I appreciate you putting your thoughts out there, its a fun discussion to have! Keep it up!

snippet.textDisplay: as someone who recently did a ''kill every PC Soulsborne boss solo - no magic - no ultra broken builds'' i can say that i enjoyed DS2 more than Elden Ring, one of the lowest points of DS2 is the boss desing and challenge, i killed almost every base game boss in less than 5 tries (a lot of them even at first) without knowing anything about them, of course the DLC changed that giving me some of the hardest battles in the series (all of them completely fair in my opinion, Elden Ring failed on that) SOTFS made some areas an absolute hell like the iron keep and like you said, you end up just avoiding everything, this also happens in Elden Ring so i appreciated my running away from enemies experience from DS2. if you play Elden Ring you can see that both games share some low points but Elden Ring is contrasted by some of the highest in the franchise so that's why people loves it (me included). i think everyone can play DS2 and enjoy the game, maybe it's just not as good as DS1 and DS3 but it's far from being a bad game

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 is an objectively good game, far better than most AAA releases. It's not a near/masterpiece like every other FS title since 2009 imo, but people compare it to the other games in From's catalog and most games would crumble under the weight of such comparison.

I think it's a solid 7.5/10. I give Demon's souls a close score honestly, but people understandably get hung up on DS2's differences and flaws rather than what it gets right. The atmosphere and spirit of DS2 is objectively a souls experience and I think DS2 is even a more authentic Souls entry than DS3 because DS2 is brimming with passion and the desire to expand upon it's predecessor, whereas DS3 plays it safe and risks introducing very little.

And all things considered, I can agree that DS2 is understandably the black sheep of this catalog, but where it ranks defines it as an objectively good game, even if it comes in last as all of these games stand far above most game releases imo obviously. 

DS2 7.5/10, DnS 8/10, DS3 8.5/10, ER 8.5/10, DS1 8.5/10, BB 9/10, S 9.5/10, being able to stand among these titles says a lot to someone like me, but hey, that's just my opinion.

Only someone who is truly Maidenless wouldn't try Dark Souls 2 for themselves.

The atmosphere and spirit of DS2 is objectively a souls experience and I think DS2 is even a more authentic Souls entry than DS3 because DS2 is brimming with passion and the desire to expand upon it's predecessor, whereas DS3 plays it safe and risks introducing very little.

And all things considered, I can agree that DS2 is understandably the black sheep of this catalog, but where it ranks defines it as an objectively good game, even if it comes in last as all of these games stand far above most game releases imo obviously. 

DS2 7.5/10, DnS 8/10, DS3 8.5/10, ER 8.5/10, DS1 8.5/10, BB 9/10, S 9.5/10, being able to stand among these titles says a lot to someone like me, but hey, that's just my opinion.

Only someone who is truly Maidenless wouldn't try Dark Souls 2 for themselves.

snippet.textDisplay:
I find Dark Souls 2 to have the strongest "plot" of the trilogy, more directly tied to the tragedy of Vendrik compared to the ambiguous motives of the kings in the other games. 
Its also more directly reflective of the themes that hold the series together than the first and third. 

This is marred sadly by the (clear) broken consequences of the awkward Dev cycle, and some strange Dev decisions.

(Forcing the player to defeat all four bosses or grind a comparable amount, not placing the DLC enterances into the world more organically, the overly plentiful healing reserves,) making the story requiring more reading in to follow.

That said, I hate the critiques of Soul Memory and Adp, ideas I wish would be re-examined overall, because I find they both added more than they hurt.
snippet.textOriginal:
I find Dark Souls 2 to have the strongest "plot" of the trilogy, more directly tied to the tragedy of Vendrik compared to the ambiguous motives of the kings in the other games. 
Its also more directly reflective of the themes that hold the series together than the first and third. 

This is marred sadly by the (clear) broken consequences of the awkward Dev cycle, and some strange Dev decisions.

(Forcing the player to defeat all four bosses or grind a comparable amount, not placing the DLC enterances into the world more organically, the overly plentiful healing reserves,) making the story requiring more reading in to follow.

That said, I hate the critiques of Soul Memory and Adp, ideas I wish would be re-examined overall, because I find they both added more than they hurt.

snippet.textDisplay:
The issue with Dark Souls 2 is that it is called Dark Souls 2. This game really should have been its own standalone title akin to Nioh or Remnant From The Ashes, because otherwise it's going to be scrutinized due to our expectation of souls games. All those positives like one cool item, some fun designed bosses or cool story are simply not enough. The sluggish movement by itself already puts it closer to Lords of The Fallen. It's not an underrated game - It just fails as Dark Souls.

On top of that - I cannot imagine how anyone enjoying Elden Ring's gameplay could ever want to play it unless they're just looking for a completely, not even remotely similar, experience. Which defeats the purpose of that recommendation.

snippet.textDisplay: I do agree that Dark Souls 2 has some neat smaller aspects that are unique to the game, but I’m sorry, I think these videos are usually the same. I think saying Dark souls 2 has some good aspects and Dark Souls 2 is underrated or is better than any of the other games besides maybe Demon Souls is outrageous (my opinion not objectively outrageous), because looking at the game as a whole, most of the bosses suck to fight against, most of the areas suck to explore, the movement and animations are really terrible a lot of the times. It really feels like the game is just bad from the get go, even if worse dark souls is still fun. But aside from the NG+ changes, I think a lot of the compliments you attributed to the game are just done better in the other games with out all the stupid bullshit. Like what you said about the areas getting a distant view before you explore them, I know you mention that the other games do but you still use it as a compliment to the game, but I just think the point it mute when the area your about to explore is going to suck. And stuff like “the bosses all have good explanations or connections” is done better in the other games and it’s my even done very well in 2. I just think the title of this video is wrong, even if dark souls 2 has a few fun mechanics, and does have a few fun bosses and areas, I don’t think most people ever deny that. It’s just that those small aspects don’t make up for the weaknesses of the game. I think Dark Souls 2 is fun, but I think it’s perfectly rated as being significantly less good than the other games

snippet.textDisplay: DS2 was the first Souls game I ever played, and while I can understand some of the criticisms, I still think it's one of, if not my favorite, in the whole series. One thing I don't hear brought up enough is the stance system. I hate that we've never really gotten that back in any game since DS2. The Bonfire Ascetic is a great Item for boosting difficulties with a risk/reward system. The covenants were all pretty fun, my favorite being the rats. The PVP is arguably the best and most balanced in the franchise. And the NPCs and Bosses are among my favorites in the series.

snippet.textDisplay:
It really shouldn't have been called Dark Souls II. 
It is more of a spin off with nods to DS1 than a successor. The games Bloodborne, Sekiro, and Demon's Souls all use some similar mechanics but don't rely on a congruent story through them all.

That said I do still find it a shitty game. I had fun while playing it and it's fine to enjoy it, but let's not pretend the qualities and mechanics which make up the game itself are acceptable. It is a bad game that has good things and highlights to enjoy. Those of you who love the game are okay to do so, I bear no qualm against you for what you like.
However, I will have an issue if you love the game so much as to make it out to be an objectively good Souls game. It isn't. One would need to ignore the bosses that are underwhelming, multiple areas considered to be the worst in the series, mechanics that are horrid, a world that has areas where they shouldn't be, and way too many enemies in certain areas. The game doesn't know what it wants to do, and it can be felt.

I would encourage people to give it a try, there is no harm in playing the game even if it has poor mechanics, just be aware of what you are getting into.

snippet.textDisplay:
Been playing some Scholar for the past week and god it's so fun. I can't help but laugh at the absurdity of having 20 mobs just thrown at me every now and again and beneath all of that it's so enjoyable. Just like the options open to you right from the get-go, how intricate and fun the map designs are, and how goofy some of the enemy designs are. It's hands down my favorite souls game as it encapsulates such a chaotic and cursed nature. That said I-frames are let's just say not forgiving and sometimes *cough* Velstadt *cough* it feels a little bit bull.

I just love this game to much and decided to go on a little tangent on what, in my eyes makes DS2 the most unique and in my personal opinion best souls game ever made (Bloodborne being a close second)

#1 Having a set amount of spells making it a resource. Mana is a cringe and a very "gamey" system whereas the spells being a set amount makes it feel more like you're using scrolls to cast which is very thematic and feels a lot better while being very thematic

#2 The various consumables and how fun they are to use. In literally every other game be it a souls one or not I never use consumables and forget about them, and yet this game makes it somehow fun to use consumables. There is such a huge variety and they are all so incredibly fun to use. I just don't understand why this game makes me so interested in it's consumables, the system is just in a league of its own.

#3 The world layout, I've never felt so free in my vertical and horizontal movement. I truly feel like part of a world in DS2 and it feels like wherever I go I won't just be forced down a set path to reach my destination. 

#4 Scale. Holy does the game feel epic and everything feels so large. I've never had that same feeling with Elden ring or other souls games. Some areas in DS2 are truly ginormous and I especially like that each location feels like a fully fleshed-out location (except the royal rat area of course).

#5 The animations. Some people (this youtuber included) mention animation time as a negative but I've never felt it that way. I've played and completed every single from soft souls like and nothing feels as good to me as DS2 combat. I love the flow of it, the combat dance you do, and the emphasis on spacing as if you're really fighting something. It's the closest representation to real-world combat. It's not some anime where I roll and do a cool move and then roll 4 times like in other souls games. It's a slow, methodical system that forces you to be careful when approaching situations. and the fact that stamina drains so quickly makes the game again feel more grounded in real combat. This also plays into DS2s world being the most grounded one we've seen, with less epic monsters and creatures and more of just dudes in armors, which helps set the tone and really makes seeing the beasts of the world feel all the more special.

#6 Every NPC feels like they matter. I feel like every NPC has a part to play, and I always enjoy finding an NPC no matter who they are. In no other from soft game do I ever have that feeling, they are all unique and bring something special to the game they inhabit. Like it's super hard to pick a favorite. Like come on, what other souls game has a huge scorpion gladiator guy you can do a quest for to have him as a summon against a big scorpion boss (Najka fight) or a big dumb dwarf that'll buy your gear (only way to sell stuff in the game BTW) or just that guy that builds ladders for you for souls. It's all so memorable and fun and I'm all here for it

Oops, I went on a tangent. Well this is possibly one of the games closest and dearest to my heart so I suppose this would happen

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark souls 2 works with open designs! This is clear in even the concept arts. The castles actually look better in game than the highly detailed drawings.
Unfortunately, a lot of Dark Souls 2 is played through boring tight corridors. This is something we've only seen before in Demon's Souls and never again. In typical dark souls 2 fashion, it does some amazing and daring things, but also makes pretty clear mistakes much worse than the rest of the series.
And I think dark souls 2 (ever since Aldia was added) actually has the most interesting story. It's deep. It has a fantastic take on hollowing, it puts chaos in an interesting new light, especially when realising that third path is what Aldia took (flames and branches and talking about rejecting the cycle). It builds phenomenally on the first game, giving a lot of localised intrigue based on the original game, but also giving it a wholly unique over-arching theme that connects well to the original. Maybe it does too much. Shards of manus is just an odd thing, and why does she look like nito? 

I've overcome most issues with dark souls 2, even adp as levels are so cheap anyway so I just level it early and it barely impacts my power curve, but there's only one I just can't get past and that's soul memory. I hate it. I will continue to hate it. I will keep playing and loving dark souls 2, but I'll never stop wishing it wasn't there.

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually loved Dark Souls 2. When I first started playing the Dark Souls games, Dark Souls 3 had just released. I had a hard time getting into them, but I somehow managed to get the furthest into DS2. After taking a year break and then finishing the first game, I played the second one and fell in love with it. Mind you, combat in both the 1st and 3d game are far superior to the one in DS2 (I also did not know what ADP did until about now). What I love about the game is how slow paced he is compared to the other Souls games and therefore is far more relaxing to play when I am farming. I am not one for grinding a lot, but when it comes to it, I love doing it in DS2. Beats playing Destiny 2 trying to get some pointless random loot. 

It is also the story that I am in love with and if I am to interpret it when it comes to the connection to DS1 and DS3, I feel as if it is basically just a standalone but still part of the same universe. I feel the message it tried to convey was what happens during the Age of Dark (when the player chooses the Darkness ending in the 1st game). As the game explains, there have been many kingdoms before Drangleic that have risen and fallen and all those kingdoms represented certain Ages where you had the Age of a glorious kingdom (Age of Fire) and it's fall (Age of Darkness), but the most important thing is, life goes on, the world keeps on going. 
Now this is something they decided to either change/or diverge from (depending how you interpret what is going on) in DS3 with the whole Age of Fire ending. But who are we to tell if people were not just merely freaking out over nothing and were not just prolonging something that ought not to be prolonged?
snippet.textOriginal:
I actually loved Dark Souls 2. When I first started playing the Dark Souls games, Dark Souls 3 had just released. I had a hard time getting into them, but I somehow managed to get the furthest into DS2. After taking a year break and then finishing the first game, I played the second one and fell in love with it. Mind you, combat in both the 1st and 3d game are far superior to the one in DS2 (I also did not know what ADP did until about now). What I love about the game is how slow paced he is compared to the other Souls games and therefore is far more relaxing to play when I am farming. I am not one for grinding a lot, but when it comes to it, I love doing it in DS2. Beats playing Destiny 2 trying to get some pointless random loot. 

It is also the story that I am in love with and if I am to interpret it when it comes to the connection to DS1 and DS3, I feel as if it is basically just a standalone but still part of the same universe. I feel the message it tried to convey was what happens during the Age of Dark (when the player chooses the Darkness ending in the 1st game). As the game explains, there have been many kingdoms before Drangleic that have risen and fallen and all those kingdoms represented certain Ages where you had the Age of a glorious kingdom (Age of Fire) and it's fall (Age of Darkness), but the most important thing is, life goes on, the world keeps on going. 
Now this is something they decided to either change/or diverge from (depending how you interpret what is going on) in DS3 with the whole Age of Fire ending. But who are we to tell if people were not just merely freaking out over nothing and were not just prolonging something that ought not to be prolonged?

snippet.textDisplay: Probably the most controversial thing to say(which I honestly say a lot myself) is that Dark Souls 2 is my favorite of the series (going to get bashed for saying that...) but I have my own personal reasons and a few slight criticisms with the game as well. Reasons why I like Dark Souls 2 the most is because of the infusion mechanic in 2(basically being able to infuse just about any weapon in the game no matter the material requirement for said weapons which Dark Souls 1 didn't even have with twinkling titanite mostly), the backstab and riposte animations are really cool, references to Dark Souls 1 (loved the story in Dark Souls 1 by the way), the addition of adaptability (big one for me because with it I don't mind rolling in 2 but never bothered rolling in any other souls game), optional methods of healing. Now for my crits with the game not being able to set the game to offline play while in game(like in literally every other souls game) because I don't like player invaders and they ruin the experience for me(biggest criticism with the game for me by the way), backstabs and ripostes consumes more stamina, spells from Dark Souls 1 requires almost double the amount of attunement slots in 2. Overall yeah more pros than cons for me and I love the game, have over 800 hours put into just one character alone and that's more than my characters in demon's souls (original on PS3 because people said that the original is better and wanted to try it so bad), Dark Souls 1, 3 and well elden ring but I personally hated elden ring but that's just me. You can definitely see how much I love Dark Souls 2 and I stand by this video, it is a good game just don't believe the haters because believe me when they play Dark Souls 2 they don't wear anything and just rush to the boss and get massacred and blame the game... don't know how many videos I've seen of people doing that in iron keep...

I've played Elden Ring nearly every single day since release but I got back to DS2 a month or two ago and my god. I'm actually surprised to say that DS2 did better immersing the player in its world then Elden Ring did. Elden Ring has some awesome highlights but it feels as though DS2 allows you to explore those highlights while Elden Ring leaves you staring (an exaggeration but it's just how I feel). 
The mechanics for the most part is what holds DS2 back from being a better game, but I can at least remiss and say that the world of DS2 might just be the personification of a "Diamond in the Rough".

snippet.textDisplay: I respect your opinion, but I do not find this game in no way to be "underrated" or "good". This is objectively the worst souls game in the franchise, and there are infinite arguments supporting this claim, from its messy development team changes to its rushed development. The dumb decision to also make this an old gen title was  baffling, coupled with a misunderstanding of Miyazaki's vision of the original Dark Souls  and it's "difficulty", Miyazaki himself has stated that the game was never really about difficulty. So ultimately the devs just had surface level knowledge about the first game and blindly focused on elements that made the game popular rather than what made the game GOOD. the only pros this game possesses are Majula and it's theme, the decently comprehensible story and some bosses (Fume knight, Sin, Alonne).

snippet.textDisplay:
My take on the story is that it can be divided into two parts.  The first part is the themes of the loss of memory and self as you become more and more hollow.  You see this happen in real time with Lucatiel and a few others, but this is also happening to your character as well.  This is why the intro cutscene is so confusing.  It's because your character is themselves confused.  You came to Drangleic to... what?  You don't know.  The Emerald Herald instructs you to Bear Seek Seek Lest, but is that really _your_ goal, or a goal that someone else has imposed upon you?  You never actually find out for sure.

The second part of the story is the story of Vendrick, Aldia, and Nashandra.  Aldia, the Scholar of the First Sin, was trying to find a way to break the undead curse that was created by Gwyn (this is the titular First Sin).  Vendrick was helping him as best he could, and refused to link the fire in the hopes that Aldia would prove successful.  In the end, it was a failure, and Vendrick sealed himself away to prevent Nashandra from reaching the First Flame.  I think Aldia may have been able to break the curse for himself, and Vendrick's blessing if you get all the crowns will also break the curse for you, but they weren't able to break the curse for all humans.

At the end of the game, your choice is to either take the throne and usher in an Age of Fire _or_ Dark, or if you finish Aldia's questline you get the chance to take a third option.

While DS3 does feel like more of a direct sequel to DS1, and DS2 feels like more of a spinoff, the story of DS3 makes a lot more sense with the additional context that DS2 provides.  DS3 is all about Prince Lothric refusing to link the fire, and the Lords of Cinder doing the same, but it's not made clear why.  DS2 was the first game to feature a character refusing to link the fire and explained what the reasons were.  DS3 really highlights that advanced state of decay of the world after linking the fire countless times, validating Vendrick and Aldia's refusal to link the fire and seek an alternate way to end the undead curse.

snippet.textDisplay:
All of the spots you pointed to as problematic really aren't hard unless you make it that way by attempting to run past common enemies. I know in NG+ there's not much motivation to engage with the rif raf, but DS2 made it very clear that attempting to run past enemies is (potentially) doing things the hard way.

Yeah. Different from any other soulsborne game and plenty of people don't like it. But it's not like you weren't warned.

EDIT: And I totally disagree with you about Scholar encouraging players to run past. Running past so frequently (and by design) ends badly.

DS 2 will always have a special place in my heart. Yes, we all know that it isn't "as perfect and fleshed out" like the other titles - both gameplay- and mechanicwise.

But in its defense: DS2 was my first Dark Souls experience with a stable and wide-reaching multiplayer. Some of my closest friends I met in DS2, one of them like a brother to me. I still remember how I randomly was summoned by him for the Last Giant Boss while I was just farming my first 50k of souls in the Forest of the Giants ~ special memories.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't think it is underrated, it is just seen as the worst of the Dark Souls games, which is honestly a spot that it doesn't deserve, but one of the games need to fill the spot. To be perfectly honest, just because it is often seen as the worst, doesn't mean that it is bad. It is perfectly playable and is a pretty good continuation of Dark Souls 1. From my perspective, the B team at From Software was left with in control since Miyazaki went to direct Bloodborne and they decided to be experimental with the game. Some stuff was really good, others were weird like the level design didn't mesh all that well (the elevator at the top of a windmill to inside of a volcano made little sense), which is why it has the reputation it does. The actual area designs were pretty good though. 

I personally loved Aldia's final words to you if you choose the dark ending. "There is no path. Beyond the scope of Light, beyond the reach of Dark... what could possibly await us? And yet, we seek it, insatiably... Such is our fate." 

It is somewhat reminiscent of other games' messaging (Spoiler warning for Final Fantasy 14's patch 3.4 and Destiny 2 Beyond Light campaign)

Ardbert from FF14 patch 3.4 post battle vs the Warriors of Darkness: "Light, Dark, it doesn't matter. What matters is how you choose to use them. We made our choice and you see what came of it. So please... forge a better path. Seize a better fate."



Destiny 2. Your Ghost in post Beyond Light campaign: "I own you an apology. From the start, we were warned not to let our emotions take over. And that was exactly what I did. I got so caught up in worrying how the Darkness would hurt, well us, I didn't realize the damage I was doing. Which is the opposite of what I'm here for. I'm your ghost. Light. Dark. It doesn't matter. We're a team."

I found that Dark Souls 3 to have completely ignored DS2's conclusion to be far more jarring to me as it seemed to be just a direct continuation of DS1. The hollow crown giving us a way to ignore, but not break the curse was intriguing, but it just wasn't followed up on.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, I feel like people heavily exaggerate the gankiness of DS2. If you just play carefully and steadily, there won't be that many situations when you're attacked by multiple enemies and when it happens - these enemies are rather weak (and let's not pretend like other parts of the series don't try to overwhelm you by numbers sometimes, they just have less tricky ambushes).

What makes it feel so ganky, I feel, is the fact that DS2 has got a clear idea of not encouraging running through levels. While in all the other parts of the series, running through levels is easy and smooth as you have a lot of i-frames, a lot of stamina, and enemies quickly forget about you, in DS2, the game really doesn't want you to do that and doesn't really hide it (It's especially clear in such areas as the Heide's Tower - it's not even nearly as crowded if you just go through it normally, step-by-step).

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve always felt that dark souls 2 is the worst in the series, but the entire series is amazing. Like dark souls 1 and 3 are easy 10/10s for me but dark souls 2 is a 9/10. I still highly recommend everyone to play it. The movement is different and I think that’s what most people ACTUALLY have an issue with. And “turn-based dark souls” isn’t necessarily bad if you know that’s how you need to treat the games combat. If people understood those 2 things going into it, I think they’d have a better time with it. I do think if the game had Ds3 movement and combat, it would easily be able to keep up with the other soul’s games.

snippet.textDisplay: DS2 is the ultimate mad hollow simulator. It somewhat makes me think of TES4 Oblivion's Shivering Isles. For the sake of every character being mildly forgetfull, perhaps even blissfull. And the contrast of design between the gritty dark dank zones and colorfull almost psychedelic zones is refreshing. Majula, Heide's Tower, Shrine of Amana and Shaded woods feel very comfortable. Gave a bit of the Never Ending Story/Labyrinth vibe, with an ounce of Dark Crystal.

I'm just here before increasingly longer and longer response videos.

although this can be said for just about every game, they all have merits, they all have drawbacks. If anything I felt 2 was more sandbox like compared to the other Souls games. There's the option for the player to collect 1 Million souls or collect the 4 Lord souls, and with the bonfire ascetics can raise the level of the area and reset the area to the next new game cycle. This makes it seems like it's even more "open" than the player is first presented with

I thought I'd hate this game because I heard so much negativity about it, but I ended up liking it a lot. It's not as good as 1 and 3 but it's not some travesty. I think ADP filters a lot of people because rolls are their crutch. Just realize that iframes start at the beginning of rolls in this game, and suddenly it's sekiros block system, but with rolling. I find it amazing that people say the ADP makes the game too hard, when it's the easiest DS.
The dlc though? I HATE the dlc, it's the worst of all DS games.
