snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 is my guilty pleasure and I'll play it once a year while watching reviews on it.
That being said, I think it's important to distinguish between subjective enjoyment and objectively quantifyable quality and that they are not the same. I love Deadly Premonition which is an utter fuckfest in terms of gameplay and performance. And I don't care about Final Fantasy games, although they are apparently really really great.

Another thing is context I think. DS2 in the Context of Demon's Souls and moreover DS1(lateron ds3 which went more towards ds1) fell very short at the time. We had 2 games prior and especially DS1 set the tone and quality of how DS ought to be. And DS2 just fucked that up on so many fronts. SOTFS made it infinitely worse anf I think most people hate that version the most.

Nowadays in the context of Bloodborne, Sekiro, Elden Ring and a bazillion of soulslikes, the perception has changed and DS2 seems to experience a renaissance. I myself went from disappointment, to hating it, to having it as guilty pleasure and now I got an old PS3 and a vanilla DS2 copy and started a playthrough. The fps are atrocious, but I am already having more fun than with SOTFS

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 is one of my favorites. The world interaction functions are top tier. Explode certain walls, make the enemies break them, move traps, get naked to run in acid, zip lining, light torches, torches help you see, burn things with torches, wind and water can put out torches, reveal hidden enemies with torches, distract enemies with moaning trees, scare enemies with torches, rings help you traverse paths, light up braziers with torches, break doors, knocking on doors so enemies will open them for you, secret trap doorways, dowse yourself in water to minimize fire damage, set off explosive barrels with fire, heal springs, unpetrifying people, Giant Seeding invaders, invaders joining the Looking Glass Knight fight, booby trapping your world and attracting invaders, and equipment durability actually mattering, but sometimes it breaks into something better.

As for lore, at least 65% of DS3's world is effected by DS2's lore. Then 20-30% is DS1's. The rest is DS3's alone. Almost NOBODY can tell you the tree sorcerer Pontiff is a descendant to the Oracle in DS2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have a completely different interpretation of the story, that I remember even came from Vaatis videos, so I find it surprising that you have a different one and then recommend Vaatis videos. The game hints a lot that Drangleic is Lordran and that just so much time and so many cycles have passed that nobody remembers the old names. Chloanne says something along those lines directly. The great one's drop the souls of the great one's from DS in NG+ and the old iron king hints at having a fused souls with gwyn. Also children of Manus exist here and obviously the first flame is in the throne of want. That is also why the original ending of the game had no choice. 

-"Once fire is linked, souls will flourish anew and all of this will play out again. It is your choice to embrace or renounce this." No matter if you burn yourself in the fire or step away, the cycle will continue no matter what. Flames will eventually be linked anyway. There is no escape. 

-"Beyond the scope of light, beyond the reach of dark. What could possibly await us?" The alternative ending is you becoming so powerful that you exist outside the cycle, you cannot go hollow or lose your humanity. Once the crowns are together if you have them on, when you die, you never lose your humanity in game. You don't usher in a new age of dark. That cannot happen, the cycle is forced to continue for eternity. You instead grow so powerful that you exist outside the cycle as an all powerful being beyond the influence of the curse.


Also DS3s Story makes zero sense if you read the lore of DS2 and even DS1 to some extent. So I don't think that a single thought was put into when DS3 happens compared to 2. I believe that it was completely ignored simply because some fans were angry that DS2 was not like one and not a direct continuation. If you wanted to go insane and try to make sense of 3 when you assume that DS2 ever happened then it would have to be after main game DS3 but before the last area in DS3 and with it the Ringed city DLC .

snippet.textDisplay:
Man I hate and loved the Sotfs edition at same time, I hate how they unnesseceraly change the enemy placement, Best example on how awful it is, is the first two area of the game, 
When you first entered the forest of the fallen giants, you see the Heide Knight sitting besides a tree in an open area seemingly passive, It gives the player an option to fight him early on or come back to him later, Essentially treating him as an Optional Miniboss, and I like that, 

The Sotfs however changes that Into generic Gank mob that attacks the player, And what's worse is that they Turned the Heide Knights from a rare Miniboss that's spread out around the world for us to hunt down and get their guaranteed gear, Into a generic enemy that you have to farm in Heide's tower of flame, Idc if it's lore accurate for them to be mass produced in that area, it's just bad game design to mass produced such powerful enemy there early in the game, 

Also that dragon Is extremely out of place, It really destroys our First Impression of them, from first appearance being the Guardian dragon boss into a normal mob in Heide's Tower for sotfs.

snippet.textDisplay:
Like? I LOVE dark souls 2. Better than 3 and better than Elden Ring. I think Ds3 and ER are praised too much and Ds2 definitely given no credit for all that it does right. I love the pvp, the build variety, the way duel standing works, being able to replay bosses and encounters and get extra boss souls woth asthetics. The lore is also fantastic and there's a soothing and sad somber tone set by Majula hopeful seaside cliffs, the Forest of fallen giants sad and torn down battlegrounds of a battle once fought, the sheer variety of the areas too. I also love the way new game actually feel like they matter and each one feels like a new variation of that same journey. I love Ds2, unashamedly, and I do believe that the game, while flawed and dated, still embarsses games like ds3 and ER which have some very dated mechanics themselves for games that are meant to be "masterpieces" but simply don't live up to this. I believe Elden Ring's damage scaling is terrible, the horse combat is clunky, the open world is mostly barren, the dungeons are repetitive, the fire giant is just...BLAH. not a terrible game , I enjoy ER, but definitely not a masterpiece or game of the year in any way. 

Also side note, Frigid outskirts is great. Yea I said it, great. it's meant to be a CO OP area, and if you tag team the areas with a friend, navigating the frigid fucklands in a blur of snow running for ur life and fighting reindeer in the blinding snow storm is a thrill and hiding out for shelter in building before moving on is fantastic. Just sayin.

snippet.textDisplay: Something different in ds2 is the protagonists ( the character you play as) goal. In ds1 and ds3 you are a chosen one who will supposedly link the flame anew. In ds2 tho your character is looking for a way to cancel or negate his own curse and thus lore wise the correct ending would be to leave the final throne room and continue searching for a way to fight the curse. Something close to it is by getting all the dlc crowns and talking to Vendrick who gives you the immunity to hollowing.

DS1 has the best world design, DS3 has the best bosses, BB has the best atmosphere and arguably best weapons, Sekiro the best combat, even tho its not my favorite I can see its genius, Elden Ring has the best customization in play style and Demons Souls just started it all and got an surprising amount right for a first take. snippet.textDisplay:
I think dark souls 2 has some great ideas and aspects and I want to enjoy it, but I have serious problems with the controls of ds2. They feel more cluncky than in the first dark souls and it really takes me out of the experience when crossing a narrow bridge is nervewrecking because I cant tell when the game will recognise me moving the joystick to the side and how strong it will react. I am glad they never used that control system again and I wish the game would get a remake someday, because other than that I really like it.

Also, I enjoyed that video, it was really well made!

snippet.textDisplay: One of the biggest problems I see whenever Dark Souls 2 is mentioned is how it's compared to all the other games. It had a rough rocky development. It was built around Ps3 and Xbox 360 in mind, SOTFS I wouldn't call a remaster. More of a way to bundle the game and dlcs together to be affordable. Demon Souls got a true remaster going from Ps3 to Ps5, that's a huge leap. Sekiro came out in 2019. Elden Ring came out in 2022, a lot has changed since 2012 and 2015. And when looking at Dark Souls 1, 2, then Bloodborne; the difference is Dark Souls 1 and Bloodborne same director. Dark Souls 2, 2 different directors. Originally it was going to be open world, changed entirely after halfway through development. Crazy the hurdles in the development. Gotta appreciate.

snippet.textDisplay:
The story is actually pretty cohesive, more so than the other Dark Souls games imo, if you read the items and don’t skip dialogue. Some of the NPCs (like Vendrick and Alsanna) actually tell you what is going on and you even go back in time to see for yourself what happened to Drangleic during the war with the giants. Incredible game. the story really blew me away. The theme/plotlines involving the various queens who were all fragments of Manus was particularly creative and well executed.

Another thing I love is the level of customization and the variety of weapons and armor. Most people have a weird, unique character, as opposed to Elden Ring and DS3 (not shitting on them, I love them) where you will a lot of people wearing the same sets, using the same weapons and the same spells.

Most people have a weird, unique character, as opposed to Elden Ring and DS3 (not shitting on them, I love them) where you will a lot of people wearing the same sets, using the same weapons and the same spells.

I think the whole games more focusing on the curse of hollowing and the first sin being linking the fire, and what the characters make of it, is the most interesting narrative in the series.
Aldia and Vendricks stories, as well as how the other Kings dealt with their respective problems (and the curse) is the highlight of the game.

Also Aldia's ending isen't about becoming the Dark Lord. It's about refusing to take part in the cycle and seeking something else. Maybe another solution to the curse or simply indifference.

snippet.textDisplay:
I recently finished Dark Souls II for the first time (DSII Vanilla, not SotFS)
I tried DSII a few years ago after finishing Bloodborne, I was playing the SotFS edition, and didn't enjoy it due to the many ambush type fights and mobs and weird placements of Branches of Yore statues. So I uninstalled it and didn't really think about it anymore. Finished Dark Souls III and Dark Souls Remastered in that time (genuinely don't really understand why Dark Souls I gets so much love, it's opening hours are great for the most part but after Anor Londo it's a shit show for the most part).

I came across a few videos that explained that DSII vanilla was a better more enjoyable game, that it didn't have all those hindrances that SotFS does have. So I bought that with the DLC and tried that game. I finished it in a week, spent 50 hours on my first playthrough, and enjoyed almost all of it (fuck the Frigid Outskirts). It had beautiful VARIED locations, fun bossfights that if you explored the area actually gave you an edge against them (really loved that, actually incentivized exploring and learning about the world), awesome weapon builds and armor and lovable NPCs
It's not a masterpiece, it has its faults for sure, but I genuinely enjoyed it despite some of the BS with hitboxes at times. I was preaching for years that DSII just wasn't very good based on my experience with SotFS but I honestly am glad I was proven wrong with the original. 
I honestly believe some of the content in DSII is among the best in the series, like the Burnt Ivory King in the Frozen Eleum Loyce DLC.

I even started another playthrough, something I've only done with Bloodborne and Dark Souls III before it (I can't bring myself to do that in the OG Dark Souls really... the final hours of that game were just not enjoyable)

snippet.textDisplay:
3 years ago when i first played through Dark souls 3, i was really into it played 6-8 hours since i was on summer break. After i was done i needed more, so i bought dark souls 2 and was heavily disapointed. so i never touched it again until 3 months ago, i went in completly blind i had managed to go 3 years without ever watching a single video about the game, but i loved the series so much that i had to give it a try and i gotta say i was positively suprised. I actually liked it, it almost gave me the same feeling i had when playing ds3 oder eldenring. i never saw any negatives while playing because yes i enjoyed it, it gave me the same thrill the other games gave me, it was an entirely different experience but with the same gameplay that i loved so much. I never used any life gems since i never saw the need to "why should i rely on slow healing consumables if i had my trusty estus flask " i thought. the enemy placements and the ganks are bad but why should i care it just brings that extra difficulty, i never had to go through the areas more than 3-4 times so i didnt care that they were filled with enemies, even shrine of armana and iron keep werent a big problem since if the enemys got anoying i just had to take another approach. But these are the words of someone that played all the titles before ds2, i can see that people that play ds2 first will not enjoy it and that people that came from ds1 also wouldnt like it, but to me its just more dark souls and u cant go wrong with more DARK SOULS. overall it took me about 45 hours to play through it blind, some areas can get confusing but nothing that Fextralife cant solve i guess. so yes i do agree Dark Souls 2 is a "good game" and i shouldnt have waited 3 years to play it.
PS. Agilty is stupid especially if you go in blind, but putting a few levels into it wont kill your build.

snippet.textDisplay:
ADP is great. The problem with ADP is that the greatness of ADP is not properly explained by the game, even, IIRC, in an obscure way like through NPC hinting.
The reason why ADP is great is because it decouples i-frames from equipment. This is part of what makes DS2 peak fashion souls, though I still hate that they put item discovery on a bunch of ugly helmets.

The decoupling also means there can be a disconnect with i-frames and the actual animation which can be a shining example to hate on for players already trying to hate the game. But the penalties for heavy equipment just seems most fair in this game. I do wish defensive capabilities of armor scaled up a bit more though.

Overall, while I enjoyed the game, the DLCs are what saved this game for me and make me think of it fondly and not more neutrally.

snippet.textDisplay:
I guess on a mechanical level DS2, was always pretty good and offered a tons of variation in equipment and different enemies to play around with, but back in the day I was quite disappointed by the level-design, as well as the tone of the game. After finishing it once, I simply had no desire to actually explore it further. 

The level design, ditching the interconnected world of the first game, that all to often hit me with a sense of wonder and exploration, was quite a let down (not that the later games did better, DS2 was just the first to let me down), as well as the enemy placement (not that Scholar necessarily improved much upon).

Tone-wise, after leaving the awesome tutorial area, it quickly felt more like your average "everything and the kitchen-sink" - fantasy world (compared to the first game's setting that felt more mythical with every step you took).  Until Scholar added some details, I thought DS2 was probably just "Dark Souls Gaiden" a side-story that the publisher tried to sell as Part 2 for the west: "While the Chosen Undead fight's his way through heaven and hell, to have a word with God - some inconsequential stuff happens down on earth in Drangleic".

Not that I think that later games captured me as much as Dark Souls 1. I guess, you can't bottle lightning twice (or at least it was unlikely for me to be hit by it twice :-) ).

snippet.textDisplay: dark souls 2's gameplay is inferior mechanically and the fact that when the game came out no one knew that you had to level adp in order to not get hit when dodging is criminal. SotFS also adds a ridiculous amount of enemies to the areas, artificially pumping up the difficulty while the bosses are hardly challenging, with few exceptions. There are good qualities but I think it isn't controversial to say overall it is the weakest of the souls games. Personally, I enjoyed every single souls entry but this was definitely the least fun and least memorable for me

snippet.textDisplay: I adore DS2. I love the Abyss covenant activities and its boss is an All-Timer for me. I love the dark fairy tale environments and the gorgeous scenery in the Shrine of Amana. The Sunken King DLC is my favorite map out of all DS DLC maps, with the Ringed City a close second. I love the build variety and hidden weapon mechanics, like how you can get that halberd (?) from the rat place, and then break it by the bird’s nest to change it to the most OP twinblade in the game. It’s such a massive game with deep, obtuse mechanics and I dig this video for giving it the praise it deserves. Liked, subbed and Big Ups!

snippet.textDisplay: All of Ds2 felt like if you took lost izalith, tomb of the giants and then distilled that down and assumed that was dark souls and made a whole game like it. I wanted to think that they would've learned what not to do in the dlc but the same type of excessive ganks were still prevalent. For every one thing Ds2 did right, it gets under my skin in 3 other ways. Why would I care about ng+ if I can barely stand the base game? I did play this game 3 times, once before scholar, two runs after. And I didn't like it. The positives are not enough to out weigh the negatives for me. I can't enjoy the weapon and spell variety If I just don't enjoy the game's combat.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wouldn't entirely agree that DS2 is "underrated", but rather more so is just over-hated.  I think even most defenders of DS2 can agree upon its shortcomings, it's just that the haters tend to overexaggerate those shortcomings while ignoring some of the actually good parts of the game.

DS2 is probably the most experimental of the franchise. Even Bloodborne and Elden Ring have more in common with DS1&3 than DS2 does. With that experimentation comes both highs and lows. Out of the trilogy, DS2 is probably the game that could most benefit from not just a polished remaster, but a full ground up remake. Not to make it more like the other games, but rather to further refine its best qualities while shaving off the rougher edges.

snippet.textDisplay:
6:05 he does not need to land this atack or even do it, pursuer can use dark magic regardless.
Absolutely love this game. There are a lot of things that reasonably annoy people, but I just see them as part of a challenge. Hear me out, it supposed to be unfair. Do you think if you were in DS2 universe someone would fight you "fair"? No, if enemies really want to get your souls, they will do anything. It can be terrible from gameplay perspective, but understandable from story perspective, and like Lenny said, does not matter if you like the game.
Also got to love how bosses and enemys tell the story just by being placed in certain places. You would think that Nashandra being so easy is bad boss design. But you don't take into account how SHE is the one who enters the fog. Most of the areas were designed by king Vendrick so Nashandra could not take the throne but you could, becoming stronger in the process. Making you final measure against Nashandra becoming monarch.
